XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.33 am): I table the public report of ministerial expenses for the period 1 July 2009 to 30 June 2010.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Public Report of Ministerial Expenses for the period 1 July 2009 to 30 June 2010 [ 2744 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: The report shows that ministerial expenditure has remained reasonable and that fiscal responsibility remains a cornerstone of our government. Compared to 2008-09, overall expenditure has increased by only 0.72 per cent. This is below CPI and the enterprise bargaining increases to staff.

The period of this expenditure included the new IT rollout for ministerial offices and the opposition office. As in previous years, some expenses have gone up while others have gone down. Despite enterprise bargaining increases, employee related costs were down by $23,000 on the previous year. Other savings include motor vehicle costs, which were down nearly $26,000; air charters, which were down $17,500; and communication charges, which decreased by nearly $83,000, along with domestic travel, which was down $207,000.

Expenses for my own office, excluding the Townsville office, increased by 5.38 per cent. While an increase to my office expenses, this actually represents whole-of-government savings that were generated from economies of scale by centralising into my office a range of administrative support services including media monitoring, regional media coordination and travel support. This report shows that ministerial expenditure is being maintained at reasonable levels in these tough economic times.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.35 am): Mr Speaker, I know that you, along with others, were very pleased to enjoy the best that the Ekka had to offer. The Ekka wrapped up last Saturday, on 14 August, after 10 days of outstanding crowds and fun for everyone. I think that all members of the House would be pleased to see that the 2010 Ekka was a terrific success, with more than 400,000 people pouring through the gates--up 20 per cent on last year.

Mr Speaker, you know that the Ekka is in town when RMs and Akubras become a common sight in the city as the bush meets the town. Traditions such as dagwood dogs, strawberry sundaes, hair-raising rides, fireworks, cotton and wool parades and show bags were popular once again.

I understand that the animal nursery was again the most popular attraction for city raised children at this year’s Ekka. Some children for the first time in their lives saw where milk really comes from. Others were lucky enough to see a lamb being born--a highlight for those children.

The RNA hosted the traditional community cabinet on Monday, 9 August, and I was very pleased to have the opportunity to thank them for their hospitality. I was also pleased to compete in the annual best steak sandwich cook-off. In all modesty, I have to declare to the House that John Cotter of AgForce and I cleaned up with the assistance of a secret ingredient--Mrs Law’s cooked salad dressing, with eggs from local chickens, Mavis and Joyce. It was a bottler.

The Queensland Government Pavilion was again popular, providing information on initiatives such as our flying start for Queensland children. Healthy fruit snacks were distributed each day and thousands of visitors now know how to make sure that every dollar counts, with information provided on government concessions, rebates and discounts. I think we would all agree, as I said, that the Ekka is a very important event on Queensland’s calendar, and our government is proud to support it.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.37 am): It was with pleasure last week that I announced Queensland Events had secured a deal to host the annual rugby league clash between the Indigenous All Stars and the NRL All Stars right through to 2013. This event is about much more than sport. No-one who saw the inaugural game played at Skilled Park earlier this year will forget it. Indigenous league players had dreamt of this opportunity for decades--their best players together in one team, playing for their families, their communities and their people. What tremendous pride they showed as they pulled on their jerseys and what an enormously positive influence they were on our Indigenous young people.

The game sold out months in advance. It was watched by nearly 1.3 million people nationally and it won its timeslot in Sydney and Brisbane. In addition, $1.5 million was raised for community programs focused on Indigenous areas. We can expect the same excitement and passion and level of interest when the next game is played at Skilled Park on 12 February 2011.

Celebrations will include the Bumehla Festival, which means ‘celebration of the people’. This free public Indigenous cultural festival will be held at the Broadwater Parklands on 11 and 12 February to coincide with this game. The match will also be good news for Gold Coast hotels, restaurants and shops, with 40 per cent of ticket buyers expected to be from outside South-East Queensland.

Tickets for next year’s game went on sale to NRL club members last week on 11 August and will go on sale to the general public this Wednesday, 18 August. I have no doubt it will be even more popular next year, and I encourage people to get online this week and get their tickets for what I think will be a great game next year.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts)
(9.38 am): I am pleased to announce this morning a new addition to Brisbane’s events calendar. On Saturday, 2 October this year we will hold the inaugural Brisbane Open House. Public and private buildings of architectural and historical significance will be open to the public for special, behind-the-scenes tours. Up to 21 buildings will feature, including the Queensland Performing Arts Centre, the Gallery of Modern Art, Old Government House, Santos House and the Masonic Memorial Temple.

This will be the chance for people to tour the areas that are normally closed to the public and the opportunity to unlock some of the secrets and interesting facts behind the buildings that give Brisbane its unique style. For instance, at GoMA the conservation area on the top of the building will be open offering spectacular views to the city. Visitors will also see how artworks are restored.

People touring QPAC will have a rare chance to explore not only backstage but even under the recently renovated stage. Having done that tour myself I can recommend it. It is one of only two stages in Australia of sufficient size and technical excellence to host something like the world acclaimed Paris Opera Ballet. Visitors to the Masonic Memorial Temple, which is almost 90 years old, will see one of Queensland’s largest pipe organs. I know members will be interested in that.

Queensland government architect Philip Follent deserves credit for this idea. He, along with the Brisbane Development Association, has worked in partnership to get Brisbane Open House up and running. Open house events like this are held in London, New York and Melbourne. This year in Melbourne 65,000 visitors inspected 65 sites. We are aiming for 10,000 visitors for the first Brisbane Open House. I am pleased that the Governor, Penny Wensley, who is patron of the event, will announce further details at a launch today at 11 o’clock at the Gallery of Modern Art.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.41 am): Queensland grandparents and their families will be able to take part this year in Queensland’s very first Grandparents Day on 7 November. This will be an annual event held on the first Sunday of each November to celebrate the contributions that grandparents make to Queensland families every day. Like Mother’s Day and Father’s Day, it will recognise the importance and increasing role that grandparents in a modern world are playing in supporting families and particularly young children.

From providing babysitting services to parents to being a source of endless expert advice for mums and dads around the state, grandparents are there to help Queensland families. Queensland will lead the way when it comes to Grandparents Day. Queensland will be the first Australian state to officially recognise grandparents with their very own special day. I hope families seize the opportunity. Many schools and other organisations already offer special days for grandparents. But Queensland’s first Grandparents Day is a unified showing of thanks and appreciation from the whole community.

I think it is fair to say that most grandparents will not expect or want large or expensive gifts. Like Mother’s Day and Father’s Day it is often the handmade gifts and the handwritten cards that touch one’s heart the most. This is about showing grandparents that we appreciate their help and recognise the sacrifices they make to help us. Grandparents Day is the result of extensive consultation with Queenslanders. The community settled on the November date during extensive consultation through the Get Involved website as well as direct contact with electorate offices.

I acknowledge that one does not have to be a senior to be a grandparent, and nor does one need to be a grandparent to be a senior. But as I am sure many will be aware, this week is Seniors Week. Seniors Week is a week-long celebration of seniors and the great contribution that they all make to our community. This Queensland-wide celebration, from Saturday, 14 August to next Sunday, is a great opportunity for Queenslanders of all ages and backgrounds to get together and celebrate the contribution that older Queenslanders make. As part of Seniors Week, I will be presenting to 15 older Queenslanders at Parliament House tomorrow the 25th Premier’s Awards for Queensland Seniors for their work as volunteers in the community.

The announcement today of Queensland Grandparents Day is one of a raft of commitments outlined in the first of five two-year plans in the Positively Ageless Seniors Strategy. As part of this strategy, the government has also committed to making life easier for grandparents raising grandchildren by creating extra opportunities for time out. This support is provided in the form of recreational camps and recreational activities.

In June we launched our elder abuse campaign and we will continue our promotion of the Seniors Enquiry Line run by Lifeline. In addition, we are helping the University of the Third Age, a truly great organisation, to provide online learning opportunities for seniors in regional Queensland. We are expanding our Granfriends program to use the experience of seniors in schools to teach craft and other skills to children. Grandparents deserve our thanks and Grandparents Day is the perfect opportunity to do that. I am pleased that Queensland will lead the way. I hope that other states will follow suit.

I thank all the seniors organisations right around Queensland who do a wonderful job all year round. But in Seniors Week they do a particularly outstanding job, reaching out to older people in our community and helping them to live active, happy and connected lives. I want to particularly thank those organisations for their advice, their assistance and their ideas in putting together our seniors strategy and particularly for their idea about having a grandparents day.

I particularly acknowledge my minister Phil Reeves, who brought this to the government’s attention after senior groups in his area--predominantly led by Val French, who, as everyone knows, is a great champion and advocate for older Queenslanders--put forward this idea. It is a terrific idea. We are very pleased to back it. I am very pleased today to announce that 7 November will be Queensland’s first Grandparents Day. May it be the first of many.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.45 am): I do note that the RNA did not invite me to participate in a curry sausages cook-off with anyone. I do note that you could purchase two packs of Suncoast Gold wasabi macadamias for $25--a very good deal--at the Woolworths pavilion, which I did. It is a great Queensland company.

The World Health Organisation last week declared that last year’s H1N1 swine flu virus had moved into the postpandemic stage. It was welcome news, but we cannot rest on our laurels. Some people may be tempted to think that, because the worldwide effect of swine flu this year has not reached the peaks of last year or the worst fears of the World Health Organisation, swine flu can now be disregarded as a serious threat. That would be folly.

As of 27 June, globally there had been more than 18,200 confirmed swine flu deaths in more than 200 countries. Last year, Australia’s death toll reached 191 from more than 37,700 cases. In Queensland last year there were 12,000 laboratory confirmed cases with 41 of those proving fatal.

So far this year, Queensland has been fortunate to avoid any swine flu deaths. We have a way to go in the winter flu season, but so far so good. Despite having escaped tragedy so far this winter, it would be a mistake for us to now sit back on our hands in the mistaken belief that swine flu is no longer a threat. The spectre of a more virulent form appearing down the track remains. Pigs may not fly, but without vigilance we have learned that swine flu can grow wings.

Our aim is to protect Queenslanders from the worst of this pandemic. That is why the Bligh and Gillard governments are partnering on the swine flu vaccine rollout for a second year. We are approaching one full year since the vaccine became available. While the elderly are the group at highest risk of death as a result of seasonal influenza, the young and middle aged were identified as the most at-risk groups of contracting swine flu--particularly those with chronic, immunosuppressant and respiratory problems, pregnant women, the obese and Indigenous people.

Panvax H1N1 was developed by CSL Ltd and approved by the Therapeutic Goods Administration for people aged 10 years and over on 18 September last year. The Bligh government began delivering a free vaccination program in Queensland, in partnership with the Labor government in Canberra, on 30 September last year. It was extended to children aged over six months in early December. The vaccination program extended to mobile teams visiting community clinics in remote and regional areas of the state from the Torres Strait to the cape, the gulf and the central west.

The total number of pandemic H1N1 2009 vaccines reported as administered in Queensland to 30 June 2010 was 931,729. In addition to this, 126,934 vaccinations were administered at more than 380 weekend school based vaccination clinics between February and May 2010. A total of 931,729 vaccinations were reported. More may have been administered but not reported.

The 2010 seasonal flu vaccine also provides protection against H1N1 2009 influenza. Those deemed to be in high-risk groups were provided the vaccine free of charge. This year--from 1 January to 8 August--there have been 682 cases of influenza notified to Queensland Health. Of those, 617 were typed as influenza A--with 71 confirmed as H1N1--64 were typed as influenza B, one was not typed and none, I am advised, have proved fatal.

For the same period last year--that is, 1 January to 8 August--there were 16,008 notifications of influenza. I noted with interest two days ago an interview by Warren Boland on 612 ABC Radio with Professor Anne Kelso, who is head of the World Health Organisation Collaborating Centre for Reference and Research on Influenza in Australia. The professor was of the opinion that the federal and Queensland governments had taken the appropriate insurance by purchasing the pandemic H1N1 2009 vaccine. The mild flu season we have experienced to date, Professor Kelso said, could be largely attributed to those vaccines coupled with the antibodies developed by some 20 per cent of the Australian population by the end of the flu season last year. She also said Australia had far fewer fatalities simply because of the incredible hospital care people received.

In Queensland we had more than 41,000 emergency department presentations for flu and winter symptoms between April and October 2009, 15,000 more than the same period in 2008. We had 1,200 admissions to hospital and more than 160 intensive care unit admissions due to pandemic H1N1 2009 infections. Certainly, the additional 55 ventilators we purchased for our intensive care units helped our fantastic Queensland Health staff to save lives. Professor Kelso also had a word of warning and said that the flu season could still be ahead of us, telling Warren Boland that it is quite common for flu to not really get going until August and then peak in September and wane in October. She said that it was not too late to be vaccinated. For my part, I will continue to urge Queenslanders, old and young, to be vaccinated. I certainly have been.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (9.50 am): Once again it is official: for the fourth month in a row we are leading jobs growth in the nation. Last Thursday the independent umpire, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, released its latest jobs numbers for the month of July. The figures attest: they provide the hard numbers, the data and the evidence that Queensland is the jobs-generating capital of Australia for the fourth month in a row--not per capita, not as a percentage, not pro rata but straight up and flat out more jobs were created here than in any other state. Not only have we outperformed the rest of Australia in jobs generation but we have now delivered 12 straight months of jobs-generating growth into the Queensland economy--that is 12 straight months of jobs growth, month on month the number of jobs increasing, one full year of delivering new jobs and creating new jobs for the people of Queensland.

In July we saw 5,600 new jobs created in Queensland, more than a third of the nation’s total jobs growth. This takes our jobs target down to now be at 38,800--well over halfway to our target of 100,000 net new jobs this term, and delivering it well before halfway through this term of the parliament. It is absolutely clear that the Queensland economy is heading in the right direction and that our economic plan is working, building a recovery and generating jobs just like we said it would. Our trend unemployment rate now sits at 5 per cent, unchanged from a revised June figure. While this is down from the peak of six per cent last October, we recognise that we are not out of the woods yet. The task is not complete. There is an underlying volatility to the data that demonstrates the challenging nature of the situation, and that is why you need a plan. You need a strong plan to deliver and to restore the Queensland economy to build the recovery. That means that we need to keep creating more jobs, and that is what we are doing and that is what we are committed to doing.

We are doing it by putting in place our second consecutive $17 billion building program which is, again, the biggest in the nation, a program that is building hospitals, police stations, public housing and schools--infrastructure a growing state needs and the economic stimulus needed to keep Queenslanders in jobs. We have put in place employment programs like the Green Army that is giving job seekers and young people the training and the knowledge they need to get a start in the labour force. We have delivered tax rebates for employers of apprentices and trainees. We have implemented a suite of first home buyer concessions to stimulate the housing market. We have maintained the lowest payroll tax rate in the nation.

At the last election the Bligh government promised to create 100,000 new jobs if elected. We knew that it would be a tough task, but we remain committed--committed to meeting our target and to continuing to create jobs for Queenslanders. That is the evidence, the incontrovertible evidence from the independent umpire--four straight months of leading the nation in jobs.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr FRASER: Those opposite do not like it. We have had four straight months of leading the nation in generating jobs and 12 straight months of generating jobs, and we are absolutely determined to continue.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (9.54 am): Seniors Week is off and running. The member for Brisbane Central and I launched the week at a special intergenerational walk at the weekend at New Farm Park. I congratulate the Council on the Ageing and its member organisations for organising the event and for the great work they do for seniors, day in and day out. From Burketown to Baralaba and St George to the Sunshine Coast, community organisations and the dedicated team from the Office for Seniors have planned some fantastic events and programs for Seniors Week. Rockhampton seniors will make lots of fun and noise at the Rockhampton Seniors Rage event, and the member for Albert tells me the Seniors Have Talent competition to be held at the Gold Coast will be a must-see event. The member for Burdekin will be pleased to hear that her local Burdekin Community Association has also received funding to help celebrate the value of seniors in her local community.

I toured the state listening to seniors about what they wanted in the Queensland Seniors Strategy. Seniors talked about the cost-of-living pressures. Our Bligh government responded with increased concessions. We responded with our Every Dollar Counts website that brings all rebates and concessions together in the one place. What form do the conservative governments have on easing the cost-of-living pressures? They in fact put the pressure up. The LNP models itself on the Western Australian government. What did the Western Australian government do in the past year? It cut concessions by $17 million! And we know what Tony Abbott plans to do: he plans on introducing a Coles and Woolies tax, driving up the cost of groceries.

Seniors have talked about making sure they have continued access to quality health services, including dental care. Queenslanders understand more than most the consequences of the decisions Tony Abbott took as health minister in the Howard government--$1 billion ripped out of our hospitals, GP training places cut, public dental services cut. Tony Abbott has pledged to cut more health services. Our state Labor government is working with the federal government to ease the pressure on seniors and to improve health services, including public dental care. We know that every dollar counts.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (9.56 am): Women across Australia are banding together to fight climate change as part of the nationwide 1 Million Women campaign. The campaign encourages women throughout the country to do their bit to combat global warming by cutting one million tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions over the next two years--the equivalent of taking 250,000 cars off our roads in 12 months. Every woman who joins the campaign takes a pledge to cut one tonne of carbon dioxide from their daily lives within a year of joining by doing simple things such as conserving energy at home, reducing their waste, buying local produce and taking public transport or riding a bike instead of driving their car for at least one trip a week.

The Bligh government is proud to support this important campaign, with our Premier leading the charge as the first ambassador registered in Queensland. And the response from everyday Queenslanders continues to grow. Since the campaign was launched, more than 6,100 Queensland women have joined and have collectively pledged to climate savings equating to an amazing 12,200 kilograms of greenhouse gas reductions. Currently this represents around 22 per cent of the national effort, and Queensland got a huge boost in the last weeks thanks to the efforts of the 1 Million Women campaign at the Ekka. Over 2,000 women were signed up over the course of the Ekka, a clear indication of the motivation of Queensland women to help cut carbon emissions. I was pleased to join the Ekka recruitment drive last Monday and it was great to see so many people eager for the opportunity to make a difference.

This campaign is another step forward in reaching our Toward Q2 target of reducing Queensland’s household emissions by one-third by 2020. I know Queensland women can and will rise to the challenge of climate change and I urge all of the women in parliament to join the Premier and I and sign up to the 1 Million Women campaign at www.1millionwomen.com.au to make a difference. I say to Mr Abbott, who last night reaffirmed that he does not believe in climate change or global warming and thinks that it is not happening and is not real, that 2,000 women at the Ekka cannot be wrong.

Hon. S ROBERTSON (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade) (9.59 am): Overseas trade and investment is vital to a strong Queensland economy and the Queensland government remains committed to expanding our international business links. The work of Trade Queensland has pinpointed key international markets which, through strategic research and networking, are creating opportunities for Queensland businesses and supporting Queensland jobs.

As Queensland’s fifth largest merchandise export destination, Taiwan remains an important trading partner for our state. This week, Queensland’s special trade representative to China and Vietnam is leading a delegation of 14 Queensland companies to promote the state’s expertise in a range of sectors. Queensland specialities in in-flight training, architecture and design, building and construction, food and wine, education and training, and sports infrastructure and transportation will be showcased. This mission builds on the strengthening relationship between our two regions, which has already seen the establishment of the First Commercial Bank of Taiwan opening its Australian head office in Brisbane last year.

There is little doubt that the world’s economic gaze has recently sharpened towards Latin America. The Bligh government has taken early steps to establish a foothold in the market for Queensland businesses looking to expand their base. The Queensland government is very close to establishing its first official representation in Latin America through the appointment of a senior business development manager, who will be based in Santiago, Chile, within the Austrade office. As Chile is Australia’s third largest trading partner in Latin America, Mr Vega will make it easier for Queensland companies looking to take advantage of the free trade agreement, which eliminates Chile’s tariffs on almost 92 per cent of tariff lines, covering 97 per cent of goods. Queensland business is well positioned to cater for the key industry demands on Chile, including exports of coal, LNG, renewable energy, meat, wine and some dairy as well as mining and energy technology and civil engineering and consulting.

Vietnam, which gained entry into the World Trade Organisation in January 2007, is another market in which Queensland companies will soon have access to a dedicated in-market specialist. In a similar approach to that of Santiago, a new business development manager will soon be engaged in the Austrade office in Ho Chi Minh, supporting Queensland companies to access this important market. The Queensland government will continue a flexible approach to its international footprint, ensuring that Queensland companies receive a helping hand in trade and investment markets of interest to Queensland. Trade and Investment Queensland’s new overseas representatives, coupled with the current Taiwan trade mission, will support Queensland companies to grow their business to support jobs and the Queensland economy.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.01 am): On early childhood education the difference between the Bligh government and the Liberal National Party could not be more stark. The Bligh government is committed to a major reform of early childhood services to ensure that all Queensland four-year-olds get access to kindergarten. This Labor government is committed to an investment of $320 million over five years to provide up to 240 new kindergarten services where necessary. Labor will give all Queensland children a flying start to their education.

The Liberal National Party is committed to nothing--no additional kindergartens, no additional early childhood teachers; just a dishonest scaremongering campaign waged by the member for Moggill, a dishonest and sneaky email campaign aimed at causing stress to local kindergarten committees. Every kindergarten service will have its funding guaranteed at least at the same level of 2010 plus indexation and many existing kindergartens will receive more funding.

This Bligh state government is dedicated to ensuring that every young Queenslander has access to a quality education for the first time. Funding will recognise disadvantage services in remote and low socioeconomic areas. All existing DECKAS funded services will transition to the new scheme from January next year. This is not a one-off solution; this is an ongoing commitment by the state government to these existing community kindergartens beyond 2011.

This government’s objective is to increase the percentage of four-year-olds in kindergarten from 32 per cent to 95 per cent by 2014. Starting this week, the Creche and Kindergarten Association and Education Queensland will conduct 20 state-wide information forums with existing kindies outlining the changes and the support that is on offer. It does not matter where in Queensland the kindergarten service is and the population and demographic characteristics do not matter; these services will retain their current level of funding and it will be indexed. The government is working hand in hand with C&K to provide a business advisory service to each existing DECKAS service free of charge. The government will continue to work with individual service providers to maximise kindergarten delivery for Queensland’s four-year-old children. The Bligh government will give Queensland children a flying start to their education.

We hear nothing from the Liberal National Party on education and training--just sneaky emails to kindergartens spreading misinformation. They promised to dump the government’s $320 million plan for up to 240 kindergarten services across Queensland, scrapping 850 early childhood teachers and 2,000 construction jobs.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr WILSON: They do not like it when the cat is belled on them. Under Abbott and under the Liberal National Party in Queensland, Queensland kids will be left uneducated, untrained and unemployed.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.05 am): August traditionally marks the start of the bushfire season in Queensland and, once again, Mother Nature is right on time. In the past two weeks we have seen a number of vegetation fires develop in the state’s north, centre and south-east. Thankfully, through the good work of our volunteer rural fire brigades, supported by their urban and auxiliary counterparts and police, the fires were contained quickly and the damage was minimal.

In yet another demonstration of the government’s strong support for our rural fire brigades, I am pleased to announce today that 120 slip-on units will be made available to rural fire brigades free of charge this financial year. The units hold up to 500 litres of water and are designed to be easily mounted onto utilities and trucks for use in hazard-reduction operations, low-intensity firefighting and blacking-out work. These units are in addition to the 20 that are being provided to brigades across the state under the Queensland Fire and Rescue Service’s partnership with Reliance Petroleum.

The 120 slip-on units will particularly be targeted at rural brigades identified with primary producer functions and those that are unable to generate adequate funding for such units. The units will be supplied with speed loaders at a total cost of around $810,000. The fire commissioner has notionally allocated the units, with brigades around Charters Towers and Cloncurry, Barcaldine, Roma, Miles, Bundaberg, Innisfail, Mackay, Maryborough, Rockhampton, Toowoomba, Townsville and on Cape York Peninsula set to benefit from this allocation.

Thanks to strong, ongoing support from the Bligh government, the number of slip-on units being used by volunteer rural fire brigades across the state has more than doubled. There are currently around 2,400 units in the field, up from around 1,100 in 2003. In line with our Supporting Our Heroes election commitment, Queensland Fire and Rescue Service’s Rural Operations is working to deliver 25 new and replacement rural fire appliances this financial year and to retrofit Rural Fire Service appliances with fire-reflective curtains to protect firefighters should they be trapped in their vehicle. Petrol driven pumps are also being replaced with diesel driven pumps--another commitment that the Bligh government is delivering on.

The Bligh government is committed to supplying rural firefighters with the tools they need to respond to the threat of bushfires. As we saw at Willowbank yesterday, the bushfire season has begun. For those residents who live in or near bushland, including in city areas, now is the time to prepare a bushfire survival plan. Useful information is available on the Queensland Fire and Rescue website.

Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads) (10.07 am): The thriving port city of Gladstone will be a big winner in a re-elected federal Labor government. The Gillard government has pledged $50 million to complete the final stages of the Gladstone Port Access Road. It comes on top of $55 million being spent by the Bligh government on roads in Gladstone this financial year. The port access road is a vital link for this rapidly growing region. It services and supports the thriving port precinct, the emerging LNG industry on Curtis Island, the Yarwun industrial area and the mining industry in the booming Bowen Basin.

We have delivered stage 1 of the Gladstone Port Access Road. There is now a direct connection from our state controlled road network to the port. It means no more big freight trucks travelling through the CBD. That is important in a city like Gladstone, with growing volumes of traffic. More than 1,600 vehicles a day use the port access road and nearly 500 of those are heavy vehicles.

I look forward to working with the Gillard government to deliver the final two stages: extending the port access road even further to meet the future needs of industry, commerce, tourism and the local community. With this $50 million commitment from federal Labor, we will be able to get on with the job of delivering stages 2 and 3 of this important road link.

The proposed alignment will run parallel to the Dawson Highway. The final stages will see the port access road extended all the way to Red Rover Road at Callemondah. I say to the good people of Gladstone this morning: red, red rover, Gillard come over, because that is the right choice--the only choice for the people of Queensland on Saturday. The federal coalition has turned its back on this state’s engine room. Their Gladstone bag is empty. That is not surprising. We should not be surprised. Tony Abbott thinks transport infrastructure should be a state responsibility. It is a no-brainer. With Gillard for Gladstone we will be in like Flynn.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland)
(10.10 am): Two new fire ant infestations found outside the current restricted area have prompted Biosecurity Queensland to remind people of the dangers of human assisted movements. It is illegal to move high-risk material such as soil, plants and landscaping equipment from a fire ant restricted area without an inspection. Breaches of movement restrictions by developers, construction companies, landscapers and home renovators increase the risk of fire ant infestations spreading and could lead to the devaluation of South-East Queensland land.

The warning comes as Biosecurity Queensland confirms two new fire ant infestations, one near Ormeau on the Gold Coast, 8.5 kilometres from the nearest known infestation, and another in Clontarf, 11.5 kilometres from the nearest previous detection. In recent months there have been several serious breaches of soil movement restrictions. Regardless of whether these two new infestations were as a result of illegal or accidental movement, it is a timely reminder that all material moved from restricted areas needs inspection. We were alerted to these infestations in time to prevent the significant spread of fire ants but if it continues it could be disastrous for Queensland. Ignoring or forgetting to check movement restrictions threatens to unravel years of hard work in eradicating fire ants from Queensland. Fines of up to $1 million for businesses and $200,000 for individuals are in place for those found breaching movement restrictions.

Fire ants have the potential to ruin the outdoor way of life Queenslanders enjoy. In the US, Texas spends $1 million a year treating sporting fields and outdoor amenities for fire ant infestations so that they can be used by the public. Biosecurity Queensland will continue to work with councils, developers, landscapers and residents to communicate the risk of moving material around. Biosecurity Queensland has also extended the employment of all 191 fire ant staff to continue the fight against infestation. Biosecurity is everyone’s responsibility, but we are ensuring we have sufficient staff to battle on.

Both of these recent infestations were reported by people who have undergone fire ant training offered at the control centre. A Gold Coast City Council officer reported the Ormeau infestation and someone working in the area reported the one at Clontarf. Our system is clearly working. I urge everyone to check their yards for fire ants and report findings immediately to Biosecurity Queensland on 132523 and always comply with movement restrictions.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.13 am): In the Local Government Act 2009 there are new provisions in relation to the use of discretionary funds by councillors. Over the years there have been complaints about councillors who have appeared to have discretionary funds in their back pocket as it were. It seemed they could go to community functions and make on-the-spot decisions to hand over cheques for thousands of dollars. It seemed to some other community groups that this was unfair as councillors, through their discretionary funds, were able to favour some groups over others.
Mr Seeney: It’s unfair to the state members, who couldn’t do the same thing.

Ms BOYLE: I take that interjection. There have been some members of this House who have expressed their concern about this. It is now historical practice. There were also concerns that discretionary funds were not properly and transparently accounted for. The Auditor-General reported on this matter two years ago and, consequently, a new framework for councillors’ use of discretionary funds was included under section 109 of the new Local Government Act 2009 and the Local Government (Finance, Plans and Reporting) Regulation 2010. This has brought in new standards of integrity for mayoral and councillor discretionary funds.

The key elements of the new standards are that a council must let the public know the amount of money in the local government’s discretionary funds budgeted for use by each councillor for a financial year by publishing, within 20 business days after the adoption of the budget notice, the amount in a newspaper circulating generally in the local government area and by displaying the notice in a conspicuous place in the local government’s public office. The notice must invite community organisations to apply for allocation of some of these funds and it must state how they should apply. Then the actual allocation of councillors’ discretionary funds must comply with that council’s previously developed and adopted community grants policy.

This will bring to an end a practice that has no doubt been enjoyed by a number of councillors around the state over these many years. It will bring a new and a proper transparency and accountability for this use of ratepayer funds and it will provide some confidence for community groups that they have a fair chance to share in the moneys available.

Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning)
(10.15 am): I wish to draw to the attention of the House that yesterday, in line with statutory timetables, I tabled interim land use plans for seven newly declared urban development areas across the state. As part of the Bligh government’s commitment to managing growth across the state, we have tasked the Urban Land Development Authority to give consideration to new areas that could be declared as UDAs. In response, we now have UDAs that will help deliver affordable housing in regional cities, in resource towns and across the south-east corner. These new UDAs are part of the government’s commitment to improve land supply and housing diversity; deliver infrastructure and create employment; utilise best practice design principles to deliver a range of affordable housing options; and maximise sustainable outcomes.
Mr Johnson: In Blackwater, too?

Mr HINCHLIFFE: Wait for it, Vaughan. Under the Regional Housing Diversity program, and in conjunction with the local councils, sites at Oonoonba in Townsville, Andergrove in Mackay and Clinton in Gladstone, totalling more than 130 hectares of land, will demonstrate quality planning and development policy outcomes and will deliver more than 1,300 homes to the market while injecting more than 2,200 jobs into the local building industries. In cooperation with local councils, UDA sites at Blackwater, at Bowen Street, Roma and at Moranbah, encompassing more than 57 hectares of land, will address land and housing supply issues in resource areas to meet the urgent need for key worker housing. These UDAs will deliver more than 800 homes that will help ease the pressure in local markets and establish mechanisms for overcoming impediments to a reliable supply of suitable housing stock while supplying more than 1,000 jobs to the building industry. In South-East Queensland, the delivery of the Woolloongabba UDA delivers opportunities for up to 2,500 homes to be established in an area that is located close to public transport hubs and within the inner city.

The local communities for these seven sites will continually be involved as the development plans for these sites are progressed. This is part of the Bligh government’s commitment to engage and communicate with the local communities about our plans for managing growth.

Hon. RG NOLAN (Ipswich--ALP) (Minister for Transport)
(10.17 am): The Ekka is one of the biggest highlights on the Queensland calendar--an event that kids and adults alike look forward to every August. This year’s show was a raging success, with more than 400,000 people through the gates over the 10 days. I am very pleased to report that public transport once again played a big part in getting people to this iconic event. This year about 200,000 people caught a bus or a train to the Ekka. Ekka shuttle buses ran every 15 minutes until 8.30 most evenings from three city stops and the Windsor park and ride. The Exhibition train station was open and the Ekka loop operated frequently from 8.45 each morning.

The Department of Transport and Main Roads was on display at the Ekka this year. Many visitors to the stall were interested to learn more about the new Queensland driver’s licence, the secure ID card, which will be rolled out from later this year. One of the features of the display was an internet hook-up to the Here for Life web page, a site that allows people to put their knowledge of the road rules to the test. This proved very popular with young drivers. For those who have been driving for a number of years, our new refresher road rule brochure provided a worthwhile and easy-to-remember reminder for some of the dos and don’ts on the roads.

Public transport is the way to go when travelling to major events like the Ekka. Last year 2.3 million people took public transport to major events across South-East Queensland, including at Suncorp Stadium, the Gabba, Skilled Park and the Queensland Tennis Centre. Suncorp Stadium in particular has some of the finest public transport facilities in the world. So it is not surprising that when a crowd of 50,000 fans makes its way to the ground up to 90 per cent of them use public transport.
The Bligh government is delivering on public transport for major events, getting large numbers of people where they want to go when they want to go easily and conveniently.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Death of Mr J Atkins and Mr J McLean; Retirement of Mr W Wilson
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.20 am): Today I wish to note in this House the recent passing of two great Queenslanders in Mr Jim Atkins OAM and Mr Jeff McLean. These two men transcended their sporting endeavours and proved themselves to be great Queenslanders. We are all the poorer for their passing.

Jim Atkins was born in Grafton in 1916 and began training racehorses in 1936 following the death of his horse trainer father. Jim moved to Brisbane in 1941 before a stint in the Army during World War II, including service in Papua New Guinea. Then in 1942, Jim moved to Toowoomba, famously riding his two horses from Brisbane to the foot of the Toowoomba range. For 67 years, Jim produced thousands of winners from his Clifford Park base, dominating the Toowoomba premiership as well as winning four Brisbane trainers’ premierships and three Ipswich trainers’ premierships.

But Jim’s fame did not come solely from his success in Queensland. He was a regular visitor to interstate carnivals and won some of Australia’s greatest races, including the Doncaster with his champion Dalrello and Queensland’s first AJC Oaks winner Just Now. Jim was an inaugural inductee into the Queensland Racing Hall of Fame in 2003 and is fittingly expected to be inducted into the Australian Racing Hall of Fame next month. I wish to pass on my condolences and those of everyone here, I am sure, as well as those in the Queensland racing industry to his wife, Merna, and son, John.

One of the biggest funerals ever witnessed in Ipswich was held at St Mary’s Catholic Church last week when we lost Jeff McLean after a brave fight against cancer. Jeff was only 62 years of age. My colleague Rachel Nolan knew Jeff McLean very well. He was a 13-test Wallaby winger. Jeff came from the famous McLean rugby family and carved out his own slice of the family history playing for Brothers, Queensland and Australia before a broken leg prematurely ended his career in 1974.

With almost 40 years as a member, Jeff served as committeeman on the Ipswich Turf Club for more than two decades. I spoke to Jeff at the Ipswich Turf Club about three months ago. Although obviously ill, he was determined to fight to the very end, which he did. During that time, Jeff helped develop the club into the success story it is today, hosting Queensland’s best attended race meeting each year. Again, I pass on my condolences and I am sure, again, those of everyone here to Jeff’s wife, Carmel, son, David, and daughter, Bridget.

It would also be remiss of me not to note the retirement of the ‘voice of Queensland racing’, Wayne Wilson. Wayne is the nephew of the legendary trainer Jack Wilson, who trained Eye Liner amongst other good horses. He is also the son of well-known bookie Herbie Wilson. He began his race-calling career in Gladstone over 50 years ago. Wayne took over as the No. 1 race caller in Queensland following the retirement of Vince Curry in 1982 and since then his name has become synonymous with racing throughout Australia.

Alongside his achievements of calling champions, Wayne has been a successful owner, including winning the Macdougall Stakes with a horse called Do You Remember. I wish Wayne and his wife, Sally, all the best in their retirement.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (10.23 am): Children in care will be kicking goals and scoring runs just like their favourite sporting stars thanks to sports kits provided by the Bligh government. Along with the honourable members for Thuringowa and Mundingburra, I recently visited Townsville to hand over the first allocation of sports kits to care providers. The kits, valued at $500, are loaded up with sports gear, including footballs, soccer balls, basketballs, T-ball kits and other sporting equipment.

The kits are designed to give children in care greater opportunities to get involved in sport and recreation. Many of these children, who have been removed from their families due to abuse or neglect, do not have the same chances to get into sport as other children, whether it is a simple game of soccer in the park or an organised sport at club level. The kits give them a taste of a wide range of sports so they can hopefully make a transition into more structured sporting activities and continue an active lifestyle through to adulthood. Most importantly, these kits will put a smile on the faces of Queensland’s most vulnerable children, such as those we saw when we visited these homes.

The benefits of sport and recreation are well documented. Sport can break down barriers and teach kids important values and life skills including self-confidence, teamwork, communication, inclusion, discipline, respect and fair play. Everyone should have the opportunity to get involved in sport and recreation, and I want to make sure our children in care do not miss out.

These kits are in addition to the extra $1 million that the government allocated to foster and kinship carers earlier this year to help fund sport and recreation activities for children in their care. This one-off funding went towards an allowance of up to $300 per child for costs such as sporting club registration fees and swimming lessons. Through the sports kits and the extra funding for foster and kinship carers, the Bligh government is making sure kids in care get the same opportunities that every Queensland child deserves.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.25 am): Earlier this month I visited the University of the Sunshine Coast, where a new autism centre of excellence is being established. I was pleased to announce that the Bligh government will contribute $450,000 a year to the AEIOU Foundation to help run the centre. The centre will support at least 25 local children with autism--15 at the centre itself and 10 via outreach.

This investment is another sign of the Bligh government’s commitment to strengthening disability services in regional Queensland. We are working closely with the federal Labor government. I was joined by the federal minister, Jenny Macklin, when she committed $1.8 million in capital funding to establish the centre.

When the centre is up and running next year, it will deliver group based developmental and educational programs, speech and occupational therapy, and physiotherapy. The centre will also deliver outreach services to the Fraser Coast and Central Highlands regions. By the end of next year, I would like to see autism early intervention centres up and running in Queensland’s major coastal centres from Cairns to Coolangatta and providing outreach services to rural and remote Queensland.

Last month I announced a $1 million funding boost for disability services in the south-west of the state. This is great news for south-west communities and it means that community groups from Ipswich to Quilpie can apply for a share of $1 million in extra capital funding to upgrade facilities and equipment. This will help these organisations to deliver day and respite services for people with a disability.

Just last week I officially opened the new all-abilities playground in Mackay with the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. This new playground will give children with and without a disability a chance to play together side by side. The Queensland government contributed $283,000 to establish this playground, with the Mackay Regional Council contributing $120,000. This is one of 16 all-abilities playgrounds that we are delivering with regional councils under a $4.6 million program.
We will continue to invest in stronger disability services in the regions to ensure that more Queenslanders with a disability get the services that they need.

Mrs MILLER (Bundamba--ALP) (10.28 am): I table the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 9 of 2010 . In addition, I table a copy of the submission received from the Queensland Law Society regarding the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill 2010.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.31 am): My first question without notice is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Why has the Labor government refused to fund the $22,000 necessary for repairs to the Explosive Ordnance Response Team robot that is vital for the national counterterrorism strategy and why has this vital device been allowed to rust in a basement since April?
Mr ROBERTS: I am not aware of the particulars of the claim that the member is making.
A government member: I bet the police union is.

Mr ROBERTS: That is right. The bomb squad, as it is colloquially referred to, is a unit that the Queensland Police Service resources and takes very seriously. I have met with many of the members of this particular squad. They interact very successfully with their interstate counterparts. They have set up the plans and the operational requirements in order to respond to a whole range of terrorism incidents and bomb related incidents across Queensland. They have been provided with significant resources by this government.

I am not particularly familiar with the issue that the member is referring to in terms of this particular replacement. As I indicated last year, I did visit the bomb squad and spoke to the officers. I viewed a whole range of quite sophisticated equipment that they have to deal with this issue. Obviously, I will look into the detail of that.

On many occasions the opposition raises issues about law and order. In this chamber they regularly talk tough about law and order. On many occasions when they were in government I sat here and heard them talking tough about law and order. However, let us go through some of the record of the opposition in terms of law and order and the resourcing of the Police Service, which is what this issue is all about; it is about appropriately resourcing the Police Service. When the opposition was last in government, the police-to-population ratio was about one officer to every 500 people in Queensland. We funded the Police Service to reduce the police-to-population ratio to about one officer for every 430 people. Since Labor has been in government, the crime rate has reduced by over 20 per cent. Why has that occurred? Because of the additional and appropriate resourcing that this government has provided to the Police Service. One of the key issues raised in the Fitzgerald report was the inadequate resourcing of the Police Service by the National Party government. That is the record of the opposition in this place.

Mr LANGBROEK: My second question without notice is to the Premier. Under Labor, recent cost-of-living increases, as measured by the ABS consumer price index, included 22 per cent in household rent, 34 per cent in power charges, 23 per cent in gas charges and 32 per cent in water charges. We have had rises in paper rail ticket costs of 40 per cent and go card rises of 16 per cent. Because of the fuel tax, our fuel costs are up 17.5 per cent and rego is up 27 per cent. Premier, what hope can Queenslanders have that a federal Labor government will be any better than this state government?
Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. As we know, those opposite will take any opportunity they get to talk Queensland down. We know that the Queensland--
Opposition members: Shame!

Ms BLIGH: They do not want to hear it. We know that the Queensland economy, once again, is experiencing economic growth above the national average. What does that mean? It means that, as we recover from the global financial crisis, we are delivering jobs. We went to the election and said, ‘You can count on us to deliver jobs,’ and that is what we are doing. What else does economic growth mean? It means that people have more opportunity to earn a living, to get wage increases and to spend money in the economy.

The best thing that a government can do is work to ensure that the people they represent have real chances to get real jobs. What do we see from this government? We see a government focused completely on jobs. What has it delivered? It has delivered 12 consecutive months of real jobs growth. In the past four months Queensland has been the job-generating capital of Australia, creating more new jobs than any other state.

What do we get from those opposite? They complain about Queensland. They take every opportunity to talk down what is happening here. What does the rest of Australia think about that? By and large, the rest of Australia is voting with their feet. They want to be here because they understand what is happening. They understand that Queensland is an exciting place to be, it is the state of opportunity, it is the state of jobs growth, it is the place to bring up a family and it is the place to create a fulfilling life. Queenslanders are the envy of many Australians, so much so that they are voting with their feet and coming here. When they come they set up businesses, many of which create more jobs.
Mr Springborg: Our comparative rate of migration is falling away.

Ms BLIGH: Here we go again: they are talking down Queensland. Not for one minute can they back their own state. They aspire to lead it, but they cannot even speak well of it. Queensland is coming out of the global financial crisis and it is recovering because of our government’s policies.
Mr FINN: My question without notice is to the Premier. Can the Premier please provide the House with an update on the government’s economic plan to drive growth and create jobs for Queenslanders?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for Yeerongpilly. Last week, along with the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and the rest of the government, I was very pleased to see that once again Queensland has been generating jobs. In fact, for the fourth month in a row Queensland has been generating more jobs than any other state in Australia. That is not happening by accident. It is happening because our government has a range of economic settings that ensure that we have the skills in the economy for businesses to expand and we are working to create, develop and nurture new industries, especially green energy industries such as solar and new energy industries such as the gas industry. We have programs such as the Green Army, which are delivering. All of that is adding to our jobs target. We have had 12 months of jobs growth, and for the past four months we have led the nation and we are ahead of our job-creating target. However, we will not take a step back. We will not be complacent about it. People will see our government focused on jobs and on jobs policy.

Of course, we know that the opposition has no economic policy. We know that it has no jobs policy. Those who spend any time on the opposition website will know that its policy section is an empty zone. It is useful to look a little further on the LNP website, because if you enter the membership section it opens a Pandora’s box--a treasure chest--not of policy, though. What you will find there is more than 4,000 products for sale. It is the old LNP shop-a-thon. What sorts of products are for sale? There are no policies for sale. I encourage you to click on the word ‘tools’.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock.

Ms BLIGH: They do not want to hear this. I encourage members to go on to the site and click on the word ‘tools’. There they will see a whole page of tools they can buy. A personal favourite is the Hello Dolly diamante hammer. It is diamante hammer with a pink trim. What on earth is going on in the LNP? Their website is a sham. It is not a political party; this is a commercial outlet. There is more. There is the Breville ikon electric knife sharpener. But wait--there’s more! There are no policies but 4,000 shopping items, and every one of them at a Demtel discount.
Mr Wallace: Here’s the knife sharpener, Tim.
Mr NICHOLLS: You will find the knives on the Union Shopper website, I think.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: I will wait. Those on my right will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Clayfield.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Premier. There have now been five reports that show Queensland’s economy is faltering and bottom of the heap in Australia. Does the Premier agree with her national leader, Julia Gillard, that it is dud Labor governments that have been dragging down federal Labor’s vote?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question, proving again, as I pointed out earlier, that they will go sifting and trawling through any economic analysis to find the bad ones. That is what they think about Queensland.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. The House will come to order. The honourable the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. We have made no secret of the fact that Queensland was hit hard by the global financial crisis--a crisis those opposite believe did not exist, just like former Prime Minister John Howard said somehow it did not exist. You can find economists that will tell you a range of analyses and a range of theories, but there is one absolutely independent, rock solid indicator of an economy, and what is it? Jobs growth. When jobs are growing, the economy is growing. When the economy is growing, more and more people are benefiting from it. What we know is that in Queensland--and they do not want to hear it--we have had 12 months of consecutive lift in jobs and for four months in a row the best in Australia. I will champion Queensland in absolutely every forum that I can.
Mr Springborg interjected.
Mr Fraser: Have they got you on the campaign trail? Guaranteed election winner!
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock again. Both sides will come to order.
Mr Lucas: Get Lawrence out.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The Deputy Premier. The honourable the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. Tony Abbott has an absolute smorgasbord of possibilities over there, doesn’t he? I bet the phones are running hot asking for the member for Callide to be out there picking up a few votes in Ryan. I bet the Ryan candidate, Jane Prentice, has been on the phone saying, ‘Please, can I have the member for Gregory out here to help?’

But there is a document that might be a little helpful for some members, and you can find it on the Demtel website, courtesy of the LNP. It is called the Man Manual--100 Brilliant Ideas for being a Top Bloke . The product description states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Everyone has a friend of whom they are, if they are honest, a little bit jealous. You know the type; Women love him, other men like him, small children and animals like him, dammit. His love life is blissful, he looks impeccable ... He always knows the right thing to do ... Now every man can become this kind of guy, with the help of The Man Manual ...
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what the LNP is doing--selling this kind of junk on the internet.

Mr PITT: My question is to the Premier and Minister for the Arts. Can the Premier explain how important it is for Queensland as a state, particularly for regional Queensland, to have a high-speed national broadband network?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. As we have seen the federal campaign reach its final days, nothing could be more of a stark contrast between the choices facing Australians and Queenslanders on Saturday than the attitude of the two major parties to the national broadband network. On the one hand, you have Tony Abbott, who does not understand what it is. On the other hand, you have Julia Gillard and her team, who understand not only the power of a broadband network to bring high-speed capacity into businesses and homes but also how important it is to get it into regional and rural Queensland. You would think that those people who represent rural Queensland would be jumping up and down calling for a national broadband network.
Honourable members interjected.

But I tell you what you will find--
Honourable members interjected.

You will not find a solar energy policy, but you will find the solar powered ‘Silent Helper Illuminated House Number’, and you can get it cheap if you join the LNP.
There are 4,000 items--almost every single one of them rubbish, just like the policies of the LNP. They are, like every dieter knows, empty calories.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. Those on my left will cease interjecting. The honourable the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Not satisfied with selling policy junk to the Queensland electorate, they are now online selling 4,000 items of commercial junk. If you go online, Mr Speaker, you will find nothing but rubbish from the LNP. It tells you everything you need to know about a party that stands for nothing.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Minister for Primary Industries.
