Does the minister support this fishing ban on the Fraser Coast, the Tweed and the Gulf of Carpentaria that would destroy so many livelihoods?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. The Commonwealth’s bioregions program was initiated under the Howard government. The Howard government also introduced the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park in 2004. The bioregions program is a continuation of the Howard government’s policy.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. I will wait for the House to come to order. I call the minister.

Mr MULHERIN: It is a continuation of Howard government policy. In fact the Hon. Peter Garrett has put out a media release in relation to the bioregions because of the misinformation that is being peddled by members opposite.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting. I want to hear the honourable minister.

Mr MULHERIN:
The Commonwealth government has gone out and engaged in consultation around this issue of bioregions. It has extended the consultation period beyond the election. It has committed after those consultations to further consultation around the impacts. The role of my agency is to provide information to the Commonwealth in relation to both commercial and recreational fishing.

It is quite hypocritical for members opposite to go out and state--as opposition leader Abbott said at a media conference in Mackay--that they would halt the bioregions planning process. Mr Abbott gave the impression that under a federal coalition government there would be no continuation of this process. All that coalition leader Abbott indicated was that it would consult further with industry. This is no different to what the federal government is currently doing with industry. It is going out and consulting.

It is a bit hypocritical for members opposite to go out and state that if a coalition government is elected there will not be any further bioregions. It was a policy of the Howard government to have a network of bioregions around the Australian coastline.
Ms CROFT: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the Treasurer update the House on any recent consumer sentiment surveys?

Mr FRASER: I can, and I thank the member for Broadwater for her question. It is lucky that I can update the House because we will not hear it from the other side. The Westpac-Melbourne Institute for consumer sentiment survey came out on Friday. What did it say? The largest rise in any state in the nation was guess where? Queensland. There has been an 11-point rise in consumer sentiment in Queensland following a 13 per cent rise in the month before.

Did members see the press release from the LNP welcoming this result for Queensland? No, we would not hear about it. Did members see the press release it put out when we led the nation in jobs growth for the fourth month in a row last Thursday? No, we would not hear about that.

If we were a subscriber to the LNP website we would never hear about those things happening in the Queensland economy. Those opposite are too busy retailing the commercial junk to go out and retail the Queensland economy. They are too busy out there selling Jacques Bogart One Man Show Eau De Toilette Spray. It sounds like the favourite, the one-man show for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Or how about some Carolina Herrera Men’s Eau De Toilette for the bargain price of $72 for members? It sounds a bit like lady scented body wash to me.

The reality is that those opposite have no policies. They have no economic strategy. They have no jobs target. They have no clue about what to do. All they have is a front for a commercial enterprise that questions need to be asked about. Is this being supported by taxpayer resources in the opposition office? Who is this company that is out there retailing this? Who are the directors? Where is it based? Are taxpayer funds being used to support this exercise?

What we know is that, rather than producing policies, all those opposite are engaged in is a role-play in Are You Being Served? . You can just imagine the member for Maroochydore playing Mrs Slocombe--there with the Fifi and the Flowertots for about $16.26 for members. We can imagine at the next election that they will be out there doorknocking. Doorknocking in Ayr will be the member for Burdekin. She will be knocking on the door not with a policy but saying ‘Avon calling’. We know that the member for Caloundra would get right into it. He loves a pyramid selling scheme--new and exciting ways to rip off old ladies all over the state. Go for it!

What we know is that this state requires an opposition to put up some policies. We have the economic strategy. We have the plan. We are delivering jobs--12 straight months of jobs-generating growth. What have those opposite got? Not a policy. Not an economic strategy. Not a jobs target. They are just out there retailing lady scented body washes. That is a poor excuse for standing up and standing for something.

This government has the strategy and has the plan. We have delivered four straight months of leading the nation in jobs-generating growth--12 months of generating jobs. The facts speak for themselves. The policies speak for themselves. We will keep on driving jobs growth in this state.

Mrs STUCKEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland. I refer to Labor and the Greens’ desire to decimate commercial and recreational fishing by flagging over 13,000 square kilometres of area off the Fraser Coast and over 3,000 square kilometres off the southern Gold Coast as future marine protected areas. Has the minister at any time asked for or seen any modelling of the damage this would cause the Queensland fishing and tourism industries or is the minister turning a blind eye while his federal colleagues do another sneaky preference deal with the Greens?

Mr MULHERIN: I thank the honourable member for the question. I do not know about a sneaky preference deal. It is quite obvious that the Labor Party has reached an agreement with the Greens over a preference deal. That is no different to the Liberal National Party and its preference deals with the Fishing and Lifestyle Party, Family First or whatever. It is the normal political process for political parties to enter into those arrangements.

As I answered in response to a question from the member for Southern Downs, the bioregions policy is part of a policy that was established under the Howard government. Members opposite do not like the truth being told. This program was established to have a system of bioregions around the Australian coastline.

The federal government has gone out and consulted with industry. The federal government has given an extension of time so there can be further consultation with all stakeholders involved in the fishing industry.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. I will wait for the House to come order. I call the honourable minister.

Mr MULHERIN: The federal government will go out again and undertake a 90-day public consultation period around the issues that have been raised by the commercial sector, the recreational sector and the tourism sector.

The opposition leader, Tony Abbott, was quite hypocritical when he was in Mackay and stated that a coalition government would halt the process until it undertook further consultation with stakeholders. He has said that the coalition is committed to these bioregions but he will halt the process to undertake further consultation. This is no different to the federal government’s process that is currently underway where consultation is occurring with all stakeholders. The impression people got from Mr Abbott’s statements in Mackay was that there would be no more bioregions. This is an absolute lie that has been perpetrated by members opposite.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Withdraw the word--it is unparliamentary--and then we will get on with it.
Mr MULHERIN: Well, Mr Speaker--
Mr SPEAKER: No, do not argue; just withdraw it.

Mr MULHERIN: I withdraw, but this is a misinformation campaign that is being perpetrated by members opposite that there would be no more bioregions. All Mr Abbott said was that they would consult further. It is no different to what the federal government is doing in relation to bioregions.

Mr O’BRIEN: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the minister please inform the House how high-speed broadband is already transforming health care in Queensland and how Queensland Health’s telehealth program leads the way as a model for the Gillard government’s telemedicine initiative?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. Queensland has one of the best telehealth programs in the world. Our network of videoconferencing technology makes it one of the largest in Australia and the largest providing health care, with more than 50,000 telehealth connections each year. New South Wales comparatively undertook 17,000. To give the House some of the growth examples for one year alone, mental health, psychiatry and psychology outpatient consultations went from 500 to 902 and outpatient oncology consultations went from 225 to 425. Patients in Toowoomba and Mount Isa can videoconference with a highly trained specialist in one of the state’s premier tertiary hospitals. A little while ago I was in Toowoomba with an anaesthetist and theatre nurse talking to a mum and her son in Dalby for the preoperative consultation. It reduces patient travel time away from home--no-one likes to travel unnecessarily if they can avoid it--and it brings health care to regional Queensland.

In 2010 we invested $10 million for the telehealth expansion and in just 12 months we have increased the sites from 662 to 828. It is never possible to expect to have a specialist in every town in Queensland, as much as we would like to do that. We need to recognise that modern technology allows us to do something about that, and that is why yesterday the announcement from Julia Gillard in relation to using properly the $43 billion NBN money in relation to a network of telehealth consultations is revolutionary--absolutely revolutionary. People on the other side of the House who represent rural and regional areas should be on the phone to their conservative colleagues in Canberra saying, ‘Please match that Julia Gillard promise.’

There is a $392.3 million package including $250.5 million for 495,000 services over four years to rural and remote and outer metropolitan areas and including financial incentives for GPs and specialists to participate. One of the problems--and I said this to the rural doctors conference earlier this year and I have said it on many other occasions--is that you do not get paid from Medicare if you are the GP talking to the specialist with your patient in Toowoomba, Cloncurry or wherever. This will now allow that to happen.
Mr Horan interjected.

Mr LUCAS: For the member for Toowoomba South to pooh-pooh that just shows us what a troglodyte and dinosaur he is when it comes to modern health. Tony Abbott said that he was no tech-head when it came to the national broadband network, but Andrew Pesce, the AMA national president, said that this is a recognition of the need to embrace communications technology. Queensland president Gino Pecoraro said that it is recognition of us going into the 21st century. In fact, in 2005 the member for Warrego said that we needed sophisticated telehealth services such as teleradiology, ophthalmology, orthopaedic and pre and post admission consultations. That is what he said, and Labor is delivering it. Julia Gillard will deliver it. All those opposite are interested in, of course, is a website where the member for Condamine and the member for Mermaid--

Mr ELMES: My question is to the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability. I table photos of a freshly butchered female green turtle taken over the last couple of days just south of Wujul Wujul and I refer the minister to the $2.6 million Dugong and Turtle Protection Plan announced by the federal coalition last Friday, and I ask: will this government at last admit that there is a serious problem with the illegal take of these beautiful and iconic animals in Far North Queensland and match dollar for dollar the commitment made by the coalition and endorsed by Bob Irwin?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Bundle of photos of turtles [ 2748 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms JONES: I thank the honourable member for the question. It is always interesting when the LNP comes in here and starts crying crocodile tears over some species of animal that it pretends to care about.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. I will wait for the House to come to order.

Ms JONES: The honourable member knows full well--this is an issue we have debated many times in this House--that two things have happened during the federal election campaign, and while I was on maternity leave the Minister for Disability Services was acting in my position. She wrote to Peter Garrett following on from correspondence that I had previously written to the minister about setting up a task force to investigate the illegal killing of dugong and turtles in Far North Queensland. This action had already been taken. Furthermore, a task force has already been set up by the federal government to look at this issue and it has already appointed liaison officers who are working with the communities in those areas to reduce the illegal take. However, what I have consistently said to the honourable member, who has in here and in the media continued to make allegations of illegal take, is: show me the evidence. Not once has he ever provided me with anything. I am happy to have a look at those photos.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my right will cease interjecting.

Ms JONES: What I have consistently said both here to the honourable member, in writing and in the press is to show me the evidence of illegal take and we will investigate. What I am saying is that we will have a look at that, but those opposite know full well that there is also under the federal Native Title Act an ability for traditional owners to have some take.

What I am very curious about is that all of the science shows that the best way to protect turtles or dugong is to protect their habitat. What is the LNP record when it comes to protecting the habitat of turtles and dugong? It wants to wind back the green zone protection that we have put in place in Moreton Bay. Moreton Bay is the largest habitat of turtles in Queensland, and those opposite want to wind back that protection. What postcode does a turtle have to have before those opposite start caring about it? How far up the coast does a turtle have to go before the LNP starts giving two hoots about it? If those opposite want to protect turtles, they will support us in terms of the protection we have put in place in Moreton Bay. What we are seeing here once again from the LNP is base politics.
Mr Elmes interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Noosa, you have had a fair go. Allow the minister to finish answering the question.

Ms JONES: What we have seen from the LNP time and time again is that it is more interested in gimmicks and it is more interested in selling dud items on the internet than in delivering real policies. If the member shows me the evidence we will investigate. Those opposite should start supporting us in protecting their habitat.

Ms NELSON-CARR: I rise to ask the Minister for Public Works a question without notice, and I have to say that I am very pleased to see that he has returned today, having recovered from a very unfortunate experience with the wildlife in Rockhampton. Can the minister please outline how many Queensland cities and towns will get an optical fibre broadband connection under the Gillard government’s NBN plan?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I first of all want to dismiss rumours that it was the member for Currumbin hiding herself amongst the lemons in my backyard. This is a very important question, and I thank the honourable member for her question on a very serious matter. The fact is that our Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, is in the member’s electorate today and the Townsville area generally inspecting the good work the national broadband network is doing, something which will be privatised under Tony Abbott. So come the election result on Saturday, I want to know what is going to happen to the future of that. Are there going to be cables lying in the ground going nowhere--a bit like the Rockhampton Railway Station was in 1929 when the tories got in?

The reality is that all of those who shout the loudest across here are as quiet as mice when it comes to their own electorates missing out on the NBN. I table a list of places in Queensland that are going to be affected by Tony Abbott’s privatisation of the NBN.

XML.Hansard-Body: The reality is that we had a motion before the parliament just the other day, moved by the Independents. But guess who is mostly affected by this in a lot of ways? The member for Gladstone was very forthright in what she had to say. Tannum Sands is going to miss out, Gladstone is going to miss out and Calliope is going to miss out. I hope the honourable members who represent those electorates will be as vociferous as they were in this place last week against the state Labor government.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SCHWARTEN: Whilst they are all wanting to talk about it, I will give them a bit of a show, too. What about the member for Warrego, who previously was vociferous about the need for telemedicine--obviously powered by pedal wireless, divine intervention or some other means? Roma is going to miss out. Does he care about that? Of course, he does not care less about it. I have not heard him say a word about it. What about the people in Mirani? No, they will miss out, too. He just nods his head sagely--or stupidly, whichever way you want to take it. What about in Hinchinbrook, which is represented by our friend over there? Ingham is going to miss out. Is he going to say anything about that? No. He is mute and absurd as usual. What about in Callide, represented by our loudmouthed friend over there from Biloela, which gets its name from the white cockatoo? He is going to be a very quiet white cockatoo about this. Biloela--gone. Monto--gone. Boyne Island--gone.

What about our friends who represent the Sunshine Coast? The other day the member for Maroochydore had a lot to say about the Queensland government not spending enough on the Sunshine Coast. What is going to happen with broadband down there? Gone, gone, gone. So do not worry about telemedicine, do not worry about the education infrastructure, do not worry about the--
Mr HOPPER: Mr Speaker--
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my right will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Condamine.
Mr Fraser: Have you bought the ‘Hopper’ toy yet?
Mr SPEAKER: Order, the honourable the Treasurer! I had asked that the House come to order.

Mr HOPPER:
My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries. Given the worldwide shortage of cereal grains, particularly wheat, will the minister finally accept the madness in selling off the Leslie Research Station? When will the minister start supporting our respected DPI cereal scientists in developing real productivity for Queensland farmers?

Mr MULHERIN:
I thank the honourable member for the question. During the last election campaign we went to the people with our Fresh Approach policy, which was about modernising our research and development. The member opposite is caught in a time warp. His view of the world is a view of the 1950s. We have gone about engaging with the industry sector around how we go about modernising. We are yet to determine a final outcome, but one thing for sure is that we will continue to engage with industry. We will be reinvesting back into the cereal industry through our disinvest to reinvest strategy. I see that that is no different from the draft Liberal National Party policy statement around assets that are either surplus or redundant--or not so redundant. They will look at those issues.

In relation to grains research, the government is committed to funding grains research under a national RD&E framework. That was agreed at a national level through the ministerial council. I note that the state minister for agriculture in Western Australia, Terry Redman, supports this approach to grains research. We will continue to invest in that area.

I want to draw the member’s attention to the fact that the Queensland government has invested pretty close to about $600 million in modernising our research facilities. Last week, I was out at Coopers Plains with the Premier and Senator Ludwig where, through cooperation with the federal government, we opened the new food and health precinct, which will certainly add value to agricultural production in Queensland. This will build on the work that we will do around food policy.

The member for Condamine is caught in the past. He does not want to modernise. He does not want to invest in new facilities. We are certainly investing in the area of science. If he would like, the member could have a briefing on the Queensland agricultural food and fibre alliance that we have established with the University of Queensland. We have invested several million dollars in establishing that institute over the next few years. It will certainly bring a lot of benefits to primary production through--

Mrs KIERNAN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. As the minister is aware, I have a very keen interest in renewable energy. Would the minister update the House on the progress of the Bligh government’s Solar Hot Water Rebate Scheme?

Mr ROBERTSON: I thank the member for Mount Isa for the question and indeed recognise her very strong commitment to a clean energy future for her part of Queensland. Queenslanders are embracing solar energy and taking advantage of programs such as our new Solar Hot Water Rebate Scheme. I am pleased to report that, since 1 July this year, we have paid more than 2,397 rebates to eligible applicants. That is 2,397 applicants in just over six weeks. That is $1.65 million going to Queenslanders who are wanting to do the bright thing. When combined with the federal Labor government’s incentives, solar hot water has never been more affordable than it is now.

The Bligh government is committed to tackling the challenges of climate change and it is also committed to tackling cost of living increases. That is why, through rebates such as our solar hot water rebate, more and more Queenslanders can not only benefit from the use of clean energy in terms of their solar hot-water systems but also reduce their electricity bills by up to 30 per cent simply by converting to solar hot water.

This Bligh government also has a vision for a solar future for Queensland. That is why we are investing some $115 million over five years on a range of solar initiatives to double our solar energy production. These initiatives include some $35.4 million on CS’s carbon reduction program and nearly $30 million towards our $60 million Solar Hot Water Rebate Scheme and $5.8 million for the Solar Kindergartens Program. These are just three initiatives in our record funding that we have allocated in this budget and forward estimates for solar technologies in Queensland.

This is the single largest funding commitment to solar in our history. Why? Because we know that investment is needed in research and development on alternative energy options for Queensland, otherwise the realities of climate change will become all too real for future generations. During the initial stages of development it is not economically viable for private enterprise to invest in these emerging industries. So it is necessary for government to play a role and to fill the void created by a lack of return in the initial stages of technology development. That is why in north-west Queensland we have invested some $900,000 in the Cloncurry solar thermal trial to investigate an innovative way to store energy. Being new technology, there are of course associated risks. The initial advice tells us that, whilst it may not be economically viable technology, there are important answers in terms of how you store that energy using graphite. That is of particular interest in this particular trial and represents a good investment of taxpayers’ dollars.

Mr CRANDON: My question is to the Minister for Natural Resources, Mines and Energy and Minister for Trade. I table departmental correspondence relating to a proposed quarry at Ormeau Hills which clearly shows that the deadline for a report was extended beyond the federal election date. Can the minister reveal if the member for Forde contacted his office or the department to request the extension of time to save his political hide, given the strongly held views of the local community?
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Letter, dated 6 August 2010, from the Manager, Planning and Assessment Beenleigh, South East Region, Department of Environment and Resource Management to the Chief Executive Officer, Gold Coast City Council, regarding the extension of the referral agency assessment period over property in Ormeau Hills and a letter, dated 4 August 2010, from the Senior Planning Officer, Beenleigh South East Region, Department of Environment and Resource Management, to CSM Conveyancing regarding a development application at Ormeau Hills and the Gold Coast City Council [ 2750 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr ROBERTSON: It is not readily apparent to me from the documents that I have just very briefly scanned, but I can inform the member that the member for Forde has not spoken to me or contacted me about this issue. I am happy to investigate the matter further. As we know, from time to time development applications for quarries do cause community unrest and concern. That is why we have in place an exhaustive system, developed over the past 10 years, of identifying key resource areas and providing appropriate buffers around those areas for the purposes of quarrying in acknowledgement that there are impacts if quarries are developed too close to where existing residents are.

The simple fact is that if we do not have quarries in close proximity to where development is occurring then the cost of those developments will increase significantly. The cost of infrastructure and the cost of building roads and bridges will increase significantly as a result of having to truck these materials long distances. That is why across South-East Queensland we have taken the responsible position of identifying where those key resource areas are and not allowing future development to impose themselves in close proximity to those areas. If we do not have those areas with access to South-East Queensland identified then the only place for these resources to come from will be west of the Great Dividing Range. Imagine the costs that that will impose on our hospital building program, our road building program, our schools building program--
Ms Bligh: On people’s first homes.

Mr ROBERTSON: --on, as the Premier said, ordinary Queenslanders’ first and subsequent houses. There is no greater threat to cost of living increases than not securing the necessary key resource areas to allow those resources to be extracted for the purposes of infrastructure and building projects. Whilst I understand that the honourable member has a responsibility to represent his electorate, I would hope that he will not be so short-sighted in terms of the need for us to be able to develop those quarries for the purpose of our infrastructure and building needs and that he supports us in terms of what we have done over the last decade in protecting those key resource areas for the benefit of all South-East Queenslanders.

Mr HOOLIHAN:
I also welcome the teachers and students from Taranganba State School in my electorate into the gallery. My question without notice is to the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability. Could the minister inform the House of any recent announcements outlining how we can work with farmers and landholders to combat climate change?
Ms JONES: I thank the honourable member for the question. He is actually a member of parliament who does believe in climate change and the real effect that this is having on Queensland farmers.
Mr Wilson interjected.

Ms JONES: Our farmers do believe in it, I take that interjection from the honourable member. The Bligh government has taken real action with real dollars when it comes to supporting our farmers and our landholders in combating the effects of climate change. In August last year members would be aware that we announced our climate change policy, ClimateQ, which included new programs and extensions to existing programs to help farmers deal with climate change, in particular in reducing their energy and water costs and making sure that they have access to funds for water efficiency. We also led the way in research in this area with a CSIRO report that we released here in parliament. That was a study that found great potential to lock carbon up in our rural landscapes. The Premier and I have lobbied the federal government to enable new programs to help farmers derive an income from locking up carbon in their landscapes. I am very pleased to inform the House that on the weekend the Prime Minister released her new policy, the Carbon Farming Initiative. This is something that we have lobbied hard for. We think that there is new incomes for our farmers in these green programs.

This is in stark contrast to the LNP and its leader Tony Abbott who does not believe in climate change at all. Mr Abbott has been struggling to the finish line--the election date come this Saturday--trying to stay on script. He has tried really hard to stay on script. He promised the LNP hierarchy, ‘I will not put the budgie smugglers on for the next five weeks. I will stay fully clothed’; he promised the LNP hierarchy, ‘I will not spruik the benefits of Work Choices. I will not talk about that for the next five weeks, I promise’. Tony Abbott also promised the LNP hierarchy, ‘I will not deny that climate change is real’, but whoops, he slipped up. We all saw him on Q&A and Four Corners last night advocating that climate change is not real and, indeed, that the climate is actually cooling. This is in stark contrast to what we have heard ordinary Queenslanders and farmers say. They want real action when it comes to climate change. In actual fact, Tony Abbott has been trying so hard to pretend that he believes in climate change that he has had to steal a few of the policies of the state Labor government to look like he does. For example, he announced a couple of million dollars for a reef package. The LNP leader said that he thinks that it is a good idea to reduce pesticide run-off into the reef. What did the LNP members say when we debated that and they voted against it in this House? Those opposite said that it was not real, it did not have an effect on farming and there was no such thing as climate change. Tony Abbott is trying to get there but we all know what he thinks about climate change--it starts with C and ends in P.

Mrs PRATT: My question is to the Minister for Health. Kingaroy Base Hospital has a staff allocation of five doctors. However, in real terms the five doctors are effectively cut to three with doctors taking leave for holidays, sickness et cetera. Since Kingaroy Base Hospital was transferred from the Ipswich Health District to the Toowoomba Health District, doctor staff hours have been reduced which has resulted in reduced after hours accident and emergency. Will the minister review why a reduction in doctor hours at Kingaroy accident and emergency has occurred since the change in health districts with a view to having those doctor hours reinstated in an ever-increasing busy hospital?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. I am more than happy to seek information from my department with respect to that. A couple of issues that the member has raised are worthy of comment. The current federal government has indicated that it wishes to make progress towards local health networks. At the present time we have 17 health districts in Queensland. There is certainly some argument for examination as to the size of a couple of them. One of them is in relation to the Sunshine Coast, which takes in not only the Sunshine Coast area but also Wide Bay Burnett. There is a very strong argument for separating those into two separate districts. They would then be local health networks. Similarly, there is a strong argument for looking at Ipswich and Toowoomba. I think we can look at how we might align a number of those hospitals in the member’s area as well. In the appropriate time after the election, if the current government wins, we will talk to the community about what they see is the appropriate alignment for those districts. I think it is important for us to look at that.

One of the big issues that we are faced with in this election is a very clear choice when it comes to the provision of health services. My budget in Health this year is $9.99 billion and it is growing significantly. That is the nature of health demand. We have the second longest life expectancy on earth in this country. We have an ever-ageing population with ever-increasing standards of health treatment required. Prior to 1980 if a person required dialysis and was over the age of 65 they did not get it. Now if you are over the age of 75 you get it at the rate of 10 times the rate of people under 45 and it costs $60,000 a throw per year.

Health demands are changing. One of the real problems that we have is a shortage of doctors in rural and remote locations. One of the aspects of that is training more doctors. I cannot underestimate the importance of Julia Gillard’s announcement yesterday with respect to allowing GPs and specialists specific item consultations under the MBS system of medical consultations. It means that people in the member’s area where there may not be a particular specialist will not have to travel to a larger centre. That is fundamental. That is what modern broadband is about. That does not actually replace the importance of having more doctors in a hospital; I do want to make that point very strongly. Secondly, it is about training more doctors. We know that Tony Abbott froze the number of doctor training places. Peter Beattie--and he ought to be given great credit for this--increased the number of medical school places in our universities. We have gone from 250 in 2005 to 556 this year to 644 next year. They will then flow through. I think it is morally wrong to be pulling doctors out of Third World countries when we should be training our own with local kids.

That is what we are doing and that is what we have ahead of us: more rural scholarships and more kids who want to be there. We will rotate more and more registrars and other positions throughout regional rural hospitals so they can see the secrets and the great enjoyment of living in wonderful communities like Kingaroy. Thank you for your question.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Speaker’s Ruling, Notice of Motion Ruled Out of Order
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Order! Before I call the next question, I want to rule on a notice of motion that impacts, I think, on the separation of powers. The honourable member for Burnett has today given notice of a motion that is, in the chair’s view, unorthodox because it deals with matters that are usually in the province of those who administer criminal justice. It clearly raises issues regarding the notion of separation of powers. I have considered whether a motion in such terms and on such a subject is permissible or out of order.

As I have previously ruled--and you can have a look at my ruling of 24 February 2010--a notice of motion is merely an incomplete motion; it is a proposal. It is for the House to determine whether it will agree to the proposition. As long as the motion, if agreed to, would not offend the law and standing orders and the notice is internally logical, coherent, contains only facts necessary and is able to be authenticated, it should not be interfered with, the matter being left to the House. As I have previously ruled--and, again, see my ruling of 19 August 2009--my role is to simply determine whether a motion is out of order in accordance with standing orders or the operation of the law. It is not my role to usurp the role of the House as to the merits of a motion.

However, the notice of motion as currently drafted is calling on the Attorney-General, not the House, to acknowledge an opinion that the Attorney-General may not genuinely hold. It therefore lacks internal logic. Furthermore, the notice of motion contains facts that need to be authenticated. I am therefore ruling the notice of motion as it is currently drafted out of order. However, I invite the honourable member to redraft the notice of motion and provide authentication for me to consider further.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The time for questions has ended.

Mr LANGBROEK (Surfers Paradise--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.32 am): I rise today after yet another two hours of splendid democracy Queensland Labor stye: an hour of backslapping, self-praise and breathtaking boasting followed by question time, which has been reduced to an hour of abysmal street theatre punctuated with belittling asides, guffaws and disparagement. We saw it again this morning from the Premier, who was having a go at an LNP website and asking whether it is a taxpayer funded website. I can assure honourable members that it is not a taxpayer funded website, unlike the websites of the Labor members opposite. This is a typical membership rewards situation, not dissimilar to a union rewards website through which you can buy products.

What you will not find for sale on our website is Queensland Rail. If you want to buy Queensland Rail, you have to go to the Bligh-Gillard Labor website. That is where you will find Queensland Rail for sale. What you will not find for sale on our website is Queensland Motorways. If you want to buy a highway or a road, you have to go to the Bligh-Gillard Labor website. That is where you will be able to buy Queensland Motorways. What you will not find on our website is Queensland Forestry Plantations. If you want to buy the right to knock down some trees and get some freehold land when the government said all it was selling was trees, you have to go to the Bligh-Gillard Labor website. That is where you can buy Queensland’s forests. However, you will not find the paperwork in relation to the sales because they have not released that, either. What you will not find for sale on our website is a port. If you want to buy an entire shipping port and corporation, you have to go to the Bligh-Gillard Labor website. That is where you can buy yourself your very own port.

But hang on. If you went to the Bligh-Gillard website before the state election, you would not have seen that all these items were up for sale. They waited until after the election and then they put up the new special ‘Labor shop’, the Labor shop where Bligh and Gillard kept their sales secret until it was too late, the special Bligh and Gillard shop where Labor will not even let the public know what the sale conditions are and they will not even let the public know what has happened to the proceeds of the sale. Let us talk about what each party is selling. I have consistently invited the Premier to a public debate in a public forum so that we can discuss with real people Premier Anna Bligh’s and Gillard’s plan to sell off our assets under Labor.

This morning we have seen the parliament reduced to an absolute sham. I apologise to those children who are in the gallery right now whom you have welcomed, Mr Speaker, for having to see the disgraceful contributions from the Premier, the Treasurer and the Deputy Premier. Not 10 minutes into question time they saw that this Labor government no longer believes that it needs to be accountable to this parliament. There seems to be some belief that parliamentary democracy is just an excuse to malign and criticise the opposition or anyone else who dares to express a view contrary to that deigned to be acceptable by the Queensland ALP. I apologise to those children here today who have seen this government’s version of democracy. Government members come in here day after parliamentary day and they hoot and fall about, laughing at their own supreme wit and wisdom.

I have news for those ALP members who so rejoice in their parliamentary hysterics: Queenslanders are not laughing with them. In fact, they are not even laughing at them. Queenslanders have seen enough of their antics and clowning around and they know that democracy is not supposed to be that way. These children will return to their classrooms tomorrow and hopefully they will not say to their parents tonight, ‘I saw the Treasurer, the member for Mount Coot-tha, who looks like he is not much older than us, and he was screaming and yelling and telling jokes about the parliamentary process, and the Premier and the Deputy Premier were no better.’

The Queenslanders whom I talk to are disappointed that a Premier, Treasurer, Deputy Premier or minister of the Crown would stoop to such unbecoming behaviour. As I have already said, every day during question time there are schoolchildren in the gallery. The Speaker acknowledges them, but the ALP members in this place pay them little respect. How can they justify their behaviour to the children who sit upstairs to witness our democracy in action? I am routinely dismayed by the display that they witness. Do those children leave this place with a sense of the importance of our democratic institutions, or do they go home and ask their parents at the dinner table why elected grown-ups behave like children?

Over the weekend I had the opportunity to read the submissions of the Clerk and the Speaker with regard to the review of the committee system. Both are well researched and thought out documents that acknowledge that the current system of parliament is dominated by the government. Ministerial statements were once reserved for issues of state importance. We all know that they are now a clearing house for unreported press releases that are wasting the parliament’s time. This morning’s contribution from the minister for tourism was an adjournment speech, not a ministerial statement. The Clerk’s submission points out that there has been exponential growth in the use of ministerial statements to the detriment of non-ministerial members.

In 1994 ministerial statements averaged 1.9 per sitting day. In 2010 the government is bombarding us with nearly 18 per day. The Clerk’s submission makes clear that the 70 other members of the parliament, excluding the Speaker, are allocated just an average of three minutes per week to address matters of their choosing. The statistics included in the submission of the Speaker make it clear that six times as much time is taken by ministerial statements as compared with private members’ statements. It is difficult to avoid the conclusion, from reading the submissions of the Clerk and the Speaker, that Queensland Labor has systematically squeezed the life out of parliamentary democracy over the past decade through amendments to parliamentary procedure and practice.

The sessional orders have been amended to increase the opportunity for self-praise and decrease the opportunity for scrutiny. Question time has become answerless and, as we have seen, it has become theatre. This long-term Labor government has become so focused at holding on to power that it has trampled over the very organ that delivers it, because the traditional parliamentary democracy also delivers accountability, and it is accountability that this government is most afraid of.

No doubt tomorrow and for every sitting day until the next state election we, the people of Queensland, will again suffer through the smug, goading, self-praise and mockery that has become the norm in this place. However, ALP members should keep this in mind: while they are laughing away in here, the public is not laughing with them. They are not laughing at them. They are waiting with baseball bats at the ready because of the statistics that I highlighted in my question this morning to the Premier that, once again, she refused to answer. That question included the following statistics: ABS CPI index increases of 22 per cent in household rent, 34 per cent in power charges, 23 per cent in gas and 32 per cent in water charges. There have been rises in paper rail ticket costs of 40 per cent and go card rises of 16 per cent. Fuel costs are up 17.5 per cent and rego is up 27 per cent.
What do we get from the Treasurer? I table a transcript of a speech that he gave following his recent trip to China titled ‘Innovation in the public sector in China’.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Document by the Hon. Andrew Fraser MP, titled ‘Appendix B--Innovation in the Public Sector’ [ 2751 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: It is 32 pages long and it is indecipherable. This person has no connection with the real world and the people of Queensland, who are having to put--
Mr Fraser: I already tabled it last week. I’m glad you read it.

Mr LANGBROEK: It is for the benefit of members, who will be able to see how mind-numbingly out of touch this Treasurer is, because it is 32 pages of drivel. He begins by sucking up to his alma mater and the people in the audience but then, for 32 pages, says absolutely nothing.

Our economy is suffering a case of long-term ‘Laboritis’. This morning the honourable shadow Treasurer referred to five reports by the major banks Westpac, CommSec, NAB, CCIQ and Access. When the Access Economics report was released the Treasurer released a press release that stated that the economy was on the right track. This Treasurer cannot lie straight in bed, because his phrase ‘Queensland is headed in the right direction’ does not appear in the Access Economics report. He should be sanctioned, but instead he is lampooned by his own ridiculous spin. All five reports slam the economic ineptitude of the Bligh Labor government and, of course, business conditions are very weak and poor.

Today the Treasurer wanted to come into this place and spruik the unemployment statistics, but we now have 136,000 unemployed, up from 114,000. This is what he considers to be the clever use of statistics, which again shows how out of touch he is with people on the ground throughout the state, because we have more people unemployed than we did last year.

Only this Treasurer could come in here and somehow proclaim that this state is leading the nation when we know that interstate migration is declining, because this is not the place it was. We know that it can be better. We know that the Treasurer is completely out of touch and the Premier is out of touch. We know that they went broke in a boom. Their performance is terrible and their negligent handling of Queenslanders’ livelihoods is criminal.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (11.41 am): Logan residents see real action every day when it comes to road funding, with $420 million of congestion-busting roadworks underway at the Springwood-Daisy Hills section of the Pacific Motorway upgrade, particularly around the Loganlea Road interchange. However, this project is just one part of more than $900 million being spent on the Pacific Motorway in Logan and on the Gold Coast. Those projects simply would not be possible without the partnership of the Queensland Labor government and an Australian Labor government. This can be seen so clearly when we look at what happened under 12 years of the Howard government.

For 12 years, when Tony Abbott was a member of the federal government, the Australian government did not provide one cent of funding for works on the Pacific Motorway. For 12 years, the Tony Abbott and John Howard government did absolutely nothing for motorists on the Pacific Motorway. They ducked and weaved, telling Queenslanders that they did not have any responsibility for a National Highway, even when the Queensland government offered to equally share costs.

Let us compare this to the proud record of the Australian Labor government. Prior to the 2007 election, with Julia Gillard in the cabinet Labor committed to funding the Pacific Motorway upgrade and to working with the Queensland government, not against it. Only two years after being elected, our local federal member of parliament, Brett Raguse, was there to turn the first sod on the Pacific Motorway upgrade at the Springwood-Daisy Hill section. The evidence of real action is there for everyone to see. Every day excavators, cranes and pile-drivers are working to deliver results for motorists on the Pacific Motorway.

The greatest hypocrisy is that so much of this phony inaction comes from LNP members of this House who shamelessly criticise this government and the Australian government for the infrastructure program on the Pacific Motorway. They toadied to a federal Liberal government that neglected and ignored the Pacific Motorway and treated the people they represent with contempt. They ignored Logan and took the Gold Coast for granted, but as soon as John Howard and Tony Abbott were voted out of government they started a partisan campaign against the federal government. If we look at the LNP’s history on the issue of funding for the Pacific Motorway we see their whining and carping as nothing more than hollow rhetoric.

Regardless of the politics of the Australian government, I have called and will continue to call on the Australian government to commit to funding for the Pacific Motorway. Along with fellow Logan members of parliament, I lobbied the Howard government and the Labor opposition to commit to funding those important projects. It was so important that the 2007 election saw a commitment that the Labor government could deliver on within weeks of coming to office. I will continue to lobby for the Labor government to continue its funding commitment for the Pacific Motorway. I am eternally grateful that federal Labor could come to the party on the Pacific Motorway upgrade. It will make a real difference for Logan motorists, but there is still more to do.

The Gillard government is a government that wants to build Australia. It is a government committed to infrastructure for our outer suburbs, whether to the broadband network or to our roads and public transport. Tony Abbott’s only commitment to the outer suburbs is to cut the services that our families rely on. But LNP hypocrisy knows no bounds when we see LNP members of this place standing beside a campaign for federal funding for the Gold Coast rail line. Tony Abbott proudly announced to his own electorate that public transport infrastructure was never a federal government responsibility--that is until he was forced to override his own LNP candidate in Petrie, Dean Teasdale, to match Labor’s commitment to the Petrie to Kippa-Ring rail line. It is not just that Tony Abbott will not fund public transport infrastructure; he hates it. In 2009, when riding on public transport, Tony Abbott said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There just aren’t enough people wanting to go from a particular place to a particular destination at a particular time to justify any vehicle larger than a car and cars need roads.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have a message for Mr Abbott: if he comes to the outer suburbs I will tell him how important train and bus services are and what they mean for people trying to make ends meet and get a job. Even yesterday he stood by his opposition to public transport infrastructure. When it comes to supporting the Gold Coast rail line, the LNP will not stand up for it; they will only stand against government investment in public transport. Every time they whine and carp, I intend to remind LNP members of the LNP’s history of neglect and opposition to public transport for the outer suburbs. At least the member for Lockyer was honest in his views when he described public transport as ‘middle class welfare’.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (11.46 am): On Friday, 18 June, transport minister Rachel Nolan and I joined hundreds of workers in a celebration to mark the first tunnel breakthrough in the construction of Airport Link, Australia’s longest road tunnel. The breakthrough occurred in the northbound Airport Link tunnel, 629 metres from the project’s Truro Street tunnel portal and 833 metres from the Bowen Hills end. The 135-tonne road header, travelling south from Windsor, cut through the tunnel face 22 metres below the surface of Lutwyche Road.

The chair of BrisConnections, Trevor Rowe, and the CEO, Dr Ray Wilson, joined the minister and me in congratulating the 200-plus workers from the Thiess John Holland Truro Street and Bowen Hills tunnelling teams who were on-site to celebrate. The tunnelling teams have been working around the clock in Bowen Hills, Windsor, Kedron and Wooloowin to construct the two main 5.1-kilometre Airport Link tunnels. This important feat represents a significant milestone in Airport Link’s construction program since 24-hour tunnelling operations commenced in May 2009.

It was a great experience to be there and to see the tunnel machines breaking through the wall. It was an experience I had not encountered previously. It was great to have some members of the public there, particularly Mrs Beres McCallum of the Windsor and Districts Historical Society. BrisConnections presented her with a mounted plaque of Brisbane Tuff and other rocks that have been excavated. I know that that plaque now adorns a wall in the Windsor and Districts Historical Society’s building.

As we know, tunnelling is a very difficult and dangerous job, and there are a total of 15 kilometres of tunnel on this project. The Truro Street road header that broke through to the Bowen Hills tunnel is one of 11 machines excavating the 1.5-kilometre distance of tunnel between Truro Street, Windsor and Federation Street, Bowen Hills. It is a dangerous job, and occupational health and safety is very important in that environment. The tunnel crews have worked largely unseen to achieve this breakthrough, and their hard work will leave an important legacy for the people of Brisbane. It was great to welcome them after the breakthrough, as they came through the newly created hole from one side to the other.

By mid-2012, Airport Link, in conjunction with the airport roundabout upgrade, will remove up to 18 sets of traffic lights for motorists travelling from the city to Brisbane Airport and Australia TradeCoast, reducing travel time by up to a massive 50 per cent. Our record $17.1 billion capital building program means that projects like this are delivering jobs--currently more than 2,700 and this is expected to grow to well over 3,000 in the months ahead.

Airport Link has been undertaken, together with the Northern Busway, Windsor to Kedron, requiring 15 kilometres of tunnelling in total, encompassing road and busway tunnels and connecting ramps. A total of 17 roadheader machines are now carving out the Airport Link and Northern Busway tunnels--the largest number of roadheaders to be used on an Australian project. What a milestone! The tunnelling machines, weighing up to 135 tonnes, are making great progress, with more than four kilometres of tunnel completed to date.

I also acknowledge the residents living around this massive project. I want to personally thank them for their patience. We know that there is much disruption. I will continue to work with them to minimise the level of impact of this construction site. I understand their issues and problems. I thank the minister and his office, and CNI, in all working together to achieve better outcomes for the residents in the area. I must stress that their patience and goodwill in regard to this massive project--probably the biggest that Brisbane has ever seen--is something that I welcome. I will guarantee that I will continue working with them to ensure that the disruption is minimal.

Here are some important facts: more than six million hours worked; one million plants, including 5,300 mature trees to be planted during the project; 10,000 direct and indirect jobs generated; 40 per cent traffic reduction expected on Lutwyche Road in 2012; in 2016, the busway will cater for 47,000 public transport trips per day--more than five times the current number; in 2026, there will be a bus every 20 seconds. This is a great project for Brisbane. We know it has been disruptive for the residents, and I thank them.

Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP) (11.52 am): The residents of the Sunshine Coast are the latest people in South-East Queensland to realise the enormity of the failure of the Beattie Labor government to manage essential services like electricity and water. The residents of the Sunshine Coast are the latest people in South-East Queensland to realise the extent to which they are going to have to pay extra every time they get a water bill because of the incompetence of the Beattie Labor government. Just like electricity prices, water prices have gone through the roof. The higher water prices and the higher electricity prices are presenting an intolerable burden on the cost of living for people right across South-East Queensland. But when they get their water bill and when they get their electricity bill every one of those people need to remember always that the increases in those bills for essential services are the fault of the Beattie-Bligh Labor government. They are the result of years of failure to properly manage this infrastructure.

Every resident across South-East Queensland should collect their water bills and their power bills and stick them on the fridge every month between now and the end of next year so that when they go to the next state election they can remind themselves why they should vote this state Labor government into the political oblivion that it deserves. Take your water bills and your power bills with you to the polling booth next Saturday to remind yourselves why you should never vote for a Labor government and why you should vote for a government that can manage infrastructure properly and why you should vote for a government that can manage money properly--
Ms Grace interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! The member for Brisbane Central will return to her seat.

Mr SEENEY: --because the extra money that those people will pay on their bills will be paid by generations of Queenslanders as they seek to pay off the huge debt that this state Labor government incurred because it could not manage water infrastructure properly.

Let us look at the real facts about water infrastructure. The government consistently released water from Wivenhoe Dam throughout 1999, 2001 and 2002. Then by 2004 we had a water crisis. There was no water infrastructure built in South-East Queensland from the day the Goss government cancelled Wolffdene Dam. They built nothing. They allowed the population to build up to an extent that we had the water crisis in 2006. In 2006 we had an emergency regulation introduced which saw some projects built that rate well with the BER for being a complete waste of money.

The centrepiece, if you like, of the so-called water grid was the Western Corridor Recycled Water Project. This government spent $2.5 billion of Queensland taxpayers’ money on the Western Corridor Recycled Water Project--$2,500 million. Today it stands idle, except for the production of about 30 megalitres--30 swimming pools of water--that the government forces the government owned corporations, the electricity generators, to take. They only take it under ministerial direction. But that is all that that $2.5 billion produces. The interest on that $2.5 billion is paid by every person in South-East Queensland when they get their water bill.

Let us look at the Gold Coast desalination project. The government spent $1.1 billion of Queensland taxpayers’ money on that--$1,122 million--and it has been a lemon from the day it was first commissioned. It is still creating problems and it is still not producing anywhere near the capacity that it was designed for.

I think the people of the Sunshine Coast would want to know that the doozey of them all is the northern pipeline interconnector and the Ewen Maddock water treatment plant. It was part of the Water Regulation 2002. It has cost $800 million. The northern pipeline interconnector was meant to transport water from Traveston Dam south to Brisbane--$800 million. Traveston Dam is gone, as it should be, but the government has spent the $800 million.

The government wasted something like $500 million on the Traveston Dam itself--much of which it will not get back. It continues to waste hundreds of millions of dollars on water infrastructure that is badly planned and badly delivered. That is why the people of South-East Queensland will pay high water bills for generations to come. The people of the Sunshine Coast, the people of Brisbane and the people of the Gold Coast should direct the blame at the Beattie-Bligh Labor government. Take your water bills to the polling booth next Saturday.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The member’s time has expired.
Mr SEENEY: Take your electricity bills to the polling booth next Saturday--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! The member will take his seat.
Mr SEENEY: --and never vote Labor again!

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order!
Member for Callide, I believe that was a direct reflection on the chair. I call the member for Barron River.

Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (11.57 am): Last week the results of a Queensland first survey conducted by Tourism Queensland revealed some very interesting insights into what Queenslanders think about the social impacts of tourism in their communities. It was heartening to find that the majority of Queensland residents, including those from Tropical North Queensland, agree that tourism has a positive impact in their regions.

The intention of the ‘Your Community’ social indicators survey results is to guide state and local authorities in their decision-making processes on tourism development. Tourism development that is in line with the wants and needs of the local community not only provides a more authentic tourist experience for visitors but attracts stronger support for the industry, which is a win-win for everyone.

Furthermore, the survey has revealed that overall Queenslanders look favourably on tourism in their cities and towns. It has also highlighted that the majority of Queenslanders agree that tourism has a positive impact on the local economy, increases a region’s profile and feelings of local pride, and leads to new infrastructure and more interesting things to do.

Almost 4,000 Queenslanders were surveyed from throughout the state. Ninety-two per cent either were happy with the number of tourists visiting their region or would like to see more. Of the 14 regions surveyed, Gold Coast, Sunshine Coast and Tropical North Queensland residents were more likely to recognise the direct benefit from the industry and as a result were more likely than the average Queenslander to agree that tourism had a positive impact on their quality of life. Given that tourism is a mainstay of these regions’ economies, it is great to see that locals recognise its value.

The majority of residents from the Fraser Coast through to Townsville and also up to Toowoomba acknowledged the benefits of tourists and supported the work being done by local authorities to bring more tourists to their regions. Residents in these areas also indicated they were happy for tourism development to continue.

This inaugural ‘Your Community’ social indicators survey has established a benchmark for future surveys to gauge the impact of tourism on individuals and on their local communities. Tourism is a critical part of Queensland communities and it is important for us to know how to manage the future impact while keeping in mind local priorities and community feedback. The Queensland social indicators fact sheet and regional results can be found on the Tourism Queensland website.

Today I would also like to take the opportunity to announce the results of another survey which has revealed the take-up of environmental practices by tourism businesses. The tourism operators’ environmental indicators benchmark 2010 survey engaged almost 1,000 Queensland tourism operators to assess how they feel and what they think about implementing environmental practices into their business operations. The results highlighted that, while 99 per cent of Queensland operators have implemented at least one affordable energy-saving, water-saving or waste management initiative, half of those surveyed believed that there were not enough benefits or cost savings to justify implementing additional environmental initiatives.

Another finding was that a positive number of operators have made the effort to educate their staff or customers about environmental sustainability in their business, which is good news. For example, three in 10 operators surveyed have implemented a formal staff program on environmental changes. Tourism Queensland will use the survey results as a benchmark for the whole state.

Being more environmentally sustainable through the better management of resources, reducing consumption and waste and gaining environmental credentials to have a competitive edge ultimately leads to increased profitability. This school of thought resonates with tourists as the majority of survey respondents indicated that their customers expected them to be environmentally responsible.

People who adopt green initiatives at home are increasingly looking for similar green practices while on holidays. That is why Tourism Queensland has developed a suite of environmental indicators to use in this survey to measure and manage the impact of tourism on the environment. The indicators will be used in future state, regional and local planning and development strategies.

The survey comes off the back of Tourism Queensland’s work over the past 12 months with regional tourism organisations, councils and operators to roll out the Sustainable Regions project. The project is a first in Australia to work with regional tourism operators to transform Queensland into a domestically and internationally recognised sustainable tourism destination. The project has been piloted on North Stradbroke Island, Airlie Beach, Winton, Magnetic Island and the Pioneer Valley-Cape Hillsborough area and will roll out across other Queensland regions later this year.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (12.02 pm): Despite the government’s attempts at spinning the release of the June 2010 quarterly public hospitals report, it represents more bad news for Queenslanders. On comparing the report’s figures with those 12 months ago, it is clear Queensland’s sickest patients are suffering longer. In June 2009, there were 3,672 category 1 and category 2 patients waiting longer than recommended. Twelve months later there were 5,237--an increase of 1,565 or 43 per cent.

Granted, there have been some inroads into clearing the waiting list backlog for category 3 elective surgery patients. However, this is to be expected when Queenslanders cannot even get themselves on to the list. The waiting list for the waiting list--that is, patients waiting to see a specialist at an outpatient clinic--blew out by almost 20,000 people in just a year to 199,457 as of 1 March 2010. In just six years the waiting list for the waiting list has almost doubled. We have no idea how long people are waiting for specialist appointments across the different specialities and categories because the health minister refuses to make this information available.

Turning to emergency departments, things are no better. Our emergency departments remain dangerously overcrowded with 34 per cent of patients waiting more than eight hours for the bed they need. This is up from 33 per cent 12 months ago. One in eight Queenslanders are now suffering ambulance ramping--up from one in 10 a year ago.

It is an absolute disgrace that in the face of these figures Queenslanders learnt that in the 2010-11 Health budget the health minister and the Treasurer have slowed down the rollout of important health infrastructure to shrink the large budget deficit. The health minister simply cannot justify the delay in hospital expansion projects such as those in Townsville and Bundaberg, to name just two, when waiting lists and times at these hospitals continue to worsen.

The appalling figures in the quarterly hospital report are a direct consequence of 12 years of waste, mismanagement and poor planning from this state Labor government. Time after time we see report after report, audit after audit and review after review telling us that Labor continues to spend huge amounts of money without proper planning or assessment. Labor simply cannot be trusted with the $10 billion Health budget. Labor cannot be trusted to ever deliver health infrastructure where and when it is needed. Labor’s way is to deliver health infrastructure years after it is needed in its marginal seat.

I can sympathise with Queenslanders who are frustrated with the way their health system operates. I can understand that many are looking to the federal government to fix health and hospitals. Unfortunately, passing health from an incompetent Bligh Labor government to an incompetent Rudd-Gillard federal government will not help because federal Labor are just as wasteful and even worse at delivering services.

Everyone recalls Kevin Rudd’s promise to fix hospitals by mid-2009. This promise was broken and the date passed with no action. Everyone recalls Kevin Rudd’s promises of 31 GP superclinics but only around five have been delivered and many are built in marginal seats in direct competition with long-established successful private clinics. Julia Gillard now wants Australians to believe she will deliver a further 23 GP superclinics even though her government could only deliver five out of the 31 promised in 2007.

Earlier this year, in a panic, Kevin Rudd threw together a poorly thought-out health plan with as much detail as state Labor’s campaign costings. Kevin Rudd bullied state premiers to hand over GST and sign up to the plan. Only the Liberal Premier of Western Australian had the sense and the guts to say no. How could the Bligh government have been so reckless with Queenslander’s health by signing away to Canberra 42 per cent of our GST for a deal that lacks so little detail?

From the little detail we have available on federal Labor’s so-called reforms, we know that it will not stop the blame game or cost shifting. It will increase the level of bureaucracy not decrease it. Even less of the health dollar will find its way to front-line health service than before. The states will be in control of the dollars and the local networks will not be local at all because local clinicians will still be locked out of the decision-making process and the networks will simply be existing health districts with the name changed.

Waste and mismanagement are in Labor’s DNA, whether it be state or federal. Queenslanders cannot risk their health with a federal Labor government with a track record of broken promises, waste and abysmal service delivery. The only way Queenslanders will see real action in fixing our once proud health system is to first change the federal government and then change the state government in Queensland.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (12.07 pm): If there is one program that has truly transformed the face of our schools recently it would be the Building the Education Revolution program. As the Parliamentary Secretary for Education I have had the privilege of visiting many schools over the past few months and every single one of them has a BER project. I have been out talking to principals, P&C members, parents and people walking past in the street. These people know that schools are community hubs. These people know what it means to campaign for funds for their schools.

I can tell members confidently that these funds are being delivered and the proof of the pudding is in the eating. As a Gold Coast member, let me give members some examples on the Gold Coast. There are 162 schools with 655 projects receiving a massive $363.5 million in funds for libraries, classroom upgrades and school halls.

Did Southport State School get an injection of funds and building work? You bet. It received $3.2 million for a multipurpose hall, resource centre and refurbishments, and the opposition did not want it. Did Surfers Paradise pick up much needed resources and building work? Absolutely. It received $3.2 million for a hall and library, which the opposition did not want. What about Currumbin State School? Of course. It received $3.2 million for a hall, library and smart digital whiteboards.

In my electorate, St Francis Xavier Primary School received $3.2 million for a new resource centre and new classrooms. Burleigh Heads State School received the same amount of money. Cedar Creek State School’s projects, which are opening soon, received almost $2.2 million.

Gilston Primary School received $3 million for a new hall and Coombabah High School received $200,000 for shade sails, including funding for the upgrade of its home economics building. Every primary school not just on the Gold Coast but in Queensland has benefited, and still those opposite manage to sit back and plot how they would rob our schools of this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. They did not want it, they still do not and they are out of touch with their entire state by running an agenda that would gut our schools. But an opposition empty on policy is even sounding hollow on the issue. As newspaper clippings and school records will show, they have been turning up to BER openings right across this state, as have members of the federal opposition. Just ask Steven Ciobo and Stuart Robert, who are turning up at these openings and new projects trying to take some of the credit when they wanted to take all of the money away.

You have to ask yourself why. If they are so stubbornly opposed to this revolution, why are they trying to plaster their faces all over these photo opportunities? I will tell you why: because they know these projects are a fantastic hit with the community. They backed a losing policy in opposition and are trying to switch the betting now that they have realised that this program has been a huge success in Queensland. But do not take my word for it; ask a parent, ask a principal and ask the students who are now studying and learning and playing in 21st century facilities that they deserve. The Bligh government and the federal government are spending $10 million a day on capital works in Queensland schools and the opposition would have gutted more than two-thirds of that figure. Non-state schools are benefiting too, as are small schools that would struggle to raise the kind of money needed to build quality buildings. At each turn in Queensland I see the benefits of this program. This is the single largest investment of capital into Queensland schools in the history of investment, and it has been a resounding success.

These projects have also created jobs. The Gold Coast suffered more than most during the global financial crisis as the construction industry slowed down and people were looking for work. They found work on these projects--thousands of workers across the state, from our small contractors to our larger businesses that employ many people. The BER created work for these businesses, jobs for locals and unprecedented investment in our schools. I would hate to think what would have happened on the Gold Coast if the BER was scrapped like the opposition wanted. I would hate to think what might have happened in Queensland. That is why I want those members opposite to look our parents, principals, children and workers in the eye and tell them why they would have forsaken this program.

Those opposite have no more fearmongering to hide behind, as three independent reviews have confirmed the greatest aspects of the BER in Queensland--the job building, the nation building and the quality buildings in our schools. They have nothing left except a hollow mantra that our schools did not deserve this and that our students did not deserve anything better. I do not know what planet they have been living on, but I enjoy visiting in my community and noting the real positive difference BER projects have made. I challenge the opposition to visit any school, speak to parents, students and staff and continue to make the empty argument that schools should have received nothing. That is not what a Labor government stands for.

Mr CRIPPS (Hinchinbrook--LNP) (12.12 pm): Two articles in the Sunday Mail on 14 August by Kathleen Donaghey touched on issues that I have been pursuing in this place in respect of autism spectrum disorder. These two articles seriously question the Bligh government’s handling of the issue of ASD in Queensland amongst children and challenge the claims by the Minister for Disability Services that early intervention services for autism are a priority for the Bligh government, and I table the articles.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Articles from the Sunday Mail , dated 15 August 2010, titled ‘Autism diagnosis doubt’ and ‘A hidden condition’ [ 2752 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: The articles quote autism expert Dr Glenys Jones from the University of Birmingham describing Queensland’s two per cent of state school students last year being diagnosed with autism--a rate double that of the United Kingdom--as excessive and worrying. The articles also quote Professor Tony Attwood, an autism expert based in Brisbane, describing Queensland’s two per cent diagnosis rate as excessive by world standards and asserting that either something in Queensland is creating an epidemic or something is happening in the diagnosis that needs to be checked.

The fact is in Queensland the Bligh government is not capable of determining whether it is one or the other because it does not have any reliable data to make an informed decision. During the hearing of Estimates Committee D on 16 July I referred to a 2007 report from the Australian Advisory Board on Autism Spectrum Disorders that stated that it could not use Queensland figures because Education Queensland declined to provide any data on the basis that there is no nationally agreed definition of autism and Disability Services Queensland did not keep ASD specific statistics. The articles revealed that a review into Queensland’s high rate of autism was ordered by the then minister for education, Rod Welford, but that this review did not go ahead. Evidently, no effort was made by DSQ to secure reliable data in respect of the prevalence of ASD amongst young Queenslanders.

When I asked Minister Palaszczuk on 16 July about needs based mapping, the minister confirmed that needs based mapping has only been happening now in 2010--three years after the advisory board revealed Queensland’s data shortcomings.
