I also asked the minister, given that no needs based mapping had been done, on what basis DSQ had been allocating funding to meet the needs of Queensland children with ASD to this point in time. I acknowledged that the minister can point to funding provided to Autism Queensland and the AEIOU Foundation and the delivery of early intervention services in places like Bundaberg and Mackay and, as we heard this morning, the Sunshine Coast, and I welcome these allocations. However, what the advisory board report confirms and what this article reveals is that there is no rhyme or reason--no scientific rationale--behind DSQ’s haphazard funding for early intervention services for ASD across Queensland.

What I want to know is how has the Bligh government been making its decisions about how to fund early intervention services for ASD in Queensland. In April this year I asked Minister Palaszczuk why the Bligh government was refusing to provide funding to Waminda Services in Dalby, a local disability services provider delivering services to the Western Downs and the Surat Basin. The minister did not answer my question in April and the minister did not answer my question when I asked her again during the estimates hearing on 16 July. The truth is that the minister did not answer my question because she cannot answer my question. The minister cannot tell this parliament or the parents of Queensland children with ASD why DSQ is prepared to fund the AEIOU Foundation and Autism Queensland but not Waminda Services, and that is the crux of the problem in Queensland and the reason I am concerned.

While the minister has described the AEIOU Foundation and Autism Queensland as the major providers of early intervention services that have the capacity to deliver, there are other local providers of support services that have the capacity to deliver to their local communities. While I certainly wanted to draw to the attention of the House the plight of Waminda Services in Dalby, the parallel point that I have been trying to make is that the Bligh government cannot and has not been making genuinely needs based funding decisions because there is no needs based mapping data for ASD.

In terms of delivering early intervention services for autism in Queensland, we are flying blind, feeling our way through and responding in an ad hoc fashion to an enormous outpouring of competing demands for support services across the state driven by a diagnosis rate double that of comparable jurisdictions that has been described by experts as excessive and worrying. The experts have been questioning the policies of the Bligh government in respect of who can diagnose ASD amongst children in Queensland and how resources are subsequently allocated. I thank Kathleen Donaghey for underlining the questions that I have been asking.

Mr PITT (Mulgrave--ALP) (12.17 pm): The Green Army is an election commitment that is being delivered as promised by the Bligh government. It is a $57 million investment that will employ 3,000 Queenslanders during this term on projects of environmental importance. The Green Army is part of the Skilling Queenslanders for Work initiative in which the Queensland government in 2010-11 will invest more than $106 million to give job related assistance and skills training to maximise labour force participation for an estimated 24,000 long-term unemployed and underemployed people.

Over the past few months the esplanade at Yarrabah has been undergoing an upgrade at the hands of 12 local men and women who joined Queensland’s Green Army. Yarrabah has one of the highest unemployment rates in the state and is still reeling from the withdrawal of the Community Development Employment Program--CDEP--last year, so this Green Army project was a real boost for these participants. The state government funds Green Army projects in part to achieve results like the Yarrabah esplanade project--attractive green spaces that draw in locals and visitors and teach them about caring for the environment. The changes that have happened to the site have been great to see. Their efforts--weeding, growing native plants, building garden beds, benches, tables, barbecues and walkways--have been a great benefit to the whole community. The state government also funds these projects so that participants can gain skills and experience while working on the projects.

I was fortunate to be able to be there last week to meet with each of the program’s 12 participants as they graduated at the end of their 20 weeks paid work on the project funded to the tune of $191,980 by the Bligh government. This recent experience completing different landscaping and horticulture tasks, which included learning new skills and how to use tools and other machinery safely, will be a great asset when applying for jobs. They have shown a great attitude to completing the different tasks asked of them and they have also completed some accredited training for the certificate II in horticulture, so heading to TAFE and earning a qualification that will open up more job opportunities is now an option for them too.

The Yarrabah Aboriginal Shire Council also deserves recognition for supporting, supervising and organising this project. As well as providing the use of vehicles and materials, the council provided great support and supervision for the group, which ensured that the participants gained a lot of valuable skills and understanding and their standard of work was very high. My congratulations go to everyone involved in this project. This group of people should be very proud of their work and have self-confidence as they pursue other employment and training options in the future.

But where will those jobs be? When CDEP came to an abrupt end, much of the workforce was left without employment and almost all existing opportunities in Yarrabah were taken up, thanks to the good work of the Yarrabah transition to employment task force. The federal Department of Families, Housing, Community Services and Indigenous Affairs--FaHCSIA--provided a subsidy to provide a bus service based around work hours in order to assist workers to access opportunities outside the community. But this service was an interim transition measure and to remain viable it must be subsidised. The withdrawal of the subsidy would make the cost of travel to individuals for work purposes prohibitive.

After positive discussions with the state government, the federal government has extended funding for this service until October 2010. But where to after that? In addition to the funding for the bus subsidy, FaHCSIA provided further funding to the Yarrabah Aboriginal Shire Council to engage consultants to undertake a transport study regarding the internal and external public transport needs and options for the short, medium and longer term. For several months I have been investigating options for the continuation of the current service to allow time for longer term options in the study to be progressed. I mentioned earlier that Yarrabah lost its CDEP as it was not designated a remote area for the purposes of the program, largely because, when viewed on a map, it appears close to a major centre like Cairns.

Although the distance to be travelled may not be great, Yarrabah is an isolated community. People do not have access to reliable transportation--public or private. I am not aware of too many communities of 4,500 people that have such limited transport options. However, the community’s proximity to Cairns may yet be the answer, with a water based transport option a logical long-term option. A ferry service like the one that services Palm Island near Townsville would reduce the transit time from 90 minutes to about 30 minutes and would have the added advantage of opening up economic development opportunities for the community. This is an option that governments of all levels need to consider seriously and I am seeking the assistance of state and federal agencies to contribute to a feasibility study and a cost-benefit analysis to secure Yarrabah’s long-term future.

Of course, any talk of a ferry service would first require the necessary infrastructure. A jetty would be a multimillion-dollar proposition. So the discussion around infrastructure and who pays is critical. Then there is the recurrent funding that would be necessary to operate an ongoing ferry service.

Water transport could also allow tourist access to Yarrabah, opening up options for cultural tourism with subsequent jobs growth within the community. It may be that the construction of a jetty must be a development condition of any future tourism accommodation venture that, subject to agreement of traditional owners, would be located on one of Far North Queensland’s best beaches.

Yarrabah has a strong pool of skilled workers who only need to be matched with suitable employers. But those jobs are in Cairns, not Yarrabah. If we want to combat high unemployment, we have to provide this basic service to get people to the jobs. The alternative is that they have to move away from the community to be closer to work. We have an education system and training and employment programs like the Green Army getting people ready for the workforce, but we have no service to transport workers to the job market. It is for this reason that passenger transport services must be a priority for Yarrabah in order for inroads to be made into unemployment in the community.

Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--Ind) (12.22 pm): Today, I would like to call on both the Leader of the Opposition and the Premier to, between now and the state election, hold a bipartisan forum on the roles and responsibilities of the state parliament itself. As simple as that may sound, I think that the time has well come that all levels of government need to have a bit of a reality check on their roles and responsibilities. The debate will always go on as to whether we are overgoverned or whether we are governed inefficiently. It is my opinion that it is probably both.

I think that there needs to be genuine, systematic reform--and a genuine will from both sides of the parliament--of state parliament. Today is the first opportunity that I can place on the public record my draft model for the reinstatement of an upper house, which the Queensland Party will be running as a major policy platform between now and the state election. I have written to all 73 mayors across the state and have been liaising with many of those mayors and with many more to come. They have until 10 September to contribute to this consultation as we formulate a model for the reinstatement of an upper house.

Over the years there has been a lack of will from all sides of the parliament to reinstate an upper house. I think it is absolutely essential that Queenslanders be given the opportunity to have a little bit more faith in terms of the parliamentary system which, currently, is fundamentally flawed. As things stand, mayors are largely powerless and councils are treading on eggshells, living with a sense of fear in terms of what they can and cannot do. It was Thomas Jefferson who said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: When the people fear their government, there is tyranny; when the government fears the people, there is liberty.
XML.Hansard-Body: That quote rings true when we consider the state of Queensland politics today. I think it is well time that the leaders of the major parties--the Leader of the Opposition and the Premier--put on the public record a draft model. I am not saying that my model is right; I am putting it out for public debate. I think we need genuine will from this parliament to ensure that there are credible checks and balances in the representation of the 4.3 million Queenslanders who, slowly but surely, are losing faith in the system that we call democracy here.

Last year I met with the mayor of the Torres Strait Islands, Fred Gela. The people of the Torres Strait want to have their own territory, because they are feeling somewhat disconnected. It was only last week that we saw the north’s bid to split from the state. Only two of 100 delegates voted against the motion at a recent North Queensland Local Government Association meeting to split Queensland. I can understand their frustration. However, I do not support it. But I think the underlying factor is that people, apart from rural and regional Queenslanders, are starting to hurt. The people of North Queensland are feeling disconnected. The people of the Torres Strait are feeling disconnected.

The draft model that I have proposed is that 45 seats will be reinstated in the upper house. Of those, 36 seats will have a four-year tenure and those 36 will represent the 36 most populated councils across Queensland. The remaining 36 representatives would rotate annually in nine seats. That would be 45 seats, which represents half the number of seats in the lower house. The 73rd seat would be the equivalent of the Speaker, which would be the Lord Mayor of the Brisbane City Council. This would also make sure that there are checks and balances and that there is a fair ledger. At the moment, power is centralised in South-East Queensland.

We need to understand that state and local governments need to work together. They need to have faith in each other--not to live in fear of each other, but to be able to work together and provide true representation. To date, it is the only model that I can think of that has been laid on the table that includes in this parliament local and state governments working together and also includes an Aboriginal voice and a Torres Strait Islander voice, both of which will be necessary. Any division on any legislation in this House would provide a trigger for it to go to the upper house. That would ensure that sloppy legislation is not passed in the first instance in this parliament.

I believe that this model has merit, as do many mayors across Queensland. As I liaise with the mayors, the communities and the councils over the next 12 to 15 months, I say that we need to have faith in local government and the state government being able to work together--not to take the water assets from them, not to impose a water bill separate from people’s rates notices and not, at a whim, to take any assets from councils that ratepayers have contributed to over the years. People out there are hurting. Their rates are increasing and their taxes are increasing. I think a mature approach would be for local government and the state government to work together. It is the only model that will create efficiencies for the state and local councils. It will require a clear and concise set of roles and responsibilities. I now put out the challenge to both major parties to put their model of the House to ensure that there is true representation and that Queensland is no longer, as Tony Fitzgerald would say, the political malpractice of Australia.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (12.27 pm): I am pleased to advise the parliament of an exciting new development for the Coorparoo junction area. As many members would be aware--particularly those from the south side of Brisbane--the junction at the intersection of Old Cleveland Road and Cavendish Road is the heart of the suburb of Coorparoo. I grew up on Brisbane’s southside at Holland Park, one of the many vibrant suburbs in the electorate of Greenslopes, which I am now privileged to represent in this parliament. As a boy I can remember going to the junction with my parents to shop at Myer at Coorparoo. In those days, the area was a vibrant commercial hub.

Since then, shopping trends have changed and we have seen the growth of major suburban shopping centres such as the Westfield complexes at Carindale and Garden City. The departure of major tenants from the old Myer building at Coorparoo meant that this jewel in the crown of the Coorparoo business precinct lost some of its lustre. News earlier this month indicates that this jewel is about to shine again.

The revitalisation of the Coorparoo junction will take a massive step forward later this year when new markets open in the old Myer building. These markets, which will operate four days a week--from Thursday to Sunday--should boost the local economy and increase commercial activity in the area. The new operators, businessmen Frank Dragani and Tony Abi-Fares, have signed a lease with the Department of Transport and Main Roads to operate the new markets for two years, with an option to renew. The markets will complement existing retail activities in the Coorparoo junction precinct, selling fresh produce such as fish and delicatessen items, gourmet produce and a range of variety items from budget fashions through to specialty clothing. This is a very exciting development and has been welcomed by southside residents, particularly those from areas such as Coorparoo and Camp Hill who use this area regularly. I have been aware of the community’s views on the vacant Myer building for some time. Reactivating and re-energising the Coorparoo junction has been one of my top priorities since my election as the state member for Greenslopes last year.

I am very pleased that we have been able to work with the local business community, such as local business leaders Cass Conwell and Peter Weiss, and the Department of Transport and Main Roads to arrange this new lease. I also wish to acknowledge the support of the transport minister, Rachel Nolan, in making this new retail development a reality.

Any redevelopment of the old Myer building will complement the next stage of the Eastern Busway, which will include a busway station in the Coorparoo junction area. I firmly believe that the Coorparoo Junction site has the potential to support a mixed residential, retail and commercial development, making Coorparoo the southside’s own urban village and bringing further vibrancy to the area. A development of this nature would also fit in well with the Brisbane City Council’s Eastern Corridor Renewal Strategy. As happens throughout our city, the government wishes to work constructively with the Brisbane City Council to revitalise Coorparoo junction and to work in partnership with the council to explore the prospects of a transport associated development on the site.

I also note that the traffic intersection of Old Cleveland Road and Cavendish Road is of concern to local residents. While these roads are council controlled roads and the management of this intersection is the responsibility of the Brisbane City Council, I am aware that the council is working on options to improve the safety of the intersection for pedestrians and motorists.

The state government is also continuing to work with the federal government and in particular with Infrastructure Australia to seek funding for the next stage of the Eastern Busway beyond Main Avenue at Coorparoo. Obviously, the government’s long-term goal is to complete the Eastern Busway so that it will extend from the University of Queensland, through to Coorparoo, Camp Hill, Carina and Carindale, then beyond to Capalaba. Already stage 1 of this project, from the Eleanor Schonell Bridge at Dutton Park to the South East Busway at Buranda, has been completed at a cost of $366 million.

We have now started on the $465 million second stage between Buranda and Main Avenue. This stage is scheduled for completion by early 2012 and will make an enormous difference to travel times for commuters going to the city or the University of Queensland, particularly residents of the electorate of Greenslopes. At the moment, funding for the next stage of the busway, from Main Avenue to Bennetts Road, is yet to be secured. This will be an expensive part of the overall Eastern Busway project. Early estimates indicate that it could cost upwards of $800 million as construction work will require tunnelling as well as cut-and-cover engineering work.

The Eastern Busway will bring long-term gains to the community. I will continue to work with all levels of government to ensure the next stages are funded, built and delivered for the community. Regardless of the timing of the next stage of the busway, Coorparoo junction will always be a focal point for residents of the Greenslopes electorate. That is why the announcement of these new markets is so exciting. Along with other residents, I look forward to visiting the markets once they open for business.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (12.31 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004, the Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration Act 2003 and the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper : Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 [ 2753 ].
Tabled paper: Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, explanatory notes [ 2754 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (12.31 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: I introduce a bill into the House today that reaffirms this government’s commitment to ensuring the highest possible levels of protection for children. The Child Protection (Offender Reporting) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 encompasses a suite of amendments to enhance the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 and contributes towards establishing national consistency in compliance management and monitoring of reportable offenders both in Queensland and throughout Australia. To this end, the bill amends the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004, the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 and the Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration Act 2003.

On 19 June 2009 the Ministerial Council for Police and Emergency Management--Police met and considered a report containing recommendations that sought to align jurisdictional responses for the compliance management and monitoring of reportable offenders. Following the work of the Ministerial Council for Police and Emergency Management--Police, the Queensland Police Service also undertook a review of the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 and recommended further changes to enhance the existing legislation. These recommendations collectively underlie the amendments to be given effect through this bill. The amendments are balanced and justified with regard to respecting the rights of individuals but also ensuring the highest possible levels of protection for children as the most vulnerable members of our community.

The Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 requires offenders who commit sexual or particular other serious offences against children to keep police informed of their whereabouts and other personal details for inclusion in the Queensland Child Protection Register. This register was established under the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004, which commenced on 1 January 2005 and forms the Queensland component of the Australian National Child Offender Register, ANCOR, utilised by all Australian police jurisdictions for information sharing relevant to compliance management and monitoring of reportable offenders and investigation of any suspected noncompliance.

This bill will enhance the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 and contribute towards national legislative consistency by reducing the time limit that reportable offenders will have to make initial reports as well as the time limit imposed to report the names and ages of any children living at a place where they generally reside or with whom they have regular unsupervised contact. The time limit for completing an initial report will be reduced from 28 days to seven days and the time for reporting contact with a child will be reduced from 28 days to just four days, imposing an obligation to report within 24 hours of three days contact with a child in any one-year period, whether consecutive or not. These amendments will effectively enhance the ability of police to monitor reportable offenders in the community and enable authorities to intervene in situations where children may be exposed to risk at a much earlier stage.

Reportable offenders will also be required to report telecommunication carriage services, internet service providers, email addresses and/or other electronic identifiers used or intended to be used. The obligation will contribute to monitoring and deterring reportable offenders from using such devices in offences against or involving children--for example, accessing child exploitation material and/or engaging in predatory behaviour such as grooming children via the internet. Reportable offenders will also be required to report their passport details as relevant to monitoring and provide verification of travel outside Australia which will contribute towards deterring child sex tourism and support investigation of it.

To support rigorous monitoring of reportable offenders who pose a risk to the most vulnerable members of the community, they will be required to obtain the Police Commissioner’s approval before changing their name. If a reportable offender proceeds to change their name without the necessary approval under the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 there is provision for the registrar to correct the register under the Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration Act 2003 on application from the Police Commissioner.

This bill also allows for DNA samples to be taken from reportable offenders in certain circumstances if no record is kept. Although it is acknowledged that recidivism risk varies across sex offenders, it is considered important to obtain DNA samples from reportable offenders. The abhorrent nature of serious sexual offences warrants the taking of DNA samples from reportable offenders in the interests of facilitating investigations and providing the best protection for children.

The increase in penalties for failing to comply with reporting obligations and/or giving false or misleading information from two years to five years imprisonment and the reclassification of these offences as crimes accurately conveys the Bligh government’s view about the seriousness of such offending in terms of the risk it poses to the community. Fines that may be imposed have also been increased, from 150 to 300 penalty units. It is expected that these increased penalties will contribute to compliance including by providing courts with a higher range of punishment that can be imposed, thereby helping to deter such criminal behaviour and ultimately ensure the highest possible levels of protection for children.

The new class 1 and 2 offences to be listed in schedules 1 and 2 reflect, in part, recent amendments made to the Criminal Code Act 1995 and effectively contribute to the comprehensive coverage of serious offences against children. Significantly, the addition of the new offences will have a retrospective application because the definition of a reportable offender includes a person who has been sentenced and/or released from custody for a reportable offence--that is, a class 1 or class 2 offence--after the commencement of the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004. This will result in certain offenders whose convictions are in the past and who are not currently entered in the register becoming reportable offenders unless their reporting period is deemed to have already expired under part 4, division 5 of the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004.

New and additional reporting obligations will not apply unless the Police Commissioner has given a person a ‘notice of reporting obligations’ under section 59 of the act. Subsequently, it is maintained that these amendments strike the balance between having sufficient regard to respecting the rights of individuals and protecting children. In order to contribute to national consistency, courts will be given wider discretion to make ‘offender reporting orders’ with respect to non-familial child kidnapping offences. This will bring Queensland into line with other jurisdictions in terms of making non-familial child kidnapping a reportable offence.

Finally, the inclusion of a declaratory provision in the bill is to put beyond any doubt that any disclosure or release of personal information from the Child Protection Register to corresponding registrars in foreign jurisdictions is and always was lawful. This is to address an anomaly which occurred with regard to information sharing with jurisdictions that introduced corresponding legislation after the commencement of the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 and Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Regulation 2004 on 1 January 2005.

I am confident members of the House will agree that this legislation will contribute towards national legislative consistency and enhance the Child Protection (Offender Reporting) Act 2004 to ensure the highest possible levels of protection for children in Queensland and throughout Australia. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Johnson, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 3 August (see p. 2362), on motion of Mr Roberts--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (12.41 pm): It is with great interest that I rise to speak to the Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill 2009. I am glad that we are finally having this long overdue debate. On 6 August last year, I asked a question without notice of the Premier. The question was: why are illegal brothel operators in Queensland issued with token fines of a couple of thousand dollars, when legal operators pay $30,000 or more in government fees and charges? The Premier’s response was that if someone is caught doing something illegal and is fined, the government’s laws are working. That did not answer the question: why is illegal prostitution being treated so leniently in Queensland, which the Premier claims has the toughest prostitution laws in this country?

Two weeks later, I asked a further question on this issue, following the release of the University of Queensland research report on illegal prostitution. I pointed out that the research found that only 10 percent of Queensland sex workers operate in legal brothels--hardly a ringing endorsement of this government’s prostitution laws. On this occasion the Premier seemed to take the issue more seriously and announced the introduction in the House of this bill that is now finally before us. I am very pleased to see that the government has belatedly seen fit to address part of this serious problem in our society. I do find it extraordinary that it has taken so long.

It was 20 years ago that the Fitzgerald inquiry showed the links between prostitution, organised crime and police corruption. The CMC report regulating prostitution was released in 2004 and its follow-up report on the regulation of outcall prostitution was published in 2006. Finally, the government has seen fit to take some action. Whether it goes far enough is another matter.

Queensland has had legalised prostitution for 10 years. That has not stopped illegal prostitution from flourishing in this state. One reason for that is the current legislation, which makes operating a legal brothel very expensive. I have already referred to the fees of $30,000 or more. That is what it costs to apply for an average legal brothel licence. A successful applicant then has to pay an annual licence fee of around $20,000 to continue operating that brothel. There are additional fees payable if there are multiple licence holders and for each manager who works on the premises. Each of the licensees and managers also has to have a current first aid certificate--a further expense.

The average brothel would be required to spend around $35,000 in licence fees and related charges alone. I understand those fees are likely to increase again this year. That is a lot of money. While we may see it as a way of limiting the number of brothels in the state, the real consequence is to encourage people to operate illegal brothels. There is not much incentive to apply for a legal brothel licence when you compare the costs. No wonder there are only 25 licensed brothels in Queensland. The costs and restrictions make it very difficult to run a successful legal business.

The example I used in my original question to the Premier in August was the penalty handed down on the Sunshine Coast to a man linked to an illegal Asian sex ring. He was fined $2,000, but no conviction was recorded. That is hardly more than a slap on the wrist for someone running a very profitable illegal business. That man’s alleged link to an overseas sex ring points to another issue: the connection between illegal prostitution and people trafficking. We are kidding ourselves if we think that is not happening in Queensland. People trafficking is in the same league as drug and arms smuggling. It causes enormous human misery and exploits some of the most vulnerable people in our society. It is, to a large extent, a hidden problem and difficult to get accurate statistics, but that does not mean we should ignore it. I note that there was a report published that 95 per cent of people-trafficking victims in Australia are women who are forced to work as prostitutes. Anything we can do to stop this should be done.

There are many positives in this state’s prostitution laws. They prevent brothels from being established in inappropriate areas. They provide protection for both sex workers and customers through health and safety regulation. They set criteria for brothel licence holders and regulate advertising. The evidence would seem to suggest that Queensland’s laws have been effective when it comes to prostitution in legal brothels. What has not been addressed properly is the unregulated prostitution industry, which includes legal prostitution offered by sole operators, as well as illegal brothels. The lack of regulation of this part of the industry is extraordinary when compared to the strict controls on brothels.

I am pleased to see that the bill before us addresses at least some of the issues relating to illegal prostitution as offered through outcall and social escort services. The CMC has estimated that 75 per cent of prostitution in Queensland involves outcall services rather than brothels. These services can legally be provided by a prostitute working as a sole operator who does not have to pay licence fees. Given the size of those fees, it does not come as any surprise that this law is being abused by those escort agencies that offer illegal outcall prostitution.

Sole operators are not controlled in terms of health checks, which presents great risks both to them and to their customers. Sex workers operating alone are also vulnerable to violence and exploitation, particularly those who are street prostitutes. The latter are often involved in illicit drugs and may have additional health problems related to their drug addiction. They are very unlikely to seek assistance from authorities. The same applies to prostitutes who may have been brought in illegally from overseas to work in the sex industry.

It will, of course, always be difficult to control or prevent street prostitution. However, the government has missed a real opportunity in this legislation to address the problem of sole operators. Why should they not be subject to some form of licensing, which would include mandatory health checks? As well as providing protection to the sex workers and the community, this would provide authorities with a register of legal prostitutes. Such a register would help not only the police but other agencies, including the tax office and health authorities.

Clause 12 of the bill specifically excludes provision of prostitution from the definition of a social escort. Other clauses in the bill address how such services may be advertised. Advertising for escort services will now have to specifically state that sexual services are not provided. Further, the provider of the escort service is required to clearly inform the client that such services are not provided. While this in itself will not necessarily prevent illegal prostitution from being offered, it will make it much more difficult for those agencies to attract clients. Legitimate escort agencies, such as those who do not provide prostitution, will not be affected.

It is to be hoped that these restrictions will reduce the incidence of illegal prostitution being offered through escort services. This is a long overdue reform, as illegal brothels posing as escort agencies are flourishing. They are able to take out cheap advertising in the local papers and, because they do not have the massive licence fees and regulations that are imposed on legal brothels, they are able to charge customers a lot less. Recently I have been told of one such escort business on the Sunshine Coast that is doing exactly that.

Another avenue that should be considered is to legalise the provision of outcall services by legal brothels. I understand that this is allowed in Victoria. With strict laws governing brothels already in place, it would be far easier to police outcall services provided by them than by unregulated sole operators. This bill introduces to the Criminal Code a new offence relating to the business of providing prostitution by two or more prostitutes. It is appropriate that this offence should carry the maximum penalty of seven years imprisonment, making it a serious crime. I note that this will also enable the assets of illegal providers to be confiscated. We need to ensure that all penalties associated with running an illegal prostitution business are high enough to be a real deterrent.

The amendments in Clause 16 are worthy of comment. A person who holds a crowd control licence is legally able to act as a driver for a sole operator sex worker, provided they do not work for any other sole operator prostitute. A person may also legally receive a message from a sole operator about their location or activities, provided the person receiving the message is not themselves a current sex worker or assisting other sex workers. Sole sex workers are currently allowed to have a bodyguard to protect them, and this is appropriate. The ability to send messages to another person, without that person risking prosecution, should provide additional security. However, I question how these provisions are to be policed, particularly in regard to allowing these people to work for only one sex worker. It will be almost impossible to prevent a driver setting himself or herself up in a nice little business with more than one prostitute. My understanding is that police resources are already limited when it comes to enforcement in this area. Unless that is addressed, illegal operations will continue to flourish. The amendment to the Child Employment Act to make it an offence for anyone under 18 years of age to be employed as a social escort is entirely appropriate.

In closing, I commend to the House the research I have already referred to by Dr Andreas Schloenhardt and the Human Trafficking Working Group at the University of Queensland. Their findings support much of what I have said today. I suggest that the research be used to consider further opportunities to reduce the incidence of illegal prostitution in Queensland. There is still not enough incentive for people to operate legally in this industry. There are experts who can advise government on how to improve the law and its enforcement. We should be making better use of those experts. I commend this bill as a starting point, but much more work needs to be done in this area.

Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (12.51 pm): In rising to speak to the Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill I acknowledge the previous speaker, the member for Buderim, and his great advocacy work. He has highlighted many injustices and inconsistencies in the current state legislation. It is largely because of his efforts that this bill is before the House today. I believe that, overall, the bill has the balance right. In its report the CMC said that it operated on the precautionary principle. However, I would like to see some adjustments made to the bill, especially around penalties. I will come to those very shortly.

I acknowledge the five aims of the prostitution bill: to ensure the quality of life of local communities, safeguard against corruption and organised crime, address social factors that contribute to the involvement in the sex industry, ensure a healthy society and promote safety. In the report titled Regulating Outcall Prostitution, which informed this legislation, a former chair the CMC, Robert Needham, wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We were unable to find any evidence--and none was submitted to us--that legalising outcall services from licensed brothels or escort agencies in Queensland would improve the health and safety of sex workers providing these services, or minimise the size of the illegal industry. As a result, we are now firmly of the view that the risks associated with the legalisation of outcalls from either licensed brothels or independent escort agencies (which might include an expansion of the industry overall, and/or an increase in illegal activity either within the industry or more broadly across the state), are simply not worth taking.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I say, ‘Hear, hear’ to that. He continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The CMC sees a risk emerging in this area if those illegal operators become more desperate for workers. These risks could include the importation of prostitutes from interstate, the use of illegal immigrants as prostitutes and the recruitment of underage girls.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In a very informative article in the Courier-Mail on 14 February this year, Dr Janet Ransley wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: But, as anti-corruption commissioner Tony Fitzgerald noted last year, vigilance is needed to maintain the reform agenda in the face of complacency and self-interest.

It is easy to forget the scale and reach of the corruption that Fitzgerald uncovered. From the 1960s through to the late 1980s, crooked police at the highest level protected criminals who ran illegal activities in Queensland, especially prostitution, bookmaking and illicit liquor sales.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: As as well as being harmful in all sorts of ways to the individuals who participate, illegal prostitution is also an indicator of a number of broader social illnesses or sicknesses, corruption being one of the primary illnesses. Ransley writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Fitzgerald did not just expose police corruption but also showed how an ineffective parliament, a distorted and unfair electoral system, a moribund and politicised public service and justice system, secrecy, and a lack of modern administrative appeals and judicial review all acted to entrench and hide that corruption.
XML.Hansard-Body: I believe that the illegal prostitution that is happening today is being aided and abetted by the same systemic faults that have started to make their appearance felt since Fitzgerald brought down his findings. If we are to be honest, as legislators we are treating the symptoms and not the causes, which surely must include poverty, illiteracy, abuse, addictions to alcohol and drugs, untreated mental illnesses, relationship breakdowns, organised crime and, of course, outlaw motorcycle expansion. Just as surely as night follows day, wherever you have a growth in outlaw motorcycle gangs and organised crime, you will have a growth in prostitution. You will also have a growth in murder, money laundering, intimidation, extortion, arson, assault, robbery, theft, counterfeiting, and so on.
Mr O’Brien interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hoolihan): Order! Member for Cook, the member for Burnett has the call.

Mr MESSENGER: How do you fix the problem? In a report titled 2005 National Gang Threat Assessment , written in partnership with the FBI’s National Drug Intelligence Centre to aid communities looking for ways to address the problem, the then Texas Attorney-General provided three recommendations: first the problem has to be acknowledged, then the problem has to be assessed, and then the problem has to be acted on. In acknowledging the problem the Attorney-General said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Denial is never beneficial. You cannot solve a problem until you admit that it exists.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Secondly, to assess the problem, the problem needs to be quantified. This statement worries me, because the CMC report states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: On the other hand, none of the stakeholders, including the QPS, could give any definite indication of the extent to which organised crime features in the illegal prostitution industry in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Surely it should be a priority for the Queensland Police Service to work out exactly how big is the influence of organised crime in the prostitution industry in Queensland. The CMC report goes on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The other jurisdiction closer to home is Victoria. CATWA argued strongly at the public hearing that legalisation of brothels in Victoria has entrenched organised crime in the state’s prostitution industry. In its Shadow Report for the CEDAW (Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women) committee (Jeffreys, Chambers & Spencer n.d.) CATWA claims:

Australian states that have legalised brothel prostitution say that they aim to control the size and shape of the industry and contain organised crime. This aim has not been fulfilled ... Even the legal brothels may be connected with organised crime.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Of course, we need to act on the problem and, as legislators, that is what we are doing today by contributing to the debate and voting on the legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body: I would like to highlight for the House some of the issues associated with penalties as outlined in the CMC report, particularly those related to the employing or contracting of minors. The report states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Currently, there is no law in any jurisdiction of Australia to prevent people under the age of 18 years from providing social escort services. We believe there should be a prohibition on employing or contracting a person under the age of 18 years for the purpose of providing social escort services.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I compliment the government and the police minister for picking up and following through on that recommendation. The report continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Child Employment Act 2006 , which came into operation on 1 July 2006, prohibits an employer from requiring a child to perform work prescribed under a regulation under the Act. We strongly recommend that social escort services be prescribed under a regulation under the Act. Social companionship may operate as a precursor to participation in the sex industry, and we consider that the Child Employment Act should be used to guard against this possibility. The only legitimate social escort provider with whom we had contact throughout the escorts inquiry strongly agreed with this recommendation.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That refers to recommendation 10, which is--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font.Hansard-Bold: That the regulations to the Child Employment Act 2006 prohibit the employment of minors as social escorts.

XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Part 4 of the bill amends the Child Employment Act 2006. Under the prohibition on work as a social escort, an employer must not require or permit a child to work as a social escort. The maximum penalty is 100 penalty units.
XML.Hansard-Body: Sitting suspended from 1.01 pm to 2.30 pm.

Mr MESSENGER:
In closing my speech on the Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill, I would like to acknowledge that the first priority for any legislator--indeed any member of society--should be to put the care and protection of children before all others. That should be our No. 1 priority. As reported in the CMC report, ‘Currently, there is no law in any jurisdiction of Australia to prevent people under the age of 18 years from providing social escort services.’ I compliment the government because this will be the first piece of legislation passed through any jurisdiction which, by amending the Child Employment Act 2006, will make the employment of children illegal. This bill amends that act by inserting a new section which states--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: 8B Prohibition on workers as social escort

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (1) An employer must not require or permit a child to work as a social escort.
XML.Hansard-Body: But I make this point: is 100 penalty units enough? One hundred penalty units equates to $10,000. I find it very hard to come to terms with this fact. If you employ a child to work as a social escort, you are liable for a maximum penalty of $10,000, or 100 penalty units, and no jail sentence. If you shoot and kill a flying fox in Queensland you are up for a maximum fine of $300,000 and a two-year jail sentence. If you scare a flying fox out of a roost you are up for a $100,000 fine and a year’s imprisonment. But if you get a 15-year-old girl or boy to work as an escort, the most you can be fined under this law is $10,000 and no jail term.

What are these legislative penalties telling us about this government and our society? Firstly, they show what the people who influence the legislators of this government value more--what they think should have a higher status. The wellbeing of flying foxes is obviously more important to them than the wellbeing and safety of our children. Secondly, they show that this government will do anything to appease the extreme greens--the Bob Browns--in order to get preferences to stay in power. Thirdly, they show how out of balance this state and country have become in their priorities. Small minority groups with values very different from ordinary Queensland families have a disproportionate influence and have imposed their extreme green ideology on our laws. If the Anzacs and the diggers who died fighting for us on the beaches of Gallipoli and in the ranges of the Kokoda Track were ever able to come back to life today and experience our laws and modern values, I am sure they would fix bayonets and be charging the steps of this place.

Mr HORAN (Toowoomba South--LNP) (2.33 pm): The Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill is an important bill in that it addresses four particular problems that are occurring and have been occurring for some time with prostitution. By supporting some of these provisions--which act against the illegal operation of brothels but which provide protection for single operators, which provide bigger penalties for those who use under-age people for prostitution and which provide for non-sexual advertising of escorts--in no way are we supporting the increase of prostitution. Rather, we see this as a way of stopping some of the more unsavoury aspects--much of it is unsavoury--or some of the worst aspects of prostitution.

In Queensland, the more recent history of prostitution has been that the Goss government decriminalised single sex-operators in the early 1990s and then the Beattie government brought about the introduction of legalised brothels during its term. At that stage we opposed that legislation vehemently. I remember speaking on that bill and saying something to the effect that it brought about increased opportunities for prostitution. It meant that in Queensland there would be decriminalised single operators, legalised brothels and a continuance of illegal brothels.

One of the main reasons we have this legislation before us today is that criminal operators have been able to find ways around having to operate as legal brothels and have continued to run illegal brothels. You only have to pick up newspapers to see the expansion of prostitution in its various forms--be it single operators, be it pseudo operations through escort operations or be it legalised brothels. The operation of brothels and prostitutes, through decriminalisation of single operators and the legalising of brothels, has brought about an ever-expanding increase in this trade.

I admire the courage and the strength of those people who fight to oppose the trafficking and the use of women in brothels and in prostitution--people who genuinely believe in the sanctity of women and who want to see young women in particular have every opportunity to have a good life without being forced, coerced or attracted to the trade of prostitution and all the unsavoury problems that it brings to them not only during their life of prostitution but for many, many years afterwards.

This legislation specifically looks at the issue of illegal operation of brothels. In the past they have been fined $2,000, and that has been compared to the $30,000 cost of a licence to operate a legal brothel. Therefore, it has become attractive to many people to operate illegal brothels, perhaps simply by bringing together an association or a group of prostitutes. The only problem they face is if they get caught--and it is a big ‘if’--and they are fined $2,000. That fine compares very favourably with the $30,000 cost of a licence to operate a legal brothel, let alone the requirement to pass various tests to operate a legal brothel.

That aspect in itself should bring about a greater strength in trying to stamp out the operation of illegal brothels. But we do not believe that the fine that is proposed in this legislation is anywhere near strong enough to act as a deterrent. I look forward to the comments that our shadow minister will make when he brings forward amendments to increase this fine. The operation of illegal brothels, and thereby the unsavoury use of young girls being trapped in illegal brothels, could be possibly stamped out or greatly reduced if the government were prepared to accept the amendments that will be put forward by our shadow minister.

Part of the baggage of the illegal operation of brothels is the dreadful business of trafficking young girls. We in Queensland tend to think that that is just a problem that occurs overseas in places in eastern Europe or in parts of Asia where young girls are trapped, trafficked and shipped from one country to another. When one reads some of the information that has been brought together by the academics that the member for Buderim spoke about, it becomes quite obvious that there is something going on in establishing these illegal operations.

Even here in Queensland--and we think of ourselves as part of the great nation Australia--there is this issue of trafficking. How many young girls are enticed to our state and then trapped in a system of prostitution, whether it be through the promise of work, visas or so forth? Of course it is the illegal brothel operators who are the perpetrators of this. The trafficking of young women is one of the worst trades in the world.

In Toowoomba we have had some people who have fought very strongly against this. They have had a lot of courage doing that. Some women in the Zonta Club in Toowoomba have felt that this is something that they should put their energy into. They have endeavoured to expose this to the rest of the world. It is probably one of the best things they could do for young women.

This legislation also looks at what is called protection of the sole operator. I have heard some people say that this means that there will not be pimps. But pimps are people who live off the profits or the money that is earned by prostitutes. We cannot really describe these protectors in any other way.

This legislation allows sole operators to have a driver, a security officer or a bouncer and a message taker or phone operator. When talking about illegal brothels, the use of young women and the problems that occur with prostitution, we only have to think of these poor young woman endeavouring to pay the wages of those three people--the driver, the security officer or bouncer and the phone operator or message taker--to realise the number of clients they would have to entertain in order to pay those wages, let alone make the money they desire to make. I think this demonstrates what a sordid trade this is and the effects it can have upon young women in particular.

This legislation allows for harsher penalties--and we support this--for the coercion of under-age young girls into the trade of prostitution. Whether the penalty is sufficient to stop this trade is a matter that I am sure we will address later on in the consideration in detail stage of the bill. The legislation also tightens the advertising arrangements for escorts and escort agencies so that escort agencies cannot be used as a front for prostitution. Whether or not that works is another issue. At least there are attempts within this legislation to address these issues.

I know that later on our shadow minister will be moving some amendments to this bill. One relates to the penalty for the operation of illegal brothels. I believe that the penalty for operating illegal brothels has to be such that it absolutely stamps this practice out and no consideration is given to running an illegal brothel. The penalty if caught should just about wipe them out and put them out of business.

Associated with that will have to be a real desire by the government to ensure that all these matters are properly investigated. I hope the police officers know that whilst these investigations can be difficult and they are busy with other functions the penalty that would apply, if our amendment was accepted by the House, would certainly make their investigation worthwhile and would wipe out some of these criminal types who are running these illegal brothels and taking advantage of so many young women and, as I said earlier, possibly even involved in the trafficking of young women, particularly from countries like Asia.

The other issue that we will address in our amendments to be moved to this bill, which I would like to speak to generally, is the existing rule within the legislation that when an application is made by somebody to put a brothel in a particular city or town those cities or towns with populations of 25,000 or under can veto the application. That means that cities like Toowoomba which have a population over 25,000 do not have the same right as those with a population of under 25,000.

This issue has surfaced in our city when there was an application for a brothel. There was a major public rally prior to that application being accepted by the state government. This is an issue that the people of Toowoomba feel strongly about. They feel strongly about it from a moral point of view. They also feel very strongly about it because of the dehumanising of the young women who work in brothels approved by the government.

The people of Toowoomba, like I guess people in many other cities, feel that it is an issue that they would like decided by their elected local members, not by bureaucrats based in a government agency in Brisbane. They feel it is important for their city that they are able to stand up and have decisions made by their local leaders about young women being involved or having the opportunity to work in brothels. In the interests of those young women, they would like to see local people make the decision. They believe that that would mean that locally the decision would be no and they would not have a brothel forced upon the community against the overwhelming wishes of the people of that city.

Quite rightly, they know that the expansion of the brothel industry means an expansion in the number of men or boys who would be attracted to use those facilities. They see that as bad for the overall morality of the city and community and a further lessening of standards. We see all the time a lessening of standards. People talk about, worry about and say that this lessening of standards is leading to more crime and more problems and what do we do about it. Here is an opportunity to do something about it and maintain some standards rather than having this laissez-faire attitude of letting standards slip further.

The other very important issue--and this was brought up at that major rally in Toowoomba--is the opinion that is voiced by women who are involved in caring for young women who have fallen into difficulties and have very serious problems with drugs, domestic violence, prostitution and so forth. These are the social workers of the city who provide housing for young families in distress. These are the social workers who counsel young women who have been involved in drugs, alcohol and abuse. These are the social workers who provide care seven days a week, 24 hours a day and opportunities for young women to be taken in.

These are the social workers who see the results of prostitution after talking to young girls who have gone away to the city and tried prostitution. These people have seen the devastating effects it has had upon their immediate life and they have seen the devastating effects it has had upon their future life. For that reason, those people worked hard at this rally to put in place that rule relating to towns with 25,000 people. Whilst the government has brought in legalised brothels, at least if this regulation was in place it would give local people and local leaders the opportunity to respect the very deeply held beliefs of people, to respect the standards of our city and to respect the dangers and try to prevent the dangers that prostitution and all that is associated with it can bring to the lives of young women. These amendments are very important and I ask the House, when they are moved by our shadow minister, to give them very serious consideration, because it will make our state a slightly better place if we are able to accept them.

In conclusion, whilst issues in this bill bring about a tightening of those four major areas that I have spoken about, that does not in any way mean that we on this side of the House support the expansion of prostitution. We certainly hope that these changes will bring about a reduction in prostitution and those things associated with it in terms of the harm that it does to young women and society.

Hon. NS ROBERTS (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (2.51 pm), in reply: Firstly, I thank all members from both sides of the House for their contributions to this debate. As I outlined in my second reading speech and indeed as many speakers have indicated, this bill endeavours to strike an appropriate balance between the need for strict regulation of the prostitution industry and also the need to address the social factors, and members have spoken about many of those issues in this debate. The main objective is to deter the involvement of organised crime in illegal prostitution activities and also to enhance the health and safety of those people who choose to work within this industry, however distasteful some people may find it.

The bill sends a very clear message to operators masquerading as social escort agencies. This debate has clearly identified that as a major area of concern, and that is why the bill contains some specific measures to address the illegal prostitution activities of that sector. The Criminal Code already contains a number of offences dealing with prostitution. In terms of the operating of the business of prostitution, those offences primarily target illegal brothels operating at a specific place. That has presented some difficulties in terms of enforcement, and that is why the new offence of carrying on the business of prostitution has been introduced with a significant penalty of up to seven years imprisonment. For example, one of the problems identified that businesses that masquerade as a social escort agency often rent office space to undertake activities other than the provision of prostitution, with the prostitution actually provided or delivered elsewhere, limiting the ability of police to target and prosecute people in that sector. This bill gives police the powers to specifically target that type of operation and indeed illegal prostitution providers wherever they operate and under whatever guise they operate. Illegal operators risk being jailed for up to seven years and having their assets seized, and I note some comments about the level of penalties and will make further comment about that shortly.

In its 2006 review, the CMC found that the regulated industry of legal brothels did provide a viable alternative to dangerous illegal brothels. I take the opportunity to correct the record of my second reading speech and indicate that this bill in fact implements 14 of the 23 recommendations made by the CMC. The remaining nine CMC recommendations have already been addressed through non-legislative processes, meaning that the passing of this bill today will complete the government’s response to all of the CMC recommendations from that report.

The bill makes it an offence for social escort agencies to employ minors and also for a person to obtain sexual services from a 16- and 17-year-old sole operator prostitute. That is an issue which a number of members have made comment on, and I will refer to that again later as well. The bill in particular regulates the advertising of social escorts and social escort services, and that issue has been canvassed widely. It will restrict the manner in which social escort providers advertise and create offences if they carry on the business of illegal prostitution. The bill also ensures that social escort providers comply with the same advertising restrictions as legal prostitution providers, and again that was an issue canvassed by many members. The bill also provides enhanced safety for legal sole operator prostitutes when attending outcalls by allowing the employment of a driver or a bodyguard and allowing a person to take an advisory message for a sole operator.

I now turn to making some specific comments on issues raised by a number of members. In terms of the extent of the illegal industry, the members for Gregory, Aspley, Burdekin, Mudgeeraba, Gaven, Nanango and indeed others spoke about the extent of the illegal industry in Queensland, citing figures of around 90 per cent of the industry not being carried out in legal brothels, and that may in fact be the case. The members for Aspley and Currumbin cited a CMC report which identified that 75 per cent of sexual services are provided by outcalls, mostly illegally. The key message of this bill is that a great deal of illegal prostitution offered particularly through escort agencies is a matter which is addressed through the provisions which regulate the advertising and other measures. Those statistics do not reveal or highlight, however, the number of sole operators. So I think it is not quite correct to suggest that 90 per cent or indeed figures anywhere near that of prostitution activity in Queensland is indeed illegal. There is certainly a significant proportion, but I do not know whether there is any evidence to suggest that it is as high as what some people are claiming. The bill, as I have indicated, proposes strict and effective regulation on the advertising of escort providers which, on the evidence, are significant providers of prostitution services. Following the passage of this bill, those operators will find themselves on the wrong side of the law if they continue to operate in the way in which it is quite evident many are.

With respect to local government input into brothel approval processes, again the members for Gregory, Aspley, Gladstone and Toowoomba South raised the issue of the power of councils to veto brothel applications. The current act of course does provide a provision where local government areas or towns with a population of less than 25,000 can apply for exempt status, and indeed, as the list of local government areas shows, that is quite extensive. I will be providing some response to that proposed amendment, but I would just say that if the amendment was passed it would in effect basically undermine the entire foundation of the legal industry in Queensland.

I am sure that there are many communities both within large cities and indeed in smaller communities that do not wish to have a brothel in their midst. I can understand that, but the government went through a very extensive consultation process a decade ago and determined that it was in the public interest to regulate the prostitution industry and simply allowing a blanket provision for any local authority to undermine that fundamental policy objective is something which cannot be supported, and I will say more about that when the member moves his amendment.

The member for Currumbin and others referred to the ability of a sole operator to employ a driver or a bodyguard. She raised the fact that the head of a security firm could act as a pimp to delegate, for example, 25 crowd controllers or bodyguards to look after 25 prostitutes. On the face of it, that type of activity would clearly indicate a collaborative effort between those individuals which would be illegal under the laws that exist and also the proposed amendments to the act.

Members--particularly the member for Currumbin--raised the issue of a recommendation of the CMC review regarding protocols developed between the Commonwealth and the state that allow for action to be taken against people using the telecommunications network for unlawful purposes such as prostitution. I can advise the House that those protocols are in place and that the police are already using those powers now under those protocols to, in effect, disconnect or disable telecommunication services where illegal brothel or prostitution activities have been mentioned.

The member for Currumbin also raised the Project Axis report. Project Axis was an investigation into child prostitution and organised crime and its report was published in 2000 by the former Queensland Crime Commission prior to its merger with the former Criminal Justice Commission in 2002. For the member’s information, I point out that that report is on the CMC website. All four volumes are there and are, in fact, available for anyone to access. They are public documents. The Project Axis reports are now 10 years old and, although they are useful in some respects for historical research, to some degree they have been supplanted by the CMC’s own reviews into prostitution in 2004, 2005 and 2006--the latter report being the foundation report that underpins many of the amendments in this bill.

A number of members raised the issue of prostitution and links to human trafficking--the members for Maryborough, Burnett and Toowoomba South in their contributions today and a number of other members previously--and quoted from a University of Queensland research report into prostitution and human trafficking. I think it is fair to say that all members of this House would support the fact that trafficking of young women and children in particular is a heinous crime, is abhorrent and is something no society should tolerate. However, the same report that members quoted from also found that there was no firm evidence that such crimes are rampant or rife within Queensland.

I think it would be fair to say that no-one could deny that there may well be some people who arrive on tourist visas or student visas and who may engage in prostitution activity illegally. Those people are putting themselves at high risk. If they are students here to attend courses, they are not only potentially ruining their careers but also committing criminal offences. A number of members have raised this as a significant issue and I recognise that they would be concerned about it, but I would simply say that the police advice to me is that, although it is recognised as a serious issue, there is no evidence of an endemic problem. But if members or people in their communities have evidence, I invite them to provide that to the police so that it can be pursued and prosecuted because, as we have all said and acknowledged in this place, this is an abhorrent activity that needs to be stamped out wherever it might be existing.

I will turn quickly to a few of the comments that were made today. The member for Toowoomba South--and indeed other members on the opposition benches--recognised at least that this bill goes some way towards addressing the issue of illegality in the prostitution industry and stamping out some of the worst aspects. There is obviously an illegal industry out there and there are probably some abhorrent practices taking place. No-one denies that. This bill and the recognition of the government that this sector requires regulation is a significant step forward in ensuring that we support the legal industry as much as possible and that we do as much as we humanly can to stamp out the illegal industry and all of the nasty elements and nasty aspects of it.

The member for Toowoomba South raised criticism of the $2,000 fine. The member for Buderim and the member for Kawana raised similar issues. On that issue I simply say that this bill provides the courts with the option to impose penalties of up to three years, five years or seven years imprisonment. The bill also introduces a new offence of carrying on the business of prostitution, with a penalty of up to seven years imprisonment. Although each of us may have a particular criticism of an offence against this act or indeed the penalties handed down in any case, we live in a state where we respect and uphold the right of the courts to make determinations on the appropriate penalty based on all the facts and the circumstances of the case. So whereas at face value a fine of $2,000 in light of a $30,000 fee to register or license a brothel may appear to be out of kilter, you would not only need to look at the particular offence that was prosecuted but also bear in mind that the courts have the option of imposing very severe penalties for illegal prostitution activities. Indeed, through this bill we are providing the police with stronger tools and opportunities to prosecute illegal operators and there are penalties of up to seven years imprisonment involved in that as well.

The member for Buderim also talked about the 10 per cent of brothels operating legally in Queensland. I think I have addressed that issue. He also talked about people trafficking. The member for Burnett--and I acknowledge and thank him--recognised that this bill does get the balance right, but he criticised the penalty for employment of a minor as a social escort. Certainly, in that regard this bill picks up the CMC recommendation to make it illegal to employ a minor. The penalty is framed in the context of an employment situation. Certainly, if in that context there are any sexual offences or other offences involved, the Criminal Code and other acts provide for much more severe penalties. So I hear what the member says, but I think in the context of the employment arrangement that we are talking about that is the penalty that has been deemed appropriate in this particular case.

I thank the government members--the members for Brisbane Central, Pumicestone, Kallangur, Toowoomba North, Springwood, Mundingburra, Bundamba and Keppel--for their contributions and for highlighting a number of the positive aspects of the bill. The key issues that they referred to were improving the safety and health of sole operators; the focus of the amendments to keep organised crime out of the industry; the tough sanctions against anyone using minors for the purpose of prostitution, either as an illegal operator or as a client; the sanction for those carrying out the illegal business of prostitution--the new offence that I have mentioned; the regulation of the escort industry, particularly focusing on regulating the advertising regime that they are entitled to pursue; prohibiting minors working as social escorts, which I have talked about; and also the certificate-of-discharge provisions to assist police in prosecutions. Again, that is an important element where clients, or indeed prostitutes or people working in illegal brothels, can receive a certificate of discharge on the basis of providing evidence that can lead to a prosecution.

In closing, I would like to comment that the member for Gaven raised the claim--and I was quite surprised at his claim, actually--that Queensland is moving quickly towards ‘a clandestine era of prostitution ... before legalised brothels’ as if we are moving back to the dark old days which occurred when the party to which he belongs was in power. For those who need reminding I point out that, prior to the regulation of prostitution, under the former National Party government the illegal prostitution industry was rife. They were the days of Premiers being bribed and criminals paying hush money so that they could continue to ply their filthy business. Thankfully, this government has had the courage to step into an arena which many people in the community find quite offensive--and I can understand that from a personal point of view. But a policy decision was taken. It was the right decision: to clean up an industry as much as humanly possible and to put in place a legal framework to ensure we keep the crooks out of the legal industry--we certainly have an illegal industry that needs prosecution--and to seek to improve the health and safety of those participating in it.

I note again that the member for Gladstone has put her personal views on the table in relation to this issue and I respect that. The member for Toowoomba South mentioned the strong reaction to the establishment of a brothel in Toowoomba. I met with a number of women involved in that. I have a great deal of respect for those women. They have strongly held beliefs and they prosecuted their case very strongly. The fact remains that prostitution has been with us for centuries world-wide. It will never be stamped out. We will never rid ourselves entirely of the illegal industry, but with proper regulation and proper enforcement we can at least try to minimise and reduce the criminal element to make that industry as safe as we possibly can.

In conclusion, the bill does continue to strike an appropriate balance between the need for strict legislation to prevent organised crime and corruption from once again gaining a foothold within this industry and, importantly, addressing the social factors arising from prostitution. With those few words, I commend the bill to the House.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Resolved in the affirmative under standing order 108.
Clauses 1 and 2, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr JOHNSON
(3.16 pm): I move the following amendment and table the explanatory notes to my amendment--
