Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: ‘3A Amendment of s 64 (When assessment manager must refuse application)

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: ‘(c) the local government for the local government area has required that all applications within the area be refused; or’.’.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes for Mr Johnson’s amendments to the Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill [ 2755 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: This amendment is important from the opposition’s perspective as it seeks to give local governments of all sizes the final say in development applications for brothels within their relevant jurisdictions. This amendment will mean that the assessment manager must refuse an application when the local government for a local government area has required that all applications within the area be refused under current legislation. Towns with a population of less than 25,000 people are currently not permitted to have a say in such applications and they must have agreements with the minister. The proposed amendments will remove the provision that requires further agreement from the minister when local councils require that all applications be refused.

In his summary the minister made reference to what can be called the ‘Toowoomba clause’ or the ‘population of 25,000’ clause. It is about giving the people who represent these local authorities a say in precisely what they want for their city. Whilst none of us likes prostitution and brothels in our neighbourhood, I think it is only fair that these smaller cities be given the opportunity to have their say in relation to dictating their own agenda. After all, we live in a democratic society. It is the right of the people to have a say in what they want in their communities. As the minister said, this activity has been going on for thousands of years and it is impossible to stamp it out. At the same time, the opposition believes that it is the right of local councils to have a say and not be overridden by the government of the day.

This is something that local communities should be given the opportunity to determine. In some of those smaller cities it will be difficult to have these establishments placed where they are not near schools, churches, playgrounds or where children are participating in family activities, but placed near commercial type operations. At the end of the day, it is giving a say to the inhabitants of the city in question. This is about the democratic process being allowed to work and community members being allowed to have their say and, at the end of the day, representing the desires of the people in question.

I urge all members and the minister to think about this. This is sacrosanct to some of those communities. They believe very strongly in it. As the member for Toowoomba South said, he has met with many groups in his community. I know the community of Toowoomba pretty well. I know the community groups in many other cities very well, too. It is a different situation in larger centres like Brisbane, the Gold and Sunshine coasts and maybe Townsville, Cairns and those larger provincial cities.
Mr Stevens: Rockhampton.
Mr JOHNSON: And Rockhampton, as the honourable member for Mermaid Beach has just said.
Mr Shine: Toowoomba is larger than Rockhampton.

Mr JOHNSON: I know it is. I take the interjection from the honourable member for Toowoomba North and I respect what he is saying. However, the point I make is that a great majority of people in these smaller cities are going to be denied the opportunity to say no. Where the population is close to the demarcation of 25,000, those local authorities should be given the opportunity to say, ‘No, we don’t want this type of operation in our city.’ I think it is only fair that we allow them to exercise their democratic right to say no to this type of activity.

I appeal to the minister and the government to show understanding and fairness in support of this amendment moved by the opposition because it recognises the ongoing needs and the growth of these cities. A lot of them are young cities; they are cities where there are a lot of young people and young families and, therefore, schools. They are places where I believe we should be trying to promote a culture of liveability; they are great places for families and old people, great places for recreation and great places to live. While we do not want to burden the larger cities, at the end of the day we do not need to put in place an impediment or a scourge on these places because of a demarcation figure.

I appeal to the minister to give a lot of thought to this very meritorious amendment. It is one that I believe he will be rewarded for if he can show the people of these larger and smaller provincial cities that no is going to be the answer to placing brothels in those communities.

Mr HORAN: I would like to support our shadow minister in this particular amendment. He has referred to it as being the ‘Toowoomba amendment’. The fact is that the people of Toowoomba had the courage to stand up and to attend in their hundreds a rally to fight against the imposition of a brothel on our city because they believed it was not the right thing for the city. Their right to make a decision on whether it was imposed on our city under the various planning arrangements was taken away from them because of this regulation pertaining to a population of 25,000. It was imposed upon them through a bureaucratic agency of the government. There was no say for the local people. Someone sitting down here in Brisbane said, ‘Yes, you will have it because it fits particular planning guidelines.’ The adjudication on the planning and the desirability or otherwise of a brothel proposed for a city the size of Toowoomba was taken away from the people and the elected local members, who know and understand their city, and was placed in the hands of a bureaucrat in Brisbane who is following the particular guidelines set by the government.

With amalgamation of councils, of course, the population of council areas is now even higher. No doubt many other smaller cities in Queensland will now be subject to this rule because the population governed by their council may be over 25,000. Pre-amalgamation, the population of Toowoomba was roughly between 92,000 and 94,000. Now, with the eight shires combined, it has around 160,000 people. Other areas of the state may well have had a population of around 20,000 or 25,000. As a result of amalgamation, they will find that they also no longer have a say.

This is a matter of local people having a right to set certain standards in their own community. Yes, decisions on matters to do with legal brothels are difficult. As the minister and many other people have said, prostitution is one of the oldest professions in the world, but that does not mean it is right. We hear all the time that standards are slipping. The job is getting tougher and tougher for the police. We recently had a case in which police officers arrested someone at an event for using offensive language against them and the case was thrown out of court. The standards in our society are slipping and it is worrying parents and many other people, whether it is on TV, in publications or with the way people dress. Young people who are vulnerable can quite easily do the wrong thing because the overall standards of our community have slipped.

That was one of the major reasons the people of Toowoomba in large numbers objected to the imposition of a brothel on our city. One of the other important reasons was that, through their practical experience of working with youth, young women and families, people in our city know the dreadful results of prostitution--the immediate results of prostitution on young women and young girls and the long-lasting effects of prostitution on the lives of young women. They know of all the fringe elements that surround prostitution and they have been there, as they say, from time immemorial: drugs, violence, pimps and other people living off the earnings of prostitutes. We have seen it even in this legislation where, for their own protection, this legislation allows single operators to have a driver, a phone operator and a bouncer. Those poor young women have to entertain so many more clients a day just to pay the wages of those three professionals they are employing. That really shows how bad this industry is.

The people of Toowoomba, particularly the women social workers who deal in crisis accommodation and who deal with young women in difficult, unfortunate and disastrous circumstances, really believe that for the protection of young women, first and foremost, the local government--the people who are elected as leaders, who are in touch with the issues and the people in their community--needs to be able to say, ‘No, not in our community.’ That is what this is about: empowering people to say yes or no, not leaving this decision, which is an important decision for our local community, to bureaucrats in Brisbane doing the government agency’s bidding.

Mr ROBERTS: The government will be opposing the amendment. Basically, it is based on a false premise. Obviously, I do not take away the concession that the government has given to communities of 25,000 or less to have that veto power. Indeed, I am advised that currently there are 204 such communities throughout Queensland. The amendment is based on the false premise that prostitution or brothels do not exist in many of those communities. Currently under section 64(1)(c) of the act, that concession is available to towns with a population of less than 25,000. If the opposition’s amendment was passed, basically the entire foundation of the act would be subverted. All of the consultation and all of the policy rationale for establishing the regulation of the prostitution industry in Queensland would disintegrate. Principally, that is the reason the amendment is being opposed.

In addition to that, it subverts the social objectives of the act where legal brothels are going to be in existence. The legislation ensures the sexual health of the community through mandating safe sex practices in those areas where brothels are established. The current legislation ensures the safety of sex workers in licensed brothels. It protects sex workers from exploitation and requires brothels to have acceptable workplace conditions and, also, heavily focuses on preventing official corruption and the involvement of organised crime. In my view, taking away that policy foundation--and, in fact, I am sure that many communities would pressure their councils into taking those decisions--would facilitate the expansion of the illegal industry. The current act and, indeed, the provisions in this bill provide a more powerful platform for police and the legal industry to survive. In my view anything that takes away an opportunity to establish a legal brothel in a community potentially will facilitate the expansion of the illegal industry within that particular community. On that basis, the government will oppose the amendment.

Mr JOHNSON: I am disappointed in the minister’s response. Again I ask the minister to reconsider. I heard what he said in relation to this. He talks about the expansion of illegal brothels. We can take Toowoomba, Bundaberg or any other regional city as an example. The fact is that the police are already overtaxed in their pursuit of illegal vice and illegal activities in all parts of Queensland, not just on the Sunshine and Gold coasts or in the greater Brisbane area. We will see an influx of criminal activity in some of the centres if the councils are denied the right to exercise their democratic right to represent their people. I do not take lightly what the people of Toowoomba have said. We can talk to people in many other areas of the state and they will all make the same argument. I think it is a fair argument and those people should be heard at this time.

While there is no doubt that the minister has made up his mind and has outlined his argument for not supporting the opposition amendment, this issue will not go away. This issue is destroying the lives of many young women in our great state. It is a scourge on the lives of women. It is a denigration of their rights. They are being exploited by men who take advantage of them. Certainly we do not condone that behaviour and I do not think anybody in this House condones that behaviour. It is absolutely paramount that respect is shown to women. My point is that we have to look carefully at what the police are saying and work closely with them to protect the rights of local governments to represent the people and reflect what they are saying, as has been described not only by the member for Toowoomba South but also by other members of the House who have talked about other areas of Queensland.

If the minister is not going to support our amendment, it is important that he looks very closely at how we can arrive at a demarcation number. We need to be able to say, ‘Yes, brothels can go in here,’ or, ‘No, they cannot.’ I am not talking from a religious or family perspective. We have to give credit to what the community is saying. The local people who make decisions in their communities have to be given a say, because they act on behalf of the majority of people. I do not take lightly what is said by the people who attend meetings. They are leaders in their communities, they command respect in their communities and they have families themselves. They know exactly what this element will bring to their communities.

I appeal to the minister: if he is not going to support the amendment before the House this afternoon, can he consider allowing for an amendment to be made in the future that will give security to cities by increasing the number? We do not all welcome this activity; we do not all think that it is a great thing. I certainly do not and I am sure the minister does not. I agree with what he says, but I do not agree that rights should be taken away from the relevant councils. I hope that the minister is able to revisit this issue and give the House an assurance that in time we can give some guarantee to larger councils that they will have a say in how they operate and how they manage their affairs, especially when it comes to the social needs of their cities, in conjunction with the laws that are made in this legislature.

Mr HORAN: In his previous response, the minister spoke about a couple of matters. He said that prostitution exists. Prostitution may exist, but we are talking about the desire of the people of a city to determine, through their leaders, whether or not prostitution is expanded in their city. There is no doubt that, with increasing levels of legalised prostitution in Queensland--that is, the single operators and then the legalised brothels--prostitution generally has increased because it is more available, it is more advertised and it is more open, simply because it is legalised. That is what is concerning local people. They are concerned for the young men of their communities. However, mostly they are concerned for the young women of their communities. Their first and foremost concern is for their young women and the overall moral standards of their cities.

Throwing in the white towel and saying ‘prostitution exists’ is no reason for the people of Toowoomba having a brothel forced upon them through a decision made by an agency based in Brisbane. The decision should be made by people who are in tune with and close to the various groups in the city. Those decisions will be always hard and difficult, but local leaders should be the ones to make the decision, based on what they think is best for their community. Most of our civic leaders do not believe that it is right to broaden legalised prostitution and make it more available. It provides an increased opportunity for the lives of young women to be harmed via prostitution. It is wrong that young women, who falsely think that it is an easy way to make a quid, can be dragged into the profession of prostitution, with all the lifelong problems that it will cause them. The decision should be made locally and not by a bureaucrat in Brisbane.

The minister spoke about the need for brothels to provide better health standards et cetera for prostitutes. That may be so, but it will happen only to a limited degree because three-monthly health checks are not enough. A lot can happen in three months. It is pulling a bit of wool over your eyes to say that the health problems associated with prostitution will be covered by the fact that legalised brothels are required to provide for three-monthly health checks.

The minister said that he believed that if there was not a legal brothel in a city with a population of over 25,000 there would be more illegal operations. The legislation before us today is about providing sufficient penalties so that we can endeavour to stamp out illegal operations. It has never been possible to stamp out all crime, but if we have adequate investigation and adequate penalties, and those penalties are enforced by the judicial system, we will all but wipe out the incentives to run illegal brothels.

I think all of those arguments that the minister has put forward can be shown to be incorrect. On balance, isn’t it better to go with what people of a community want and genuinely believe rather than force something on them? You could ask, ‘Is this a bit selfish of some cities to say that they do not want to have brothels and that they might end up in the capital city or somewhere with a larger population?’ But that decision would be with the local leadership of those cities.

I am standing up for my city and the people in my city who did not want a brothel in the town and who wanted their local leadership to have the right to say yes or no, not to have that right taken away from them. I think it is one of the most basic things that we in this parliament can do. It is a precious right and it should be left with the people who love their city, who believe in their city, who do not want to see the young girls of their city trashed. They should have the right to say no and that right was taken away from them. If this parliament were to support this amendment put forward by our shadow minister, we would give some proper dignity and some proper standards to the local leadership of our state so they can do what they think is the best thing for the people in their cities.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I rise to support this amendment. I remember when the consultation occurred in Gladstone. It was at the city theatre. The minister for police at the time was either Paul Braddy or Tony McGrady--I am not sure which one. He came with a party of people to conduct the consultation. Certainly the overwhelming majority of the group in Gladstone were not in favour of prostitution being legalised. None of those people pretends that prostitution does not exist. Neither do I. It is well known. It has been in existence for a long time. But that does not make it right. What many people want is the opportunity to have a say in their own electorate.

My recollection is that the choice of 25,000 people as the threshold for a council to lose the right to have a say on whether or not a brothel was approved was an arbitrary figure. I cannot recall the basis for the 25,000 people. My understanding was that it was a fairly arbitrary figure, being a city of medium size, that was decided on. However, it does not in any way indicate that there are many in those communities, those bigger towns and cities, who really do not want legal prostitution. They do not want brothels in their region. Local councils are planning approvers in many other instances. It appears anomalous that they do not have a greater power in relation to the approval or disapproval of this use of a property.

In my speech during the second reading debate I made no secret of my opposition to prostitution. There are many in the community who do not want the abuse of young men and women to be validated. On that basis I support the amendment that gives local authorities an inherent right to make comment and to be involved in the approval process or the non-approval process of legal brothels.

Mr ROBERTS: I reiterate the government’s opposition to the amendment. It is a government view that the objectives of the act are best served by leaving the current veto power in local government areas with towns of 25,000 or less intact.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the member for Gregory’s amendment be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 37--Bates, Bleijie, Crandon, Cripps, Cunningham, Davis, Dempsey, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Flegg, Foley, Hobbs, Hopper, Johnson, Knuth, Langbroek, McArdle, McLindon, Malone, Menkens, Messenger, Nicholls, Powell, Pratt, Rickuss, Robinson, Seeney, Simpson, Springborg, Stevens, Stuckey, Wellington. NOES, 48--Attwood, Bligh, Boyle, Choi, Croft, Darling, Dick, Farmer, Finn, Fraser, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hoolihan, Jarratt, Johnstone, Jones, Kiernan, Lawlor, Male, Miller, Moorhead, Mulherin, Nelson-Carr, Nolan, O’Brien, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Reeves, Roberts, Robertson, Ryan, Schwarten, Scott, Shine, Smith, Spence, Stone, Struthers, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wells, Wendt, Wettenhall, Wilson. Tellers: Keech, Pitt
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 4 to 14, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr ROBERTS
(3.51 pm): I move the following amendments--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: ‘229FA Obtaining prostitution from person who is not an adult

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘(2) If the person who provides the prostitution is under 16 years, the offender is liable to a maximum penalty of 14 years imprisonment.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: I table the explanatory notes to my amendments.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes for the Hon. Roberts’s amendments to the Prostitution and Other Acts Amendment Bill [ 2756 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr ROBERTS (3.51 pm): I move the following amendment--

Mr JOHNSON
(3.52 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘(2A) If the court imposes a fine in addition to, or instead of, imprisonment for an offence against this section, the fine must not be less than 1000 penalty units for a single offence.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: The opposition believes that this is a very serious amendment. It seeks to act as a deterrent by setting a fine of not less than 1,000 penalty units for the offence of carrying on the business of providing unlawful prostitution. Where a court imposes a monetary penalty, we are proposing that the minimum that it can impose is 1,000 penalty units. The court is not prohibited from using other penalties as defined within the Penalties and Sentences Act 1992.

We have deliberated over this clause for some time. I say in defence of our moving this amendment that the minister said earlier that there are terms of imprisonment imposed in this clause but our proposed amendment will make it even tougher or provide an impediment to people breaching the provisions relating to the illegal operation of prostitution. Whilst there is a penalty of 14 years imprisonment in the bill, we believe that a penalty of 1,000 penalty units would be an absolute deterrent if it were imposed by the courts.

The minister said earlier today that this will give the police the power to impose tougher penalties when pursuing illegal prostitution. The police can only bring these people to the courts. It is then up to the courts to impose the penalties that will be a deterrent to undertaking this illegal activity. At the end of the day, if we are going to be realistic about making our penalties tougher and trying to stamp out this industry, we have to put checks and balances in place that will act as a deterrent to the criminal activity that many people highlighted in the chamber this afternoon and during the previous sitting week, when most of the debate of this legislation took place in the House.

The real issue is putting in place tough penalties that will send a message to that element of society that feeds off illegal prostitution. This would be a real deterrent if these people were brought before the courts. This is not something that we have dreamt up overnight; it is something that we believe is balanced and will give some strength to this particular clause in the legislation. Proposed clause 2A will give more muscle to this clause. It will certainly give the courts more muscle in imposing penalties on those people who want to violate the law as it stands.

I appeal to the minister and the government to endorse this amendment moved by the opposition today because it will certainly give strength to this aspect of the legislation. I believe that it will send a clear message that Queensland is going to be tough on this type of activity if the law is breached.

Mr ROBERTS: Again, the government will be opposing the amendment. This is one of those issues in relation to which the opposition is again seeking to impose a mandatory sentencing regime. The government firmly subscribes to the principle that the courts need to make decisions on the appropriate penalty based on the facts and circumstances of the case.

Throughout the second reading debate a number of members raised the example of a $2,000 fine compared to a $30,000 licence fee. We do not know the particular circumstances of that case. We do not know the severity of the alleged offence in that case.

The facts are that this bill provides penalties of up to three, five or seven years imprisonment for a number of offences. Through this bill we are introducing a new offence of carrying on the business of prostitution with a maximum penalty of seven years imprisonment. Through the advertising restrictions on escort agencies or escort service providers we are introducing financial penalties of 10 times the cost of either the advertisement or the website that advertises those particular services. The bill as it amends the act provides ample opportunity for the courts to impose appropriate penalties on individuals or groups of individuals involved in prostitution activity.

Mr HORAN: I support our shadow minister in moving this amendment. Whilst I understand that the minister has said that there is a range of penalties in the legislation, some of which include jail, what we are addressing here is the financial penalty that would be imposed. The previous penalty of $2,000 was obviously an insufficient deterrent to someone setting up an illegal brothel or an association of girls that they have working for them. They would probably be able to cover the $2,000 fine fairly easily.

What our shadow minister is attempting to do is make the financial component of the deterrent such that it is a true deterrent. The number of penalty points proposed means that the fine could be up to $100,000. That should virtually wipe somebody out from ever doing that again. More importantly, the penalty of up to $100,000 should act as a deterrent to people entering into illegal prostitution.

We support our police in the hard work and time it takes them in endeavouring to track down some of these operations. They would like to know that, at the end day, the deterrents through the justice system--they are firstly provided by the parliament in terms of the range of penalties and then applied by the court system--are there. That makes all of their investigations and hard work worthwhile and actually goes a long way towards eliminating this practice.

If the financial part of the deterrent is not adequate and does not have a wide enough range, then to the people who have been able to operate--and apparently, from all reports, have been operating in reasonable numbers and amounts--$2,000 is not a deterrent. It costs $30,000 for a licence for a year for a legal brothel. Many of those people may not comply or may have a police record of some sort which means that they would not be able to get a brothel licence. Therefore, those people are tempted to do it illegally and a $2,000 fine is certainly not a deterrent to them. For a deterrent to be serious and to work, it must not only impose the possibility of jail time that the minister mentioned but a fine or financial penalty. I am not sure whether it can be a mixture of both, but if it is going to be a financial penalty it has to be a serious one that actually works that is a real deterrent and puts the word around within that industry that if you get caught for this it wipes out a very serious amount of your financial assets for a long time and therefore it is not worthwhile contemplating setting up an illegal brothel.
Mr JOHNSON: Our amendment states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If the court imposes a fine in addition to, or instead of, imprisonment for an offence against this section, the fine must not be less than 1000 penalty units for a single offence.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I heard what the minister said in his response, but this is about deterrents. Subsection (1) of clause 17 states--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: 229HB Carrying on business of providing unlawful prostitution

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (1) A person who knowingly carries on the business providing unlawful prostitution commits a crime.

(2) However, if a person who is not an adult or is a person with an impairment of the mind is, to the offender’s knowledge, engaged in the provision of the prostitution, the offender is liable to a maximum penalty of 14 years imprisonment.
XML.Hansard-Body: For God’s sake, there are many people who do not get 14 years imprisonment for murder or rape or other heinous crimes. I wonder whether a court would impose that type of penalty today if these people were brought before the courts by the police. A deterrent such as this will make people think, ‘God, it’s 14 years jail and a $100,000 fine. We don’t want either of those.’ This is a measure towards trying to bring some sanity and some structure into this legislation so that it will be a deterrent to the criminal element who want to be a party to this. That is the main thrust of this legislation. Whilst we are trying to create an environment that will provide some of the unfortunate people who find themselves in this predicament with a safer workplace, it is also about sending a message to the criminal element who want to enter into or stand over or be the beneficiaries of this type of operation.

We did not just pick this figure out of the air. We thought this through very carefully in order to get a decent structure in place that will be a deterrent through the passage of this legislation. This is something which has merit and I hope that the minister sees that the objective we are trying to achieve is constructive and positive from the opposition’s perspective. There would be many people in everyday Queensland--in voter land Queensland--who would support this amendment and who would think that this is the right way to go. I appeal to the minister to give some credence to this amendment and support it. If we are going to be genuine in bringing about reforms in terms of being tough on this element out there giving our communities a hard time and giving our police a difficult time, this is the part of the legislation that can say that the message is clear and precise--that is, 14 years jail coupled with a $100,000 fine or the 1,000 penalty unit fine. I believe that that shows that we are fair dinkum and we are tough on this issue.

Mr ROBERTS: Just to respond generally and in a sense to repeat some of the things I have said, there are some circumstances obviously where it is appropriate to set a particular penalty. If you speed, it is pretty clear cut that you have broken the law in that you get a fixed penalty such as losing your licence and pay X amount of dollars. Here we are talking about instances where the facts and circumstances will differ according to each particular case. The severity of the intensity of someone’s involvement in the prostitution activity or the illegal activity will differ according to each individual case. The government stands by the principle that we are putting in place in this legislation and these amendments today have appropriate penalties for the various offences. It is then up to the court to determine, based on the facts and circumstances, what is an appropriate response in each circumstance. So we oppose the amendment.

Mr HORAN: This clause of the bill is all about endeavouring to stop illegal prostitution, and members on both sides of the House are quite genuine in wanting to stop illegal prostitution. There is probably more misuse of young women in illegal prostitution than in other forms of prostitution. With regard to the penalties, there is a mixture in the statutes of jail and fines. I think I would be correct in saying that very often the penalty is probably going to be only a financial penalty--that is, a fine. The minister has said that there are varying levels of intensity of illegal prostitution, and he may well be right. It might vary from someone who runs two or three prostitutes illegally to someone who runs 10, 15 or 20 prostitutes. We on this side of the House are saying that illegal prostitution is out and, whether it is two, three or 20 prostitutes, you will face a fine that will run you out of business. That is what this is about.

For some operators a $10,000 fine is probably quite affordable, but $100,000 will probably put most of them, if not all of them, out of business. That is what this House should be about today. We have seen some absolutely massive fines imposed in other areas of law such as environmental law with regard to the killing of various wildlife. Here we are talking about protecting young women from the illegal trade of prostitution through illegal brothels. It is a pretty serious matter. It is probably one of the most serious matters that we can discuss. The amount of money in terms of the fine that is being put forward in this amendment would act as a deterrent when $10,000 would not. I would ask the House and the minister to consider this. I think it has some merit if we are genuine and serious in wanting to say an absolute no to illegal brothels and illegal collectives of prostitutes run by someone who is living off the earnings of those poor unfortunate young women.

Mr JOHNSON: The member for Toowoomba South has just highlighted something very specific, very precise, and he has given an accurate assessment. We are talking about illegal operations. We are talking about a deterrent. If we are fair dinkum about cleaning this industry up, there is another aspect of this industry--that is, the health aspect. As the member for Toowoomba South said earlier in relation to the three-monthly checks, in many cases the three-monthly checks are a joke. If we are going to be tough on this whole operation, we have to be tough right across-the-board. That is exactly where the opposition is coming from. We know that we are not going to stamp it out. We know that it is out there. It has been going on for thousands of years, as the minister rightfully said. However, at the same time we have to protect the wider community and the people who live in that community to ensure that we can get some decency into this industry.

The fact of the matter is that that criminal activity exploits these unfortunate girls and it is the Mr Bigs who will fill their hands with the dollars in question. I believe that a $100,000 fine is going to be an absolute deterrent to some of these blokes, because they will not want to hand over 100,000 big ones. If the minister accepts this amendment moved by the opposition and this penalty becomes part of the legislation, I believe that it will send a clear message. I believe that the police will support it and I believe the wider community of Queensland will support it because, in reality, we are about trying to get some management back into the structure of this awful industry so that the element that is breaching the rules all the time can be brought to its knees and told, ‘Hand it over’ because the way it is now it will be virtually a slap on the wrist.

I find it hard to believe that these people could be subjected to a 14-year jail sentence or even a seven-year jail sentence. I would be interested to hear from the minister if that has ever happened. I doubt it. We know of the findings from the Fitzgerald inquiry in relation to trying to clean up this industry. This legislation is certainly an opportunity for us to be realistic in our approach and our direction. If we could have a bipartisan approach on trying to correct some of these issues, I think we could make Queensland a better place. I urge the minister to give consideration to supporting this amendment.

XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Property Agents and Motor Dealers and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 24 March (see p. 1055), on motion of Mr Lawlor--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr STEVENS (Mermaid Beach--LNP) (4.18 pm): I rise to speak to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 and, at the outset, I advise the House that the Liberal National Party will be voting for this bill as a practical step forward to tightening legal loopholes that exist in the current act.

The Property Agents and Motor Dealers and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 seeks to amend the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 and, in particular, makes specific amendments to chapter 11. The bill will amend chapter 11 of the PAMDA and make parallel amendments to the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997. The amendments will also simplify the process and reduce red tape for delivering contract and warning statement papers and eliminate loopholes available to buyers to opt out of contracts, thereby promoting greater certainty in residential property sale transactions.

Currently, chapter 11 requires a seller to deliver contract papers in a specific order. If this order is not followed, then that gives rise for the buyer to terminate the contract at any time before settlement. The buyer is bound by the contract only if the papers are signed in order, for example, a signed information statement provided by the seller, a signed warning statement and a signed contract. If that strict process is not adhered to, the contract will not legally bind the two parties. This bill aims to fix this loophole and create greater certainty in residential property sale contracts.

These amendments have been deemed necessary as a response to the Service Delivery and Performance Commission’s Report on the review of regulatory reform (phase 2)--Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 , which was presented back in March 2008. The Service Delivery and Performance Commission review of regulatory reform was to identify the major regulatory features of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act and to recommend legislative amendments to simplify the level of regulation while maintaining effective consumer benefit--in other words, protection.

The review looked at many areas of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act, including real estate agents, property developers, motor dealers, auctioneers, pastoral houses, codes of conduct, commercial agents, other issues and the presentation and delivery of residential real estate contracts, which is the focus of these amendments.
Real estate contracts were addressed in the report’s recommendation A4. The recommendation of the Service Delivery and Performance Commission states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Streamline the approach to the presentation and delivery of residential real estate contracts by:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • repealing Chapter 11--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: other than relevant definitions, sections 365A, 365B, 368 to 370 and Part 4
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • enacting provisions requiring the inclusion of an information statement in residential real estate contracts, of no more than one page in length, as prescribed under regulation
XML.Hansard-Body: The government’s response to the Service Delivery and Performance Commission Report on the review of regulatory reform (phase 2)--Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 supported the streamlining of the presentation and delivery of residential contracts but rejected repealing chapter 11 on the basis that it believes that it ‘contains important consumer information provisions which would be reduced if Chapter 11 was ... repealed’. It also believes that ‘there has been no measurable decrease in the volume of sales proceeding to settlement and it has improved the quality of contract documentation and preparation by real estate agents’.

I sincerely hope that the nondeletion of chapter 11 does not provide an opportunity for our erstwhile friends in the legal fraternity, of which the minister of course is one of the famous glowing examples, to exploit further loopholes. As they say, necessity is the mother of invention. I am sure there will be some genius legal eagle out there who will exploit these provisions in some shape or form later on, and I am sure we will be back in this House to make further amendments to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act.

In the PAMDA changes to chapter 11, ‘Residential property sales’, the following sections will be pertinent. I will set out the existing sections of the act that refer to residential contractual requirements. In section 365(1), parties are bound by the relevant contract when certain formalities are adhered to. In section 365(2)(a), when sent by fax the document must be in the following order: a cover page that draws the buyer’s attention to the warning statement and the contract; the warning statement; the relevant contract; and any other documents. In section 365(2)(b), when sent by electronic communication other than fax the communication must be presented in the following order: a message that directs the buyer’s attention to the warning statement and contract; a single document, consisting of the warning statement and the relevant contract, with the warning statement appearing as the first or top page of the document.

In adhering to the legislation as it stands, we are defining a process that is subject to physical human error rather than concentrating on the written content of the contract. What relevance does the order of documentation received by electronic conveyance have to the validity and, most importantly, the intention of the written contract? In section 365(2)(c), when being handed documents or receiving documents in ways other than by electronic communication, for example by post, the documents must be in the following order: the warning statement and the relevant contract. The seller must direct the buyer’s attention to the warning statement and then the relevant contract.

Section 367, ‘Buyer’s rights if a warning statement is not given or is not effective’, applies if a warning statement requirement is not adhered to. The buyer may terminate the relevant contract up until the contract settles by giving notice of termination to the seller. If the contract is terminated, the seller must refund any deposit paid within 14 days after notice of termination is given. Therefore, the expected changes will be to eradicate the opportunity for buyers to terminate the contract for a simple error on the seller’s behalf. The seller will no longer be vulnerable to contract terminations if he, she or the agent mixes up the pages in a contract or forgets to attach a warning statement before forwarding the contract in an email.

When the sale of units is added, the requirements of the Body Corporate and Community Management Act come into force--that is, the BCCM Act disclosure statement and information sheet, which is form 14 under the BCCM Act. The bill makes parallel amendments to the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997.

The global financial crisis has had a major impact on the residential and commercial property markets across the globe, and Queensland has not been immune. We have seen the development of the least affordable housing market in the world, and this has had a significant impact on young people being able to manoeuvre to find a way to get into the market. It is even getting harder out there. If one goes outside of this cloistered area and talks to the taxidrivers, the restaurant owners or any person out there in the job market, one will find how difficult it is becoming. The more certainty we can give in this particular market to this section of the industry to assist young people heading into the housing market the better. It is very much a positive step towards maintaining what we have left of the real estate market.

The current economic outlook shows a decline in first home buyers and general home buyers in the December quarter 2009. The dramatic reduction in first home buyers across the state, down from a peak of 30 per cent of the market in May last year to just 17 per cent in December, meant that sales of affordable properties also plummeted. This is due in some way, of course, to the introduction of the federal government’s first home owners boost and the first home owners grant. From 1 October 2009 to 31 December 2009 the first home owners boost was halved to $3,500 for established homes and $7,000 for new homes. From 31 December 2009 the federal Labor government decided to cut it altogether. This is yet another Rudd-Gillard government policy debacle to add to the home insulation crisis, the Green Loans Program, the solar rebate confusion and the Bligh Labor government’s complicated and compulsory sustainability declaration forms--weren’t they a big hit?

In relation to contracts that are important for this particular year, house sales under $500,000 dropped from 5,753 in June 2009 to 4,502 in December 2009. Unit prices over $250,000 but under $350,000 have gone the same way--down from 2,252 in June 2009 to 1,498 in December 2009. We can see the devastating effect it is having on the market, and that is why any of these contracts that people enter into as potential buyers must be given certainty in this current hard market. The slowing of the market is a concern, and the Bligh government must ensure it does all it can to protect this market in the downturn. This legislation will do that.

This is why legislation such as the bill we are debating today is important: to ensure all loopholes are addressed for smooth contractual procedures for the seller and the buyer of properties in this state. Certainty is a very important part of the real estate market. This legislation we are debating today will, I hope, shore up some more certainty for real estate participants.

Since the introduction to parliament of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000, significant amendments have been made in order to protect consumers and industry from any gaps in the legislation and to reflect the changes in the industry over time. I must say that most of them have been reactive, not proactive, by successive Labor governments. That is always going to be an outcome of poorly drafted, all encompassing, specific orders legislation, which is the hallmark of Labor governments, with bureaucratic and red tape wrapping on all of its legislation.

The PAMDA was first introduced into parliament on 7 September 2000 by the then minister for fair trading, Judy Spence. After the bill was passed, the legislation commenced on 1 July 2001. The purpose of this act was to repeal the Auctioneers and Agents Act 1971 to provide a more inclusive act that dealt with all of the industry’s arising issues and to also provide more regulation where needed. There was an urgent need for legislation regulating this area as consumers needed to be protected from dodgy salesmen and sales practices in both property and motor dealer sales. There especially was a need for protection for consumers from high pressure sales techniques used to promote residential properties. The provisions in the original act mostly provided for the protection of consumers, and this was clearly needed. A lot of the provisions also caused small business to be caught up in red tape, which prevented small business in Queensland from running smoothly. The opposition expressed its concern that consumer protection was going too far and infringing on the fair business practices of those in the industry. In fact, the current member for Toowoomba South, Mike Horan, spoke at that time about the overregulation of the industry. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: At the end of the day, a person has to take responsibility for the decisions they make.
XML.Hansard-Body: While supporting the protection of consumers in relation to the sale of motor vehicles and property, the opposition was also concerned about potential detrimental effects that would flow on to Queensland business. The opposition was also concerned after the various stakeholders complained that the bill was unworkable and was bad news for industry employment. That reference was from Mr Denver Beanland, the opposition spokesperson at the time. I well remember all the telemarketers doing a great job marketing these properties down there. A lot of legislation we have is as a result of their very effective, high pressure techniques. All sorts of claims were made about how people had been ripped off. Today nearly every one of those people who bought those properties has made an absolute fortune and would be thanking those telemarketers left, right and centre.
Mr Lawlor: They could have made a bigger fortune because they could have bought them cheaper instead of being ripped off and making money for the marketeers.

Mr STEVENS: I will take the minister’s injection that they could have bought them cheaper. The fact of the matter is that they would not have bought them cheaper because those telemarketers actually talked them into buying the property in the first place. That is why we have this legislation today. We have to be very careful about creating a nanny state mentality in instituting all of these warning statements and processes.

It reminds me very much of an appropriate statement about our tendency to go flat out in terms of putting in place new legislation in this nanny state. It reminds me of the words of ‘The Death of Common Sense’--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Today we mourn the passing of a beloved old friend, “Common Sense”, who has been with us for many years. No one knows for sure how old he was, since his birth records were long ago lost in bureaucratic red tape. He will be remembered as having cultivated such valuable lessons as: knowing when to come in out of the rain; why the early bird gets the worm; life isn’t always fair ...
“Common Sense” lived by simple, sound financial policies (don’t spend more than you can earn) and reliable strategies (adults, not children, are in charge).

His health began to deteriorate rapidly when well-intentioned but overbearing regulations were set in place. Reports of a 6-year-old boy charged with sexual harassment for kissing a classmate; teens suspended from school for using mouthwash after lunch; and a teacher fired for reprimanding an unruly student, only worsened his condition.

It declined even further when schools were required to get parental consent to administer Panadol ... to a student; but could not inform parents when a student became pregnant and wanted to have an abortion.
“Common Sense” lost the will to live as the Ten Commandments became contraband; churches became businesses; and criminals received better treatment than their victims.

“Common Sense” finally gave up the will to live, after a woman failed to realize that a steaming cup of coffee was hot. She spilled a little in her lap, and was promptly awarded a huge settlement. “Common Sense” was preceded in death by his parents, “Truth” and “Trust”; his wife, “Discretion”; his daughter, “Responsibility”; and his son, “Reason”.
He is survived by his 3--
stepbrothers; “I Know My Rights”, “Someone Else Is To Blame”, and “I’m A Victim”.
Not many attended his funeral because so few realised he was gone.
XML.Hansard-Body: Provisions introduced predominantly attempted to wind back the powers and discretion of industry stakeholders in order to protect consumers. Property agents and developers were required to disclose any personal or commercial relationships they have with mortgage brokers, lawyers or valuers. Any property developers who sell more than six residential properties in one year must now be licensed. Sole agencies selling agreements were reduced to 60 days, which contrasts with the 90-day requirement in the Auctioneers and Agents Act 1971. Any contract for the sale of residential property arising out of an unsolicited approach from a property agent or seller is now protected by a five-day cooling-off period. The Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act also introduced the concept of a warning statement being included in any contract for the sale of residential property. The warning statement would include advice for the buyer to obtain independent legal advice before signing the contract and the seller must draw the buyer’s attention to this warning statement.

Motor vehicle dealers were required to provide warranties for all vehicles they sell. This was to protect consumers from being sold dodgy cars and would hold dealers more accountable for their business practice. Motor vehicle dealers have to provide a three-month or 5,000 kilometre warranty on a car less than 10 years old and which has travelled less than 160,00 kilometres and a one-month or 1,000 kilometre warranty for cars over 10 years old that have travelled more than 160,000 kilometres. Motor vehicle dealers were also obliged to give a one-day cooling-off period on the sale of all used cars. PAMDA also dealt with the replacement of the Auctioneers and Agents Committee by the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Tribunal with authority to conduct disciplinary hearings, hear and determine consumer complaints involving more than $10,000 and to review the department’s licensing and registration decisions.

The first amendment to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act was in 2001. The need to change certain provisions arose out of the issue that marketeers of investment residential properties were changing their marketing and sale tactics in order to avoid the provisions of the original PAMDA. This reflects the fact that when one particular door is shut, then the people involved in these practices unfortunately look to open other ones and thereby continue the very convoluted legislative processes that we see in play in catch-up football with this legislation. Generally, the amendments were desperately needed to close loopholes left by the original legislation and to strengthen the regulatory framework. These amendments were issued to parliament on 11 September 2001 by the then minister for fair trading, Ms Merri Rose. I will not even go there in terms of the history.

The changes came into effect on 29 October 2001. It was stated that the aim of this bill was to protect the interests of consumers and encourage licensees to act lawfully to avoid having their licence suspended. The opposition recognised the need for these reforms but was concerned about the lack of stakeholder contribution due to time constraints. As it turned out, the legislation still needed a lot of work and consultation from industry stakeholders was essential.

Various changes were made to regulate precontract procedures. The five day cooling-off period was extended to include all residential properties, in contrast to the previous requirement including only contracts arising out of unsolicited approaches by sellers. This provision still excluded contracts arising from an auction. Changes were made to the warning statement to make it more specific and to recommend that the buyer obtain an independent valuation of the property. In addition to this, a contract should include the contact details for obtaining information regarding an independent property valuation and also how to instruct the property valuer. In another bid to promote accountability for property agents, all agents and developers must disclose to the buyer all financial benefits the agent will gain from the sale and promotion of the relevant property.

A number of other changes were made to combat the loopholes in the current legislation that property agents and developers were taking advantage of. The blanket term of ‘unconscionable conduct’ was officially prohibited on the part of any person associated with the sale, promotion or marketing of the relevant property. Also ‘misleading or deceptive conduct’ and ‘false representations’ for the same persons were banned. This was needed in order to close loopholes found by industry stakeholders and to protect consumers from dodgy property sales tactics.

The amendments also dealt with issues extending the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Tribunal’s power to order the cessation of activities and to hold public examinations of any person associated with the sale, promotion or marketing of the relevant property. The jurisdiction of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Tribunal was also extended in order to hear complaints against any person involved in the sale, promotion or marketing of the relevant property and the authority to issue orders for the payment of civil penalties to the state and compensation to the victims. The amendments authorise the District Court to impose increased fines to provide a stronger deterrent for persons breaching the act. The new provisions also provide increased powers for the chief executive to seek substantiation or representations made by any person involved in the sale, promotion or marketing of property. The chief executive’s powers are also expanded to allow him or her to immediately suspend a licence.

After the 2000 amendments to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act, no more amendments were made until the 2004 review brought to the attention of the government the developing issues in the industry that needed to be regulated and reflected in the legislation. The review examined consumer protection issues, with the government indicating that it would make the relevant amendments to the legislation in order to address those issues. The opposition was in agreement with most of the following provisions, but again there was a concern for the absence of protection for businesses in the industry. While consumer protection is of high importance, it was obvious that the wants and needs of industry stakeholders were ignored and a lack of consultation also proved worrying. The first issue identified was the problem of misrepresentation of sale or purchase prices to consumers regarding property. The government proposed that agents be prohibited from quoting sale or purchase prices that did not reflect the agent’s true assessment and be prohibited from deliberately underestimating the expected selling price to potential purchasers. Agents must also record the estimated selling price in the agency agreement with the vendor.

The code of conduct needed to change to respond to changing industry practice and the conduct of real estate agents. The proposed changes provided for the regulation of agent behaviour in relation to things such as unsolicited mail-outs, telemarketing and cold calling for agency appointments. Changes were also recommended for the rules regarding the use of residential tenancy databases. It was also recommended that the code be changed to prohibit the selling of property within a residential complex whilst maintaining the letting of those properties within the complex and to prohibit unreasonable behaviour leading to things such as the lockout of other agents. The registration and identification of bidders at auctions also arose as an area that needed amending. It was recommended that the auctioneers code of conduct be changed to require the registration of all potential bidders at auction and to identify those bidders at the time of each vendor bid.

Some issues arose in relation to the sale of motor vehicles. The government felt the need to make changes in relation to the required motor vehicle warranty. In the case of a claim on the warranty, the dealer would have previously nominated a repairer and that repairer must not be at an unfair distance from where the vehicle is situated. If the vehicle is situated further than 200 kilometres from the dealer’s place of business, the dealer must provide another repairer where the vehicle is situated. The review also recommended that the act be changed to require motor vehicle dealers to disclose to the clients that they are, in fact, licensed dealers. This will protect the consumers’ warranty and cooling-off periods as they will be made aware that they are buying from a licensed seller. It was also recommended that the maximum penalty be increased for unlicensed motor dealing to act as a more effective deterrent. I understand that there is a very high profile website from which a lot of cars are traded. As I understand it, under the act there is a maximum of six trades per day or week. Unfortunately, some of the dealers operating on this fairly popular website are acting as motor dealers without the proper licensing requirements. That is another issue.

To promote further accountability within the industry, more requirements for auditing were recommended, such as that trust accounts and audit reports meet accounting standards and requirements of the act and to ensure that auditors carry out a wider range of checks, including levels and timing of commission paid or claimed by licensees. The review recommended that both real estate agents and motor dealers in training should register as doing so would protect both trainees and consumers. Also, a commercial agent cannot be appointed to act in specific circumstances unless that appointment is in writing. To provide more accountability in motor vehicle sales, it was recommended that a dealer’s licence renewal be conditional on dealing from only the specified premises.

Following this review and the consequential recommendations, a bill was eventually introduced to pass these new provisions. The changes commenced in 2005 to counteract these issues. Provisions in the bill prohibited inappropriate practices such as over and under quoting of property prices by real estate property agents. It required that motor dealers operate from an approved premises, although I understand that in the electorate of Southport on certain Sundays some dealers are opening in a discreet manner. It will be interesting to see if those venues are followed up by the officers of the department.
Mr Lawlor: Have you lodged a complaint?

Mr STEVENS: I hate to bring this to the minister’s attention, showing his departmental office how ineffectual he is in keeping on eye on matters in his own backyard, especially in relation to matters he is responsible for. However, other people are bringing those matters to my attention. I am sure they will be lodging the appropriate complaints. Certainly it is not up to the member for Mermaid Beach to act as a guardian in the electorate of Southport.

The legislation also introduced penalties for excessive or improper commission offences, with a requirement that such commissions be returned to the client. Since the original PAMDA, major amendments were made in 2001 and 2005. The amendments before the House today indicate a need for change in the regulation of residential property sales contracts, to improve the procedural process of contractual arrangements for the sale of houses and units.

The opposition has had thorough consultation with industry representatives and the wider community. In particular, I would like to thank Mr Dan Molloy of the REIQ for his input. He is very supportive of this legislation although he said it fell short in some areas. Some of the other members might bring that to the attention of the minister for further consideration. Obviously, the UDIA had no problems with the bill. The minister has consulted with the legal fraternity and it is supportive as well. The government consultation has been varied. According to the explanatory notes, the government consulted with the community and there was extensive consultation with the Queensland Consumers Association, the REIQ, the Queensland Law Society, the UDIA, the Property Council of Australia and the Motor Trades Association of Queensland. There was also consultation with the Department of the Premier and Cabinet, the Treasury, the Department of Justice and Attorney-General, and other appropriate government agencies. In all of these legislative matters there needs to be a balance between the needs of the buyer and the needs of the sellers. We believe that this legislation takes that into account fairly and justly so that these changes can occur.

According to the explanatory notes, there will be no additional cost to government. The only costs will be for producing and publicising to stakeholders and these will be absorbed by Fair Trading’s budget. I am sure the minister will be able to advise how much of Fair Trading’s budget will be dedicated to advertising this fact far and wide through all of those areas--the Law Society, the REIQ and others--to make sure that it is fully and completely understood by all industry participants.

The legislative review committee said that in some cases it may infringe on the rights and liberties of individuals, arguably, as the rights of the buyer to terminate because of contract delivery are abolished in this bill. The buyer will now have the same rights as the seller to terminate a contract before settlement. The minister has already dealt with that in response to the legislative review committee.

There are some significant changes. Part 2 section 366 requires a lawyer engaged by a buyer in a sale to provide the buyer with a lawyer’s certificate and must explain the nature and meaning of that certificate. Section 367 requires a buyer to receive a copy of a property evaluation for what the buyer has bought. Section 368 sets out information which must be included in a warning statement. Section 368A requires that an information statement must attract the buyer’s attention to the warning statement. This can be done orally or in a simple paragraph.

Subsections 368A(4) and (5) make it clear that a residential contract does not become another separate contract when terms and conditions are changed so long as the residential property is the same and the parties remain the same. Subsection 368A(6) states that it is an offence not to provide an information statement directing the buyer’s attention to the warning statement. Section 368B provides a defence to the above offence. If the seller realises the mistake and withdraws the contract before it is binding then this will be sufficient to stop that offence from occurring. Section 368C requires that the warning statement must be attached to the relevant contract. If the relevant contract is for the sale of a unit then the information sheet must also be attached.
In conclusion--
Mr Lawlor: Hooray!
Mr STEVENS: Well, I can go on. I have some more pages here.
Mr Lawlor: No, please. We surrender.

Mr STEVENS: Okay. But I heard the cheering. In conclusion, I would like to reinforce the opposition’s position of agreeing with this legislation, as we believe it will tighten loopholes. We have concerns that it may create some more loopholes that need to be addressed to improve the procedure and delivery of successful residential contracts in Queensland--matters of concern I shall raise further for the minister’s clarification in the debate in consideration in detail. I certainly reiterate the LNP’s support for this bill’s passage through the House.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (4.52 pm): I rise today to contribute to the debate on the Property Agents and Motor Dealers and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The objectives of the bill are to amend chapter 11 of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 and to make parallel amendments to the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997. The bill will simplify the processes for the delivery and presentation of contracts for the sale of residential property, while still maintaining consumer protection provisions, and thereby promote greater certainty in residential property sales. Any changes regarding the process of purchasing a new property are welcomed as long as the same level of buyers and sellers protection is maintained.

The purpose of the current chapter 11 provisions is: to give a cooling-off period for persons entering into relevant contracts; to require all proposed relevant contracts and relevant contracts to include consumer protection information, including advising of the cooling-off period; and to enhance consumer protection by ensuring the independence of lawyers acting for buyers. The act requires sellers to continuously draw a buyer’s attention to the warning statement, and to the information sheet and the disclosure statement if it is a unit sale, and to attach those documents to the proposed contract in a strict order. This process of having to make sure the warning statement and disclosure statement are delivered in a specific order time after time has created a loophole, allowing buyers to get out of what sellers believed to be a watertight contract. If a purchaser of a property has changed their mind for any reason and they can establish that the contract documents were not presented in the right order, either in person or electronically, they then have the right to terminate the contract at any time before settlement even after the cooling-off period has expired. The courts have confirmed this interpretation of the act.

A number of real estate agents in my electorate of Mudgeeraba have indicated to me that the current need to present contracts in a particular order is overly complex and laborious. Because of this process, many of them have had to cancel contracts, leaving them and the seller to start the process of selling all over again--and all because a purchaser may have changed their mind or found a cheaper property. Buyers seeking to avoid residential contracts have been able to rely on minor and technical breaches arising from, often inadvertent, failures by sellers or sellers’ agents to comply with the requirements for delivery of contracts under chapter 11. An example of a breach under the current act is the circumstance where an agent might have sent a property contract to a buyer via fax or scanned the contract and sent it by email and when sending the fax or email the agent faxes or scans contract pages before the warning statement pages. This scenario is grounds for termination under chapter 11 of the current act. Even though the buyer’s attention may have been drawn to the warning statement and they were fully aware of their rights and consequences of entering into the contract to purchase, they have a right to terminate at any time before settlement.

The bill will implement a preferred approach to simplify the presentation and delivery of residential real estate contracts. The bill also contains amendments to the BCCM Act, which are parallel to the chapter 11 amendments, and makes amendments to the PAMD Act to implement a number of other minor recommendations by the SDPC by removing many of the requirements for the presentation and delivery of residential real estate contracts and by limiting the circumstances under which a buyer may terminate a contract for technical breaches by the seller or seller’s agent. However, the principle of requiring a seller to draw a buyer’s attention to important precontractual consumer protection information contained in the warning statement, and information sheet for unit sales, is retained. This will still give purchasers protection and make them well aware of the contract they are about to enter into.

Under the amendments to the PAMD Act, it will be an offence for a seller to not attach a warning statement, or information sheet for unit sales, to a proposed relevant contract. The right to terminate must be exercised within 90 days of formation of the contract. If the buyer signs the warning statement, they are taken to have seen and had their attention drawn to the statement and the buyer may not terminate the contract. The amendment removes the technical requirements for how the warning statement is to be attached to the contract and in what order the warning must be presented by the agent or seller. This in turn removes the right to terminate the contract for a technical breach. I am sure that residents and agents alike in the fast-growing area of the Mudgeeraba electorate will be pleased with the protection that this legislation affords.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (4.56 pm): I rise to speak to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, which is before the House today. At the outset let me reiterate the point made by the shadow minister that we will certainly be allowing this bill to pass through this chamber today.
Mr Lawlor: Oh, thank you. That’s very decent of you.

Mr BLEIJIE: Yes, we will. When the shadow minister made the comment, there were certainly interjections from those opposite, particularly from the member for Morayfield. For the benefit of the member for Morayfield, I remind the honourable gentleman that those on this side of the House, and I personally, will always support government legislation that shows that once upon a time they were incompetent when they particularly brought in relevant legislation but they have the guts to come back before us in 2010 and fix up their mistakes. That is what this is all about.
I am reminded of the second reading speech by the honourable minister at the time I think back in 2005. The minister at the time, particularly in relation to the warning statement, said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The amendments to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act relate to real estate transactions. They will provide certainty for sellers of residential properties or their agents when transmitting precontractual documents by facsimile and other electronic means.
XML.Hansard-Body: That was some five years ago, and those amendments at the time have certainly not provided anything. All they provided was uncertainty in the profession. They provided uncertainty in the legal profession. They provided uncertainty in the property profession. They provided uncertainty for real estate agents. Now, some five years later, the government is again introducing legislation to fix up its mess from so many years ago. If it had talked to the industry at the time of those first amendments, it would have understood that we have arrived at a point today that we should have arrived at many years ago.

This bill will amend chapter 11 of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000, commonly referred to as PAMDA, and will make corresponding amendments to the Body Corporate and Community Management Act, BCCMA. The proposed amendments in this bill remove the current requirement that directions be given to a buyer after signing the contract but before they are bound under the contract. The removal of this ambiguous double direction will, I am sure, reduce noncompliance issues.

The amendments also remove the requirement for the warning statement and any information statement with respect to unit sales to be attached to the contract as the first and top page of the contract. The warning statement and information statement must merely be attached to the contract. I say to the honourable minister that under the current legislation contracts had to have the warning statement, which is the statutory form 30C. The current legislation required the 30C to be attached as the first and top sheet of the contract. These amendments to the legislation basically get rid of that requirement. I would appreciate it if the minister in his response this afternoon could explain the reasoning behind changing the requirement to have it as the top sheet to now have it attached anywhere through the documentation.

The bill introduces a 90-day period for a buyer to exercise their right to termination because the warning statement requirements have not been complied with. The bill will simplify the processes for the creation of residential property contracts and will create certainty for all parties involved in the sale of residential properties.

As the shadow minister for tourism and fair trading has stated today, the Liberal National Party believes that this bill is a practical step towards tightening the legal loopholes that have arisen under the existing legislation. I am glad that the government has realised this. It is about time it tried to reduce the red tape and burden for consumers and industry and enacted this legislation to bring about more efficient, effective and productive processes.

The bill is a response to the review of the regulatory reform, phase 2, of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 to identify the major regulatory features of the Property Agents and Motor Dealers Act 2000 and to recommend legislative amendments to simplify the level of regulation while maintaining effective consumer benefit. The details of the review are set out in the Service Delivery and Performance Commission’s March 2008 report.

The amendments provide significant changes to property and conveyancing practices and are welcomed by the legal community, developers, financiers and the real estate industry. The introduction of the 90-day period for buyers to exercise their right to terminate the contract for noncompliance with the warning statement requirements will provide some certainty and peace of mind to sellers and developers with longer periods of contract, particularly off-the-plan contracts.

It is important to note that, even though the contract process has been simplified through these amendments, the amendments do not remove the key consumer protections, including the cooling-off period and the requirement to at least attach the warning statement and information sheets for unit sales. The existing requirements under PAMDA and BCCMA set out a very stringent process and order for the warning statements and information sheets to be attached to the contracts for the sale of residential property. If the order is not strictly adhered to or certain documents not acknowledged then a buyer has the right to terminate the contract at any time prior to settlement.

In practice, what we have at the moment is a situation where a buyer signs a contract as an offer to the seller. It is then sent to the seller. Prior to the buyer signing the contract, the seller, giving the blank contract to the buyer, must direct the buyer to the 30C warning statement. The buyer then signs the contract as the offer. It goes back to the seller. The seller then signs it if they accept the offer. When the seller or the seller’s agent sends the fully executed signed contract back to the buyer, they must again direct the buyer to the warning statement. It was a double-dip direction which has created all the controversy and legal cases and loopholes in the current legislation. It was a mess when it was first introduced.
