I advise the House that the division bells are not completely audible in all offices within the George Street wing of Parliament House, which is the wing we are in now. The bells are working, however, in the corridor areas. Earlier this afternoon an amplifier failed. The Parliamentary Service is resourcing a replacement but will not be able to implement a solution until either after the House rises or before the House sits tomorrow morning.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 3, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr LAWLOR (7.31 pm): I move the following amendments--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘(8) If there are 2 or more proposed buyers relating to the proposed relevant contract and subsection (2) is complied with in relation to at least 1 of the proposed buyers, the subsection is taken to have been complied with in relation to each of the proposed buyers.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: I table the explanatory notes to the amendments. I think they are self-explanatory.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes for the Hon. Lawlor’s amendments to the Property Agents and Motor Dealers and Other Legislation Amendment Bill [ 2757 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr STEVENS: I have a question for the minister in relation to an amendment that we received today. That amendment relates to notifying buyers. It basically says ‘we notify one buyer’ as opposed to all buyers of the property. I would like to ask the minister about the case where one buyer of a group of buyers does not receive the appropriate advice, which obviously gives him the chance to void the contract because he has not received that advice. The other buyers may well want to proceed, for different financial market reasons, but because that buyer has not received that information he has the capacity to void the contract. How will that situation be addressed by this amendment?

Mr LAWLOR: I am advised that it is the responsibility of the seller, firstly, to direct the attention of one of the purchasers. That notification will then be signed and will still be attached in the normal circumstances to the contract. If it is not, then it is up to the purchasers to decide what they want to do. As the member has mentioned, some may well want to proceed and others may not, but the vendor has discharged his or her obligation by pointing out to the purchasers their obligation to sign the disclosure statement. Once that is signed, it is then up to the purchasers to sort it out between themselves.
Mr STEVENS: But in terms of consumer protection for the other buyers, they do not want to see the contract void.
Mr LAWLOR: Sure.

Mr STEVENS: They want it to proceed, but because that other purchaser has taken the opportunity to not acknowledge to them that he has not received that advice he may well want to void the contract, which may leave the other purchasers severely financially disadvantaged. That is the issue that I am trying to get around. How do we address that?

Mr LAWLOR: I am advised that the seller has discharged his or her obligation--and remembering that in most of these situations there would be an agent involved anyway--but in the event of the situation the member has described where three have signed the warning statement and one has not, then they have to sort that out between themselves. Certainly, the one purchaser who has not signed would not be in a position to rescind the contract, given that the other three had acknowledged that their attention had been drawn to the warning statement. I would imagine they would have to sort that out between themselves. Maybe the solution would be that one of them would drop out of the contract, but they would not be in a position where they could rescind the contract through the default of the vendor to point out the warning statement to each of those four purchasers.

Mr STEVENS (7.36 pm): New section 369A provides for a consumer to waive the compulsory five-day cooling-off period. Some buyers who are unaware of real estate rules and regulations could be easily persuaded into waiving the right on the pretext that that would secure the relevant property for them from other potential buyers and would reduce red tape surrounding the contract of sale. They could get that advice from not-so-helpful solicitors. So even though they are independent--all of those matters that the minister talked about--this will result in the sellers pressuring buyers to waive the cooling-off period in order to ensure a speedy sale.

There is nothing in the legislation to protect consumers from pressure resulting from new section 369B. New section 369B allows the cooling-off period to be shortened. As I have just said in relation to section 369A, I am concerned that unwary buyers will be tricked, forced or pressured into shortening the cooling-off period. As we know, the cooling-off period is an essential part of consumer protection.

This protection has been in place since 2000. The government is now giving the option for the cooling-off period to be waived. Does this mean that there will be a risk of consumers being taken advantage of and being pressured into giving up this important right?

Mr LAWLOR: No, it will not involve a purchaser putting himself or herself at risk. In fact, it is a requirement of anyone who is waiving the cooling-off period to get a certificate from a solicitor and that certificate must specify that the solicitor has explained the implications of waiving that cooling-off period. In fact, it can work both ways in the sense that you still have to get a certificate from a solicitor but, maybe in a situation where you might be able to negotiate a better deal, a purchaser can offer to the vendor to waive a certain part or all of that cooling-off period. Nevertheless, even in those circumstances that person still must have a certificate from a solicitor saying that he or she has obtained independent advice and that the implications of the waiving of the cooling-off period have been explained to the purchaser.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 5 to 9, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 10--

Mr STEVENS (7.39 pm): Another example is the removal of the provision requiring motor dealers to satisfy the chief executive that the use of the place of business is authorised under the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 for the licence to operate. There are many more provisions that remove requirements in favour of licensed sellers. It cannot possibly be an increase in consumer protection to not make them prove that they are vending from a licensed Sustainable Planning Act premise. Is the change due to potential costs and is this damaging the protection in relation to excluding that planning?

Mr LAWLOR: No, there is no consumer protection issue involved in the point that the member makes. The requirement to provide proof of their business premises being authorised under the Sustainable Planning Act applies only to motor dealer applicants and to motor dealers who change or require business premises. The requirement is usually satisfied by the applicant motor dealer providing some evidence from a local authority that the business premises comply with the local authority’s planning by-laws. However, the requirement for motor dealer applicants to satisfy this requirement is incompatible with the eligibility requirements for any other type of licensed category under PAMDA. That is the only one that was required. It was considered not to be logical just for that one to require that provision. The current provision addresses the use of premises for motor-dealing purposes. More appropriately they are left to the local authority. As the member would be well aware, the local authority polices those sorts of issues.
An honourable member: Even in Southport.

Mr LAWLOR: Even in Southport and even in Mermaid Beach, I understand. Obviously in the policing of the planning laws the local authority, if it had the issue drawn to its attention, would take steps against any business, not only motor dealers, if it was carried on in an inappropriate zoning.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 11 to 23, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 24--

Mr STEVENS
(7.42 pm): I refer to part 4, ‘Other amendments’. I draw the minister’s attention to the many amendments that remove various requirements for those licensed under this act.
Mr LAWLOR: I believe that the member is referring to clauses in the schedule, not in the actual bill itself.

Mr STEVENS: The other ones were in the bill. This clause relates to part 4, ‘Other amendments’, which I think is clause 24. Basically, clause 1 of the schedule removes the requirement for those applying for an agent’s licence to provide photographs with their application. This is one example of the removal of the accountability for licensed agents and motor dealers. What is the reason for not requiring a photo in an application for a real estate licence?

Mr LAWLOR: I am advised that there are around 38,000 of these licensees and it is a massive requirement and a massive use of resources. We require all applicants for licences for resident letting agents, real estate agents, property developers, pastoral houses, motor dealers, auctioneers and commercial agents to supply two recent certified photographs of themselves for the production of a photo licence. Current licensing infrastructure does not readily allow the department to utilise these photographs without incurring substantial additional cost with little apparent benefit to the industries or to consumers in having these occupations have a photo licence as well as a paper based licence.

There are currently in excess of 46,000 licence and certificate holders under PAMDA. The amendment intends to repeal the requirement for applicants to supply photographs except for commercial agents, otherwise known as debt collectors or process servers, and their subagent employees. Because there is a very small volume of applicants for commercial agent licences or subagent licences or registration, these can be processed manually at very little cost.

As I said, there are 46,000 of the other licences. It is important for commercial agents and subagents to properly identify themselves to debtors because they are repossessing goods, serving process and so on, and that is where the identification is important and required. A photo licence in this case is an appropriate means of satisfying the debtor that the person is a licensed or registered individual. It is not considered necessary for those other 46,000 licence holders. It is basically doing away with another level of red tape.

XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr SEENEY (Callide--LNP)
(7.46 pm): The bill before the House is called the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010. The bill takes its title from the introduction of a new legislative regime to administer large scale geothermal energy exploration and production projects in Queensland. The bill, however, will also introduce a new land access framework that will change the way resource explorers and producers will engage with landholders in this state. Hopefully that part of the bill will provide a more ordered and settled framework for access to agricultural land by the resources industry.

The release of the bill and these provisions dealing with land access follows the release of the Land Access Policy Framework in December 2009. The announcement of the proposed framework followed on from the Land Access Strategy released by the government in 2008. These particular provisions of the bill relating to land access have been a long time coming. Many would argue that they are long overdue. That part of the bill that addresses the land access provisions is the part of the bill that has probably been the subject of most public discussion as these provisions extend across the spectrum of the resources legislation so I will consider that part of the bill first in my contribution tonight.

The land access issue has always been a difficult one for farmers and graziers, with many rural landholders seeing the arrival of a mining company seeking access to their land as an assault on their private property rights. I fully understand the importance of private property rights and I know too well the extent to which property rights have been ignored by 12 years of state Labor government legislation. The vegetation management legislation will always be remembered as the ultimate assault on private property rights. It will always be remembered by the rural landholding community as an example of legislation that completely ignored private property rights. The bitterness that that piece of legislation created when it was first introduced in 1999 and through all of its subsequent changes remains very raw amongst the landholding community across Queensland.

I have twice introduced a private member’s bill into this parliament to protect and reinforce private property rights. So I have considered the land access provisions of this bill before the House tonight from the perspective of that very strong philosophical commitment that I have to the security of private property rights. However, it would be absurd to argue that only farmers and graziers have property rights. Anyone who holds a title of ownership has the right to expect that that title of ownership will mean something, that that title will be secure. While each particular title may convey different rights to its holder, it is the security of those rights that is important if our system of legal ownership is to have any integrity. It is important to recognise that any attack on property rights is an attack on everyone who owns anything because if property rights are lessened, then the value of the property is lessened as is the security of the ownership, and the rights that that ownership involve are eroded away.

It is therefore, I believe, in every property owner’s interest to recognise the property rights of others to protect the value of their own properties. That is a very important philosophical concept that both landholders and mining companies should consider in the current debate about the land access provisions that are included in this bill before the House tonight. If we are to insist, as I do and I have always done, on the recognition and protection of property rights for agricultural landholders, then we need also to recognise that holders of mining titles also have rights under the titles that they hold. In the situations that the land access provisions of this bill seek to address there could quite well be a number of different title holders exercising rights conferred by their titles over the same area of land. Theoretically at least, the situation could involve an agricultural land title owner, a holder of a title under the petroleum and gas act, a holder of a separate title under the Mineral Resources Act and a holder of a separate title again under this Geothermal Energy Bill all having rights over the same piece of land. Thankfully, while that situation is theoretically possible, it would certainly not be common. However, the more common situation involves the overlay of the agricultural land title by a petroleum and gas act title and/or a Mineral Resources Act title.

Many of my constituents face this very situation. Many of my constituents, who are freehold landowners, find this situation very difficult to manage, especially when they are confronted with it for the first time. For those freehold landowners dealing with the situation where the owner of a resources title wants to exercise the rights pertaining to that title, that involves confronting the reality that they, as freehold landowners, do not have the right of total exclusive possession. In my experience over 12 years as a local member in an area of considerable resource development, given that I represent the southern end of the Bowen Basin, I believe that it is the loss of that exclusive possession which is at the heart of most of the resistance to resource projects by my constituents who are landholders. The frustration and fear that the loss of that exclusive possession causes gives rise to a range of other arguments about the environment, about food security and about social issues. However, the bottom line is that many farmers and graziers have a huge difficulty accepting the loss of exclusive possession. They have a huge difficulty accepting the idea that someone else has rights and access to the land that they believe as landowners they own.

I grew up on a family property. I own and I have developed a property of my own over a period of almost 20 years. I understand full well the bonds between landholders and the properties. The farming property is more than an economic asset; it is more than a place of business. It is a family home; it is a source of pride; it is a refuge and a sanctuary for independent people. The farm is a public representation of what the individual and family are and it represents what they have achieved over a long period. Their farm embodies a physical expression of their philosophies as farmers and businesspeople. It is a measure of their value as stewards of the land and it is a display of their self-worth.

However, we as landholders cannot deny or avoid the reality of land ownership laws. It is a reality that under our system of land ownership, while landowners have a range of rights associated with their land title that allow them to use and enjoy the benefits of the land, the minerals have always been a state resource separate from the land and have always belonged to the state rather than the individual landowner. The state has always issued titles to explore for and extract those resources to operators who have been obligated to pay royalties to the state for the right to extract those resources, and those royalties have always been to the benefit of all Queenslanders. While there have been some variations over time in what is defined as a state owned resource, the basic concept of the extractable resources belonging to everyone rather than belonging to the individual landholder has a very long history in our system of law.

In Australia, land has been granted under freehold or leasehold title initially and primarily for agricultural and pastoral purposes, and that title conferred the exclusive right to use the land for agricultural or pastoral purposes to the landholder. The security of those land titles has been an important factor in the development of our world-class primary industries that contribute so much to our state economy. That security of title is vital for the investment and for the protection of our land asset. In the same way, mining titles have been granted to explore for and extract resources and the mining industry, too, has become a hugely important part of regional Queensland and our state and country as a whole. The security of mining titles is equally important for investment to take place and for the resources to be managed properly.

Agricultural land titles have never granted exclusive possession or negated the existence of other titles such as those granted under any of the resources legislation referred to in the bill tonight. So there has always been a necessity for co-existence of title holders, each with a particular set of rights over the same piece of land. In the main, that co-existence between agricultural landholders and the resource title holders involved the farmer or grazier conducting their agricultural business on the land and the mining company gaining access to the land through a prescribed process to conduct exploration activities either looking for or determining the extent of the available mineral resources. Usually, if the resource proved large enough to extract commercially, a mine would be developed. To allow that to happen, the agricultural landholder either sold out or was compensated for the property and moved away.

However, in Queensland history there have been some smaller examples of long-term co-existence. Smaller scale miners have co-existed with agricultural landholders on larger properties in the state’s north and in the west, and the oil and gas industry around Roma has always co-existed with landholders over an extended period. However, the coal seam gas industry has brought this issue of land access and land access protocols into a sharper focus for two reasons.

Firstly, by its nature, coal seam gas requires a very long-term co-existence with a large number of landholders over a period of at least 20 to 30 years because the extraction wells are spread over a large geographic area and the effective well life and the extraction times for the gas are long. Secondly, the coal seam gas industry is accessing a resource in an area that is much more closely settled and where agricultural landholdings are much smaller and there is a much greater personal connection between the landholders and their properties.

Mining companies in the main have no such attachment to the land. They understandably see a resource to be evaluated and extracted. While the social and environmental standards of the industry have profoundly improved over the years, it is still understandably for them a business involving extracting the resource at a minimum cost. For many rural landholders, the sudden appearance of a resources company seeking access to their land and the confronting reality that they do not have and never have had that right of exclusive possession to their properties is a very difficult thing to accept and we have seen the expression of the frustration that that causes in Queensland in recent times.

The situation is not helped by the attitude of some mining companies who either do not understand or are insensitive to the reactions of landholders to their arrival on their properties. There can be no doubt that, under our current body of law, both parties have their rights and both parties have their responsibilities. The provisions in this bill seek to define those rights even further and to make those responsibilities even clearer.

The catalyst for the changes in this bill may well have been the rapid expansion of the coal seam gas industry. It is an industry which has enormous potential to provide jobs and economic growth across a large area of central and south-west Queensland where communities have struggled for decades. Hopefully, the provisions in the bill tonight will increase the opportunities for the long-term co-existence that is necessary between the coal seam gas industry and rural landholders to achieve that mutually beneficial existence and assist that economic potential to be realised.

It certainly has been a mutually beneficial relationship in some areas in my electorate where the industry has now been operational for some seven or eight years. Around Taroom and Wandoan and west to Injune, landowners who are my constituents have, in the main, come to grips with the changes that the industry has brought and have successfully negotiated beneficial outcomes for their properties. As is human nature, some landholders and some resource companies deal with the situation very differently to others. In the best of the situations that I am aware of as the local member, landholders have been able to negotiate outcomes that make their agricultural businesses stronger. They have been able to do that through accessing regular financial payments that are not dependent on the season or the cattle market, and that money has helped to insulate their businesses from the vagaries of those notoriously variable elements. Many landholders have also negotiated other outcomes with coal seam gas companies that have improved their properties through better road infrastructure or by gaining access to extra water supplies. To date, these good outcomes have been dependent on landholders and companies respecting each other and negotiating in good faith. They have also been achieved in an area where the properties are bigger and the impact of losing that sense of exclusive possession is somewhat easier to manage and deal with.

However, those good outcomes have certainly not been universal and a formal process to deal with land access issues is certainly overdue. I believe that that formal process, which this legislation will introduce, sets out to take the best practice behaviour that has been developed in the most successful situations by both sides and make that behaviour mandatory for all industry participants via the code of conduct that the bill will invoke. It should mean that there is a greater chance of achieving a respectful relationship between farmers and graziers and the coal seam gas companies that can result in a mutually beneficial co-existence. I strongly believe that there should be no losers and there should be no victims in that relationship. Landholders especially should never accept the role of victims.

It distresses me that there are always those who want to portray rural landholders as victims. Farmers and graziers are not victims in this whole process, either as it stands now or, more pointedly, as the process will stand after the passage of this bill. I would never accept any situation that made farmers and graziers victims or left them worse off in the long term. After close examination, I believe that the process outlined in this bill certainly does not allow that to happen. The freehold title that those farmers and graziers hold is indisputably the superior title and the provisions in this bill, along with all the other legislation already enacted, gives them and their properties an array of protections. Most notably, the recognition of their freehold title as the superior title in all of this legislation gives them the opportunity to negotiate favourable outcomes for themselves and their properties before access is granted to resource title holders. That is a very important change that is being introduced in the bill before the House tonight.

Since the early 1990s, beginning with the previous coalition government and continuing through the revisions of the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act and the Mineral Resources Act, there have been a series of new pieces of legislation that have strengthened and protected those landholders’ rights and this piece of legislation continues that trend. Over that period, this parliament has given landholders and the resources industry the legislative tools they need to build the mutually beneficial co-existence that is so important to the whole state. Unfortunately, this relationship is too often dominated by rumour and myth, rather than fact. Unfortunately, there is often a disconnect between the legislation that passes through this parliament and the reality of the activities in the field in places that can be somewhat remote. Unfortunately, some bad experiences in the past are recounted much more often and are much more widely known than the legislative changes that have happened over the years or the provisions of the bill that the parliament considers tonight.

The extension of the resources industry into the more closely settled areas of the Darling Downs, combined with a couple of very badly handled situations, overlaid by a federal election campaign have created an almost perfect situation for a scare campaign in the last couple of months. Political opportunists, such as the Greens and the so-called Friends of the Earth, have been quick to exploit the situation for their own political ends. Their aims have been to try to garner Senate votes for the federal election campaign or to advance their efforts to rid the world of new fossil fuel production projects, and they have been keen to take advantage of people who are concerned, and even fearful in some cases, about what is happening with the rapid expansion of the resources industry in their districts. Those political opportunists have no real long-term interest in regional Queensland or the people who live there. They are simply taking advantage of a situation and the people who are caught up in it. I despise their efforts, because I and other members on this side of the House have represented those people and those communities for many, many years and we will represent and protect their interests for many, many years to come.

The current state Labor government has been slow to fulfil its role in ensuring that landholders and communities can have confidence in the legislation and the administration of the industry. No matter how good the legislation is, it will never fulfil its purpose without appropriate communication and education for stakeholders and without appropriate monitoring and supervision of on-ground activities. In my view, the state government has a very clear role to ensure accurate information is available to stakeholders about what the legislation and regulations require and to ensure that the general community can have confidence that that legislation is administered and supervised appropriately. In both of those functions, the current state Labor government has failed because it has been torturously slow to act. It has been behind the game all the way. It has failed completely to realise that administering the industry in a closely settled area like the Darling Downs is markedly different from administering the industry in the Cooper Basin or in Central Queensland or in the north-west minerals province. However, the government is beginning to make some efforts, which it should have done quite some time ago. Finally it is getting some people on the ground or at least it is promising to do so, but I am concerned about the length of time it will take to recruit those officers and to get them in place, given the government is already playing catch up on a problem that has been causing concern for some time.

However, I am prepared to give credit where it is due. Last week I was sent the landholders’ information pack, prepared by the department for landholders confronted with the resources industry. I genuinely commend the minister and his department on the preparation of this document. The only problem with it is that it is long overdue. It is a collection of information that should put landholders in a position to adequately negotiate an outcome for themselves. I commend it to members in the House who deal, as I do, with these constituent issues on a regular basis. The document contains things such as the petroleum gas laws and a guide for landholders. It explains the role of the coordinator-general. It explains the adaptive environmental management regime for the coal seam gas industry. I have tried to explain that regime to constituents over and over again. The information that is provided presents that adaptive management regime in a simple and understandable form. The document deals with such things as the approval process. It deals with the contentious issues of coal seam gas water, fracking and flaring, and all the things that cause concern for landholders. It is an information resource that should have been available to landholders much sooner, but I commend the minister and the department for making it available in the way they have. It is a valuable resource and I believe it should assist in avoiding some of the unfortunate problems that we have seen in recent times.

I turn now to the detail of the changes proposed for the land access regime. This bill contains some significant changes to a revised land access and land compensation regime in respect of private land. It is to be introduced into all resources legislation in Queensland. In respect of the land access regime, not only will the provisions of the bill apply to the geothermal titles but the bill will also amend the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Greenhouse Gas Storage Act 2009, the Petroleum Act 1923 and the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004. It will apply the new land access provisions to all resource industry titles across the state and there are transition provisions as well.

This will bring a welcome degree of uniformity--uniformity that has been missing to date and the lack of which has, in my view, been the cause of a regrettable degree of misunderstanding and friction between landholders and resources companies. The amendments will affect all authorities and titles under the existing resources legislation relating to land access and compensation, and the changes to each piece of legislation will come into force at the same time once this bill is passed.

The scope of the changes contained in the bill is certainly not inconsequential but would, I believe, represent a mandating of what the best people in the agricultural and resources industry have been doing for quite some time. For the good operators on both sides of the equation, this bill should not represent much change to the best practice example they have already set for themselves.

The bill proposes a land access code to be made by way of a regulation setting out a single land access code for all resource legislation in Queensland. This land access code will set out the best practice guidelines for communication between the holders of resource titles and the owners and occupiers of private land. It will impose on the resource title holders mandatory conditions concerning the conduct of authorised activities on private land being essentially land held under a freehold land title or other land within the state held under a statutory leasehold land title.

There will be a statutory obligation imposed by this bill upon a resource title holder to comply with the provisions of the land access code and to ensure that any other person carrying out an authorised activity for the resource title holder also complies with those mandatory provisions of the code. If a condition of a licence under a resource title is inconsistent with a mandatory provision of the land access code introduced by this bill, then the bill requires that the mandatory provision will prevail to the extent of the inconsistency. This will introduce a welcome level of consistency to a process which at the moment can be very confusing. It will introduce that consistency across situations covered by the same act and consistency across situations covered by different acts. That level of consistency would be welcome by both landholders and resource companies.

The bill also distinguishes between what are defined as preliminary activities and advanced activities being conducted or proposed to be conducted by resource companies. This is a welcome and sensible distinction, with different requirements imposed on the resource companies for each type of activity. It recognises the differing impacts each level of activity can have on landholders and will ensure the process for minor activities is not unnecessarily cumbersome.

The bill defines a preliminary activity as an authorised resource activity that will have no impact or only a minor impact on the business activities of any owner or occupier of the land on which the activity is to be carried out. Examples given are walking the area of the permit; driving along an existing road or track on the land; taking soil or water samples from the land; drilling without constructing earthworks; geophysical surveying without physical clearing; aerial, electrical or environmental surveying; seismic surveying without using explosives; and survey pegging--all activities which require land access but would not be expected to result in significant impacts on the landowner’s business.

However, there is a very sensible recognition in the bill that such activities, although minor, can have a much greater impact on smaller landholdings than on larger landholdings. Under the terms of the bill, these minor activities cannot be classed as preliminary activities if they are carried out on land that is less than 100 hectares in size. This provision sensibly recognises that the potential impact of any such activity is considerably greater on these smaller blocks of land and their owners. The minor activities cannot be classified as preliminary activities if the land is being used for intensive farming or broadacre agriculture such as irrigated cropping, plantation forestry or horticulture; for dairy, cattle or sheep feedlot; for a piggery or a poultry farm. Likewise, an authorised activity carried out within 600 metres of a school or an occupied residence or an activity that affects the lawful carrying out of organic or bio-organic farming systems cannot under the provisions of the bill be considered to be a preliminary activity. All of these situations would be classified as advanced resource activities under the terms of this bill.

The bill defines a range of other more complex and disruptive activities as advanced resource activities and regulates the issues surrounding land access to conduct such activities. Examples of advanced activities given in the bill include such things as levelling of drilling pads and digging sumps, earthworks associated with pipeline installation, vegetation clearing, constructing an exploration camp, geophysical surveying with physical clearing, carrying out a seismic survey using explosives, constructing a track or access road, or changing a fence line.

Under the law as it will exist with the passage of this bill, a resources company cannot enter private land to carry out a preliminary activity unless at least 10 business days prior written notice of entry has been given to each owner and occupier of the land. The entry period can be no longer than six months irrespective of the type of authority, although a longer period may be agreed to by the relevant owner or occupier of the land in writing. Where it is the first entry notice given to the particular owner or occupier, there must be included with the notice a copy of the land access code, any code of practice made under the relevant resource legislation applying to the authorised activities and a copy of the relevant environmental authority documentation for the proposed activities. The bill also requires that a copy of the entry notice must be given to the chief executive of Queensland Mines and Energy or, for exploration permits and mineral development licences, the mining registrar.

The bill also deals extensively with the provisions surrounding compensation for landholders for the impacts of those resource activities on their land. The issue of compensation is the one that I believe is most surrounded by myth and rumour and where, in my experience, there has been the most misinformation. For some landholders, no compensation is enough for them to readily accept the presence of resource industry operations on their land. They just want someone to make them go away. For some resource companies, compensation is a begrudging burden and, while they will readily invest heavily in machinery, vehicles and staff, those resource companies quibble over relatively minor amounts when it comes to compensating landholders.

The compensation issue is difficult because the impacts of the same physical presence and the same infrastructure can be so different for each individual and each property. Issues such as the loss of the exclusive possession of the property can be not a big concern for some landholders and almost impossible to accept for others. Physical infrastructure such as wells and pipelines can have a major impact in some areas of a property and very little impact in others. Some resources companies will readily cooperate and relocate infrastructure to suit the landholders, while others just take a more arrogant attitude and say, ‘That’s where it has to go.’

If it were not clear in the previous legislation, this bill makes it clear now--and I think some of the proposed amendments that I have seen circulated that the minister intends to move in committee will make it even clearer--that landholders are entitled to compensation for every impact of the resources development on their property, and that is the way it should unquestionably be. No-one can make it go away, as some landholders want. And those who try to tell landholders that they can make it go away are doing them a disservice. What we can do in this parliament and what we have a responsibility to do is to ensure that the legislation and the regulation is right and fair and provides the protection that is fair and reasonable for landholders and ensures that the resources title holders can exercise their rights as well. I believe that this bill achieves that goal and fulfils our responsibility as legislators.

Under the terms of this bill, each owner and occupier of land will have a statutory right to be compensated for all the compensatable effects of the activities of the resources companies on their land. These compensatable effects are to be uniformly defined for all resource authorities and all resource legislation and include: the deprivation of possession of the surface of the land; the diminution of land value; the diminution of use of land and improvements; any severance of the land; and any cost or loss incurred from the conduct of the resource operations.

An amendment that has been circulated that the minister intends to move later removes any doubt that such things as professional costs for accountants and solicitors, the time of the landholders themselves in dealing with resource companies and consequential impacts are all compensatable costs. Landholders need to be aware of the extent of their rights to compensation. That is the way it should be. Landholders should be properly compensated because the cost of compensating landholders for the effects on their business is only ever going to be a small percentage of the capital costs of these resource projects. Resource companies should not quibble unnecessarily about the value of that compensation.

This bill also makes it clear that the resource company cannot enter private land to carry out an advanced activity unless each relevant owner and occupier has agreed to an appropriate conduct and compensation agreement or unless each owner and occupier for the land has signed a deferral agreement to defer the negotiation of such a conduct and compensation agreement. The only exception provided in the bill is where each owner and occupier of the land is an applicant or a respondent to an application made to the Land Court to determine compensation or where entry is to preserve life or property or because of an emergency that exists or may exist.

The bill also mandates statutory requirements for what a conduct and compensation agreement must contain to ensure that such agreements have credibility and that they serve the purpose proposed for them in the legislation. A conduct and compensation agreement under the terms of the bill cannot be inconsistent with the relevant resource legislation, nor can it be inconsistent with any condition of the resource title or any mandatory provision of the land access code introduced by the bill.

As I indicated at the beginning of this contribution, I come to the consideration of this issue with a very strong philosophical commitment to the concept of private property rights. I will strongly defend anyone’s right to compensation if their property rights are impinged or lessened or affected by public projects or by resource industry projects. So I would consider myself to be a very hard judge of what is a fair compensation process for situations where those private property rights are inevitably adversely affected. I believe that the system should err on the side of the property owner who through no choice or action of their own ends up in a situation where their property rights are lessened or affected.

After considering the proposals in this bill from that philosophical viewpoint, I am left with the conclusion that there is not much else that I can see that could be done to make the compensation system fairer. The only possible issue I can see is the provision that allows land access while a matter is being referred to the Land Court. It is hard to argue that this provision should not be there given that it is possible to foresee a scenario where, without it, the court process could be used to unnecessarily delay a resolution of the access issue.

Equally, it could be envisaged that in the extreme the provision could be used to get access without a realistic attempt to arrive at a fair settlement. I would hope that the court itself would serve as a brake on the misuse of this provision by taking a very dim view of situations that were referred for adjudication as a means of frustrating the process set out in the legislation.

A statutory process for negotiating a conduct and compensation agreement is part of the new regime introduced by the bill and that process must be followed before the matter can be referred to the Land Court. Unless the process has been followed, a resource titleholder cannot apply to the Land Court to have compensation determined and that process, if it is entered into in good faith by both parties, should in all but the most difficult cases, in my view, provide the desired outcome without any need for court hearings.

The resource titleholder may begin the process by giving the relevant owners and occupiers of the land a negotiation notice stating that the titleholder wishes to negotiate a conduct and compensation agreement or a deferral agreement as a preliminarily step to gaining access to the landholder’s land. The initial notice must be accompanied by a copy of the land access code to be established by this bill.

The bill makes it very clear that it must state all of the following. It must state if the holder wishes to negotiate a conduct and compensation agreement and whether it is in respect of all or part of the compensation liability and all or part of the property. It also must state if the holder wishes to negotiate a deferral agreement and the reasons a deferral agreement may be the best option in the particular circumstance. It must state a full description of the activities proposed to be carried out on the land that may produce compensatable effects. The notice must state where and when the activities are proposed to be carried out and the contact details for the resource titleholder. A copy of the negotiation notice must also, under the terms of the bill, be given to the chief executive or the mining registrar, whichever is applicable.

After the negotiation notice has been given, the bill requires the resource titleholder and the landholder to use all reasonable endeavours to negotiate a conduct and compensation agreement or a deferral agreement. These negotiations must be for a period of at least 20 business days starting from the giving of the negotiation notice so no-one can be rushed into something they did not understand. The bill requires that if during the 20-business-day period a conduct and compensation or deferral agreement is entered into then the resource titleholder cannot enter the relevant land to carry out advanced activities until the minimum negotiation period of 20 business days ends, irrespective of when the relevant agreement is entered into.

Further, the bill requires that if during, but before the expiration of, the 20-business-day minimum negotiating period a compensation agreement or a deferral agreement has been entered into then either party may during the balance of the 20-business-day period terminate agreement by notice to the other party. So not only is there a defined minimum period for negotiation; the balance of the defined minimum becomes a cooling-off period if agreement is reached earlier.

There is also a mandated mediation process set down by the bill. The bill requires that if at the end of the minimum negotiation period of 20 business days the landholder and the resource company have not entered into a conduct and compensation agreement then either party may ask an authorised officer of the Queensland mines and energy department to call a mediation meeting. In addition, under the terms of the bill an authorised officer may request the resource titleholder and the eligible claimants to attend mediation if a landholder or occupier gives notice stating concerns about the way in which a resource activity is being carried out.

Equally, the bill allows for a mediation meeting to be called by the resource titleholder if the holder gives a notice stating concerns about the activity of a landholder or an occupier. The bill also sets out that a mediation meeting can also be called by the department itself if for any reason an authorised officer of the department has concerns about the relationship existing between the resource titleholder and the owner or occupier of the land.

The bill ensures that nothing said at a mediation meeting is admissible in future court proceedings without the person’s consent. The department’s authorised officer must, under the terms of the bill, take all reasonable steps to ensure the mediation is finished within 20 business days after it was requested. The bill also determines that if a landholder or the resources company after being given notice of the mediation does not attend, the mediation is taken to have been conducted for the purpose of the party which did attend being able to apply to the Land Court to determine the compensation.

It also determines that if mediation has not been finished within 20 business days after the authorised officer receives a request for mediation or there is no conduct and compensation agreement between the parties entered into within 20 business days after the mediation was called then any party which attended the mediation may apply to the Land Court for it to decide the resource authority holder’s compensation liability.

In addition, the bill allows that an application can be made to the Land Court to review compensation already agreed if there is a subsequent material change in circumstances. I believe that that is a very important provision because I think there were agreements made in the early days of the industry when both sides did not fully appreciate the extent of the compensatable impacts on particular properties. I am very pleased to see that provision in the bill which allows for an application to be made to review compensation given a subsequent material change in circumstances. So like the compensation provisions, the mediation provisions set down by the bill are very detailed indeed. They should assist to achieve outcomes for both landholders and resource companies.

The bill also contains transitional provisions, that I referred to earlier, for situations where agreements have already been negotiated and those agreements need to be brought under the statutory provisions provided by this bill. It determines that where parties have entered into a compensation agreement which is still in force immediately before the commencement of the amendments introduced by the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010, the bill we are considering tonight, then on the commencement of those amendments any such existing voluntary agreement becomes a conduct and compensation agreement for the purpose of the amendments. It also sets out that any entry notices given prior to the date of commencement of the amendments continue according to their terms to be valid for the carrying out of the activity notified, even though the notice does not comply with all of the entry notice requirements introduced by the amendments in the bill tonight.

To summarise, the land access provisions contained in this bill set out a detailed process which has been worked out by the parties themselves and it is undoubtedly thorough. We will support its passage into law and continue to monitor its implementation to ensure that it produces the reasonable outcomes both the agricultural and resources industries need to continue to provide the great economic base for our regional communities and for our state as a whole.

I now turn to the main body of the bill which, as its name suggests, deals with the regulation of geothermal energy. As stated in the explanatory notes that help to define what the main body of the bill is about--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Geothermal energy is heat energy derived from the Earth’s natural (subsurface) heat. It occurs in various forms, including hot geothermal water (‘wet’ geothermal energy) or as hot dry rocks. This energy can be used in a variety of applications, including heat pumps, industrial applications and electricity generation. Importantly, geothermal energy has the potential to produce virtually carbon dioxide ... emission-free power.
XML.Hansard-Body: Currently, geothermal exploration in Queensland is administered by the Geothermal Exploration Act 2004 which was designed as an interim legislative regime to enable the commencement of geothermal exploration. This bill proposes a more comprehensive regime to administer both exploration and production of geothermal energy into the future as the production of geothermal energy hopefully expands in our state. It also introduces a regulatory framework in which proponents can operate and provides for issues regarding competition with other resource industry title holders or overlapping titles with other resource industry legislation to be addressed adequately.

Overlapping tenures have already caused difficulty in relations between coal seam gas proponents who hold title and operate under the petroleum and gas act and underground coal gasification operators who hold title and operate under the Mineral Resources Act. It is not hard to imagine that the potential overlay of another title under another regime created by this bill could add an extra degree of complexity to what is already a complex situation. The tenure regime introduced for geothermal energy by this bill roughly follows the regime under the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004 providing for geothermal exploration permits, geothermal production leases and geothermal data acquisition authorities. Only large scale geothermal exploration and production will be regulated under the bill before the House, with the threshold for large scale production to be specified in a separate regulation. The bill notes that the matters to be considered in determining large scale production may include temperature, flow rates and the amount of energy produced.

The extraction of ground source geothermal energy by using geothermal heat pumps to heat and cool buildings will be regulated by the Plumbing and Drainage Act 2002, pursuant to anticipated amendments to be made to that act. All other geothermal production that does not meet the threshold criteria will be regulated under this bill only if it triggers existing legislation such as the Sustainable Planning Act 2009 or the Water Act 2000. Geothermal exploration activities carried out with the intention of producing large scale use of geothermal energy will require under the terms of the bill a geothermal exploration permit. Geothermal exploration is defined in the bill as--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) exploring for and quantifying geothermal resources; and
(b) carrying out investigations and other activities associated with exploring for, or quantifying, geothermal resources.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Large scale geothermal production activities will require a geothermal production lease. Geothermal production is defined as--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the recovery of geothermal energy--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) on or from beneath the surface of the land in which it is contained, other than production testing; or
(b) from a place at which geothermal energy naturally appears at the surface of the land.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Data acquisition authorities will also be available under the terms of the bill to allow the collection of data from land contiguous to an existing tenure.
XML.Hansard-Body: The bill deals with the issue of overlapping tenure. It generally follows the overlapping tenure regime provided for in the petroleum and gas act, restricting certain activities and providing a process for determining priorities for competing tenures. The bill provides the mechanisms to allow holders of overlapping tenures to make agreements for a structured approach to the timing of activities and the sharing of infrastructure.

Further to this coordination approach, and for situations where it may not necessarily be appropriate, protections are provided in the bill for competing tenure holders. The bill provides that if a geothermal exploration permit covers the same land as a non-geothermal exploration authority then authorised activity for the geothermal permit must not be carried out if the activity will adversely affect the carrying out of the activities under other resource legislation where that activity has already commenced. It also ensures that the application for a geothermal production lease that overlaps with any area of any competing tenure must include a statement assessing the likely effect of the proposed geothermal activities on the future use of the resources under the competing authority, as well as the technical and commercial feasibility of coordinating those activities.

Under the terms of the bill, the applicant must provide the overlapping tenure holder with a copy of the application and the overlapping permit holder then has the opportunity to make submissions in respect of the application. The bill provides for the minister to make a resource management decision on the priority of the tenure holders, and if coordination is unlikely or such an arrangement is not technically or commercially feasible the minister may give priority to one of the competing resources. It is important that the overlapping tenure issue be dealt with in some detail, as it is, and it is appropriate that the minister has to make the decision in the end.

Given the number of resource titles that have been issued and will be issued in Queensland, the likelihood of overlapping tenure issues emerging is very high indeed. I think it is a widespread hope that geothermal energy will, some time in the future, be a major contributor to the state’s energy grid and the legislation as it is contained in the bill before the House tonight should allow the development of that industry to proceed. The bill also clarifies the situation relating to overlapping tenures for coal seam gas titles issued under the petroleum and gas act and the underground coal gasification titles issued under the Mineral Resources Act.

The bill also once again seeks to intervene in a long-running dispute between two coal companies--that is, Cherwell Creek and BMA in Central Queensland. This parliament passed a bill in 2008, the Mineral Resources (Peak Downs Mine) Amendment Bill 2008, to deal with this issue and it does not reflect well on the minister or his department to again be seeking a legislative solution to the same legal issue. However, as I did in 2008, I will not oppose this part of the bill, accepting somewhat reluctantly the need for another legislative solution to ensure that the Caval Ridge Mine is able to proceed and provide the economic benefits that have been long promised. The bill also makes some minor amendments to the Electricity Act 1994 in relation to the retailer of last resort provisions and repeals the Timber Utilisation and Marketing Act.

As I said at the beginning of my contribution, we will be supporting the passage of the bill through the House tonight. It does address a couple of very important areas. The land access issue is overdue to be addressed, as I said, in some detail. I think this bill does address it appropriately. Certainly, we hope that the geothermal energy provisions that the bill puts in place will lay the basis for the development of a geothermal energy industry in Queensland.

Mr HOPPER (Condamine--LNP) (8.37 pm): I want to congratulate the shadow minister for his in-depth contribution crossing every part of this legislation. This bill introduces a new legislative regime to govern large scale geothermal energy exploration and production projects in Queensland. The bill also introduces a new land access framework, which has been long awaited, that will modify the process of resource company and primary producer engagement in Queensland and is expected to provide a more uniform and strengthened framework for access by the resource industry to agricultural land.

Tonight I will be speaking about several elements of this bill, including land access. The recent release of the Land Access Policy Framework was welcomed by the LNP. Land access is a critical part of all negotiations between resource companies and landholders and one that has become extremely contentious in many areas of my electorate. The former electorate of Darling Downs and the now electorate of Condamine will have a massive impact coming upon us in the very near future. Our landholders are going to be impacted very heavily, and we must get this right tonight. This government was disappointingly slow in actioning the framework.
Mr Robertson: We have been careful.
Mr HOPPER: Very disappointingly slow.
Mr Robertson: We have been very careful.
Mr HOPPER: Very disappointingly slow. We have seen many instances where you people did nothing. You people did nothing. We met with you. We had many deputations to ministers--
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! I ask the member to direct his comments through the chair.

Mr HOPPER: Madam Deputy Speaker, they did absolutely nothing. It was not until we had deputations come down here to meet with the minister that some action was put in place. This bill is the fruit of very hard work by the likes of the member for Warrego, the member for Callide and me. We put pressure on the government to represent our primary producers, which it should have done over the past few years. Finally, we have legislation that is a touch towards what it should be.

This government was very slow in putting together this framework. In some cases, farmers were extremely vulnerable to the resource companies that want to access their land for exploration purposes. Some of our landholders have felt not only exploited but also violated.
A government member: Violated?

Mr HOPPER: Yes, absolutely. Those people over there would not have the slightest clue. Land access remains a complex issue for many landholders. It is very difficult for landholders to accept that the land of which they have been the custodians for decades can suddenly be occupied by another entity. It is exactly the same situation as a person owning a home in Brisbane and then someone comes in and says, ‘I’m going to use that bedroom.’ That person says, ‘No, you can’t’, but then all of a sudden by law they can. That is simply unacceptable.

Tonight, we see legislation to address some of these problems. I ask members to imagine themselves as a landholder whose land is suddenly occupied by another entity. This intrusion is disturbing for landholders, which is totally understandable. Rightly or wrongly, they feel that their property rights are being worn away. They feel that their property rights are being taken from them.
Mrs Sullivan: No land comes unconditionally.

Mr HOPPER: I hear them squawk in the background. They have never been confronted with anything like this. There is no way in the world the member has ever been confronted by anything that this bill is trying to address tonight.
Mr Shine: How do you know that?
Mr HOPPER: I know for a fact--
An opposition member: Absolutely--would not have a clue.
Mr HOPPER: Absolutely--would not have a clue.

Mrs SULLIVAN: I rise to a point of order. Those comments were directed at me. I find them offensive and I ask that the member withdraw them. As chair of the Environment and Resources Committee, I happen to know a lot more about geothermal than the member would ever know.
Mr HOPPER: I withdraw.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms van Litsenburg): Order! The member has withdrawn.

Mr HOPPER: I withdraw. Not a problem. The bill addresses many of the land access concerns and seeks to reassure all landholders that their property rights are still intact. Many of my constituents are freehold landowners. It used to be that if you bought something you owned it. Many, many times we have heard Senator Barnaby Joyce say that if you take something without compensation it is theft.
Mrs Sullivan: Does he say a million or a billion?

Mr HOPPER: How rude. I would like my speech to be heard. Those landholders find this situation of a resource company having the right to exercise a resource title difficult to comprehend. The recent landholders information packs that were prepared by the department are a positive step forward to opening up communication channels. We have farmers who have employed people full-time to fight this fight. We also have property owners who are faced with a mining company coming on to their property and they do not know a thing about it. So an up-to-date information pack has been prepared and landholders can access it. That is a good thing. It is not often I congratulate the government.

It is hard for resource company representatives to understand the attachment that primary producers have to their land. It is a long association that spans many generations. The families of many of my constituents have been settled on the Darling Downs for over 100 years. I am from one of those families. Those people are still producing food, foliage and fibre for the people of Queensland and Australia and they are exporting clean, green produce all over the world. These landholders conduct their business in a sustainable manner and find the intrusion of an industry, which has a life span of 20 to 30 years, unsustainable. The only reason Australia did not go into recession was agriculture. Our farmers have it together. They are producing the wealth of this nation and that is the only reason Australia did not go into recession.

In my electorate, the rapid increase in the coal seam gas industry has caused a great deal of angst. Much of my electorate is covered by intensive farming systems involving the growing of highly valuable crops on irrigation farms. These farming systems do not lend themselves to land access for the exploration of resources. The highly invasive nature of the coal seam gas industry provides many challenges and intensive farming systems are not a desirable place for co-existence between the two industries. That is why we have put in place a policy to protect prime agricultural land. We will protect prime agricultural land and lock it up. I note that the government has copied our policy in a lot of ways.

The bill introduces practical and significant changes with the revision of the land access and land compensation regimes. These changes are long overdue and will provide much needed security for landholders. The bill will amend the Mineral Resources Act 1989, the Greenhouse Gas Storage Act 2009, the Petroleum Act 1923, and the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004 to apply the new land access provisions to all resource industry titles across the state. As members can see, the bill is responsible for an enormous amount of legislative change, which is why it needs to be right. We must get this right.

I welcome the uniformity that the bill will bring. To date, uniformity has been missing in action, which has probably contributed to some degree to the misunderstanding that has occurred between the resource representatives and the landholders. Once this bill is passed, all authorities and titles under the existing resources legislation relating to land access and compensation will be affected. The bill differentiates between preliminary activities, advanced activities and makes other welcome changes. This distinction for different requirements is a sensible change that will ensure that the process of miner activities is more streamlined.

The provision of a minimum negotiation period is an appreciated change for landholders. These negotiations must be for a period of at least 20 business days, starting from the giving of the negotiation notice. The entry period is to be no longer than six months irrespective of the type of authority, except if a longer period can be agreed upon by all parties. That means that a negotiation must be put in place. We need to educate our property owners so that they know their rights--that things can only happen though negotiation and that they must agree to it.

The bill addresses the compensation issue and many landholders will embrace these long-awaited changes. Compensation has been and is a point of contention. Each landholder has their own opinion on what is an acceptable amount of compensation. As the shadow minister said before, in some areas no amount of compensation will suffice. Compensation for intensely farmed land is a different issue compared to grazing land. The impact of the resource activity on one farming system compared to another is very different. Farmers in my electorate are fighting for their interests full-time. Are they going to be paid an hourly rate for their time? Under the legislation, I seriously believe that they can charge the mining companies for the time and effort that they have put into protecting their interests, protecting their farming land and protecting their families. Many of the farmers in my electorate are fighting full-time the invasive initiatives that have been put upon them.

This changes the whole situation in relation to compensation. If we realise what we are up against here and what our rights really are, we can actually protect what we believe in. Under the terms of this bill each owner and occupier of the land will have a statutory right to be compensated for all compensatable effects of resource companies on their land. These compensatable effects are to be uniformly defined for all resource authorities. Some of these include the deprivation of possession of the surface of the land, the decrease of the land value, the decrease of the use of their land and the improvements, severance and any cost or loss incurred from the conduct of the resource operations. Compensatable costs include such things as professional costs for accountants and solicitors and also the time that I spoke about that the landholders themselves spend dealing with the resource companies, and the fuel they use. Landholders should be properly compensated for all their costs and losses incurred and this is very long overdue.

This bill proposes a more inclusive system to administer both exploration and production of geothermal energy into the future. Queensland is hoping to expand the production of geothermal energy and this bill introduces a regulatory framework. Overlapping tenures have caused difficulties between various resource companies competing for the same tenure. This bill addresses these overlapping titles. We have seen that west of Chinchilla where two different companies were overlapping and were fighting against each other. On many occasions it has been a big problem. Recently we have seen problems with one of the underground coal gasification projects at Kingaroy. This should alert all of us and cause us to look long and hard at the long-term effects of these relatively new industries.

Only 15 years ago we were talking about importing gas from New Guinea. We did not realise the resource we had. Now the resource is being developed to such an extent that we do not have the technology to deal with it. We need to take a serious look at the problems we are facing. We need to make sure that our precious underground water supplies are safe from contamination. There are 22 towns in the Western Downs shire that rely on underground water. If we allow an industry to go ahead that affects that water, what will we say to future generations when there is no underground water? It is vital that it is scientifically proven that the process of underground coal gasification and coal seam gas extraction can occur without interference to the quality or quantity of our underground aquifers.

Any changes to legislation that enable closer, more vigilant monitoring of these industries is well received. This legislation tonight goes a step further. As the shadow minister said, we will support this legislation. The LNP has a five-point policy to protect prime agricultural land. I read that policy out in this House a few sittings ago. Our leader and the member for Surfers Paradise, John-Paul Langbroek, came out to Dalby and announced that policy. We are the only party that has said that we will protect our prime agricultural land. We are the only party that has had the nous to do it. I see the primary industries minister sitting across the chamber. We have not heard a word from him. We will protect our prime agricultural land and our farmers.

Included in this framework is a charter of property rights. If something is taken from someone they will be fully compensated. There will be a rural water advisory board that will protect prime agricultural land from all activities. We are not talking only about mining; we are also talking about development. We are going to lock that land up to produce food for the people of this nation. If our underground water aquifers are dewatered or contaminated, we can no longer produce food. We have to be very careful about that when we put legislation in place in this chamber. We are known world-wide for foliage and fibre. We produce clean green food in this nation. We beat every nation in the world with what we produce. It is our duty to protect our land and water. The LNP when in government will absolutely do so.

Mr JOHNSON (Gregory--LNP)
(8.54 pm): I have been in this place for a bit over 20 years and tonight I heard one of the best researched speeches I have heard on any piece of legislation come from the shadow minister in relation to the Geothermal Energy Bill. I congratulate him on the amount of work that went into it. Every aspect of his contribution tonight canvassed precisely what this very sensitive piece of legislation is all about. It is sensitive in many ways. This industry is in its infancy. I believe that the legislation has many complexities and that we will see it come back here time and time again to be debated in this House.

We are pursuing new horizons with geothermal energy. It is certainly a new frontier in Australia, especially here in Queensland. The coal seam gas industry is another industry that is very fragile, with issues being raised on a daily basis in relation to the underground water table and prime agricultural land. I believe that as legislators we have to be responsible and understanding of the complexities of these two, I suppose one could say in tandem, aspects of new technology: geothermal and coal seam gas.

The first issue that I want to speak on tonight is the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010. This bill repeals the Geothermal Exploration Act 2004 which places limitations on geothermal exploration and production. The real issue is just how much people understand about this new technology and what it offers for Queensland and ultimately for Australia. I believe that it will be the energy source of the 21st century if we can harness it and develop it in a responsible, economical way. It will certainly meet the energy needs of much of our great state, especially some of the remote areas that I and other members of this House represent, in the area of the north-west minerals province and certainly in the Central Highlands region. Geothermal energy will make a significant contribution to looking after the environment.

This bill allows for geothermal exploration of large tracts of this state that hopefully will result in new energy benefits for Queensland. The bill will also regulate access to geothermal resources, provide security for exploration and, more importantly, security for landholders. There has always been controversy because there is a lot of misunderstanding by landholders as to what their rights are. This piece of legislation covers that issue. Not one of us is perfect, but this legislation goes a long way towards providing the security in question. This industry is in its infancy--in fact, it is probably in its embryonic stage--and certainly it has many complexities that are very real. Bearing in mind those complexities, I think that we have to have understanding from industry, landowners and the state as a whole as to how we manage the process on the way through.

In the long term this very sensitive issue will be a contributing factor to providing energy at a cheaper rate than what we witness now. There is a solar energy system at Windorah in Western Queensland that provides for the energy needs of that little town. As technology improves and as time moves on, we will see a lot more of this type of technology provide for safer, cleaner and more efficient generation of power. It will provide our communities with a cleaner environment in which to live. Ultimately, that outcome will have long-term benefits for those communities and the people who live in them.

We are living in exciting times. I do not think any of us really knows what the future holds in terms of these new technologies and the developments in energy, whether it be coal seam gas, geothermal or whatever other type of energy. Geothermal energy is one source that we have to really embrace. We need to assist companies to make it a viable alternative to our current sources.

The shadow minister, the honourable member for Callide, provided a very complex and detailed insight into this legislation this evening. As I said earlier, he has researched it very well and addressed every aspect of it. One aspect that he did touch on that I want to talk about also is land access and compensation. They are important factors in this legislation. Still to this day in my own electorate of Gregory and the area around Emerald, north of Emerald and south of Emerald there is prime agricultural land going back down to the Arcadia Valley adjacent to the electorate of the honourable member for Callide. As we know, they do not make land anymore. We have heard of the controversies in recent times of the golden triangle between Emerald, Rolleston and Springsure, that magnificent country around Orion, which is probably some of the best grain growing country in not only Australia but also the world. It is absolutely paramount that we provide security over that land indefinitely. I know there are coal seams under it. However, they do not make land anymore. As the member for Condamine made reference to tonight, the LNP certainly has a policy about protecting that land in question.

I turn now to the single access code for freehold and leasehold land. This is a very integral part of this legislation. It gives landholders the right to negotiate with these companies in the allotted time. I have to say that in the past 20 years we have seen much legislation come before this House. I think that the rights of landholders have been continually improved by legislation as it progresses. This piece of legislation is different in many ways in that it is now identifying with the needs of landholders in relation to protecting their land, rights and assets. More importantly, we must identify the importance of their asset, the value of their asset, the wealth-generating capacity of that land in question whether it be through grain production, sheep, wool, cattle or whatever the case may be.
