We are talking about some of the best farming land in Queensland. We are talking about coal seam gas, coal and mineral development. The important factor is that there must be no hidden agenda in terms of compensation to landholders. They should be made aware of their rights and given every opportunity to take advantage of their entitlements.

Turning to the coal seam gas industry, this is a new industry. It is an industry that is locking up a lot of very good land in the Western Downs area and the southern Arcadia Valley area that I represent. The interlocking of pipelines in the gas fields will render a lot of good farming land useless, but this is going to be the network. Many property owners have legitimate concerns, and it is something that I hope the minister will address in his summary sometime tomorrow. It is important that landholders are told up front exactly how this is going to work, how they can continue to operate their farming operations or their cattle grazing operations as the case may be. We are talking about the most productive land in Queensland. Ultimately, this land’s production quality is equal to nowhere else in the state.

One good aspect of this legislation is the 20 business days cooling-off period for both parties. I believe in the issue of negotiation with these companies in question. Another good aspect of this legislation that I have studied is the option to go to the Land Court for mediation. I think that is an important priority. In relation to negotiations, it is sacrosanct that landholders are assured that their property rights are recognised, that they are protected and that a multinational company does not ride roughshod over them because it wants to extract the coal seam gas, coal or whatever the case may be. In this case tonight, many provisions in this legislation will clarify some of those issues.

I say to the minister that many people, especially in that Arcadia Valley area that falls under the banner of the coal seam gas industry, have major concerns in relation to their own operations. I trust that those people in that southern area just north of Injune can be afforded the courtesy of departmental officers or these exploration or gas companies making certain that there is a meaningful co-existence between both our farming and grazing operations and these coal seam companies. While it is going to be a long-term operation, it is absolutely paramount that we see that agricultural industry co-exist in a productive way with this new form of development that we have never witnessed in that part of Queensland before.

The issue of it being prime agricultural land is paramount. We do need to address these issues. Over the next couple of years, the new Waratah and Hancock developments--those mega mines--will develop further in the central area of my electorate going back towards Alpha and between Alpha and Clermont. That is a different type of country. We are talking here about red soil, forest-type country. It is not the prime agricultural farming land that we all know exists in the Central Highlands.

With those few points I say to the minister and departmental officers tonight that it is paramount that we get this mix right, that the farming operations, the landholders and the people who operate those good agricultural operations through that region are not penalised, are not subjected to the torture of being ridden roughshod over by these multinational companies. More importantly, we must work it out so that both the coal seam gas companies or the coal companies and these agricultural operations can gain full productivity.

I refer to the farming land of the golden triangle area and Arcadia Valley just north of Emerald. They do not make that land anymore. I refer to the farming country of the southern downs and the western downs, around Roma and Dalby. They do not make that land anymore, either. We could take a leaf out of the book of the people of Europe, because they look after their prime agricultural land. They have done so for hundreds of years and they will continue to do so. In recent years in the south-east all the beautiful country of the Redlands, which was prime vegetable-growing land, has been developed into residential estates. That is where we have the mix wrong. I hope that we do not get the mix wrong as we develop and secure a coal seam gas industry and a coalmining industry in the very valuable lands above those commodities--that is, coal seam gas and coal. I hope that we can work through this.

The geothermal concept affects Western Queensland and remote areas. I believe that this industry has to be pursued and developed as quickly as humanly possible, because the long-term benefits of the geothermal industry are untapped in more ways than one. Many people are living in and moving to the south-east of the state. We are overtaxing the resources in this part of the world and we need to develop the clean energy resources of the western areas. Mr Deputy Speaker, you come from Western Queensland so you would know as well as I that they are good places to live and raise a family, but we do lack natural resources. Power will be a significant factor in the development of the regions so people will move there. The social infrastructure is there with hospitals, schools and all that type of thing. It is very important that we look at fast-tracking those developments, so that we can secure a future for the growing population of this state. Those of us who have lived in such places for a long period certainly know that they are good places to get ahead and to raise a family while progressing the causes of this great state.

I congratulate the minister for putting together what is very complex legislation. I think in terms of geothermal energy and coal seam gas, this legislation will take the state a long way into the future. However, we have to address the anomalies that exist, such as the underground water issue and the preservation of our prime agricultural land.

Mrs ATTWOOD (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (9.13 pm): I rise to speak on the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010 because I and many others believe that Queensland needs to move forward in relation to the generation of renewable energy. As the member for Mount Ommaney I have been pleased with the level of interest shown by local environmental groups in sustainable energy and their knowledge of the effects of climate change.

One local group, Sustainable Jamboree, was established in 2006 and continues to go from strength to strength, providing programs for local schools, households, businesses and community groups to reduce our ecological footprint and promote sustainability. Sustainable Jamboree’s convenor, Ngaire McGaw, has a high profile in the community for her very hard work and the number of hours she puts into this local community organisation. Recently, ABC Carbon listed Ngaire among the top 50 climate activists in Australia. In 2009 this organisation ran more than 45 public events or activities, usually to large interactive audiences, and the Queensland government provided $10,000 in funding for the group to deliver the Low Carbon Diet program, which resulted in carbon savings of 1,211,822 kilograms per year and an average household reduction of more than five tonnes. The group’s first project was initiating the first community farm at Rocks Riverside Park, where over 100 people from the local community cultivate 40 sustainable garden plots, growing their own produce to share.

Like these sustainable energy enthusiasts, people generally recognise that climate change is one of our greatest challenges. The Queensland Renewable Energy Plan outlines a strategy for the expansion of our state’s renewable energy sector. I am pleased that this bill will deliver a flexible framework for regulating geothermal exploration and production. Geothermal energy, described as hot rocks, is virtually emissions free and, therefore, is a greenhouse-friendly energy source. It has the potential to produce more baseload energy for Queensland than any other single source of renewable energy.

Heat energy is contained in the earth’s crust and is derived from natural geological processes which have various forms including geothermal water, steam or wet geothermal energy, and hot dry rocks. This type of energy can be utilised for small scale and large scale power generation. It is estimated that Queensland has at least 90,000 cubic metres of hot rocks, and geothermal production presents a number of potential benefits to the state. These include access to a new and potentially vast energy source, attracting significant exploration and research investment and placing the state at the forefront of this new technology. It is important that Queensland takes responsibility for reducing its emissions and sequestering greenhouse gases from the atmosphere. We need to ensure that our state is well positioned for economic and social resilience by fostering sustainable industries.

The purposes of this bill are: to implement the Queensland government’s policy for geothermal energy production and use by underpinning the concept that the people of Queensland own all geothermal energy resources; to ensure a consistent approach with other Queensland resource based legislation; and to provide security and flexibility for the geothermal industry in its infancy.

Encouraging regulated large scale production and use of geothermal energy will support rural and regional employment. Our focus is to promote competition and business investment. It is vital that we manage the environmental impacts of the geothermal activities by ensuring that companies obtain the relevant environmental and water authorities before exploration or production activities commence. Everyone recognises that the resources and agricultural sectors are the backbone of Queensland’s rural and regional economy, and their co-existence is critical to the long-term prosperity of the state. This bill addresses those important issues.

As a member of the parliamentary Environment and Resources Committee I am pleased that currently we are looking at creating the right conditions for tapping into renewable energy resources in Queensland. Switching to renewable energy resources for some of our electricity needs is the key to reducing climate change risks and ensuring that the state has environmentally sustainable energy sources for the future. Coal-burning power stations continue to produce about 85 per cent of Queensland’s electricity, and demand is predicted to grow by around half by the end of this decade.

With only six per cent of the state’s electricity now sourced from renewables, it is time to act and to tap into our potentially limitless resources of solar, wind, biomass and geothermal. Research suggests that our state has more geothermal material than any other Australian state or territory. Enormous quantities of virtually emissions-free energy could be produced in Queensland. This bill will move Queensland forward and recognises the Bligh government’s passion and commitment to a clean energy future.
Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (9.17 pm): I rise to support the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010.
An honourable member: How’s Jon going?
Mrs SULLIVAN: He is going very well, thank you. It is our 30th wedding anniversary tomorrow and I appreciate all of the comments from well wishers in the chamber.

By world standards, Australia is an energy guzzler. Of the 21 nations assessed, the International Energy Agency, the IEA, has identified that we are the fifth largest user of energy behind Canada, Finland, the United States of America and Belgium. Queensland is the most energy intensive state in Australia and we rely heavily on fossil fuels to meet our energy needs. A recent weekly greenhouse indicator shows Queensland emitted 1.458 million tonnes of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere and unfortunately our energy usage continues to grow at an average of 2.3 per cent per annum. That is why reading the Toward Q2 August newsletter was heartening. I have to congratulate Queenslanders for embracing alternative energy, particularly solar, with the aim of reducing our carbon footprint. I also congratulate the state and federal Labor governments on their subsidies for solar and other renewable energy sources.

Geothermal energy sources could play a vital role in the federal government’s national renewable energy target of 20 per cent of Australia’s electricity supply to come from renewable energy sources by 2020. The committee that I chair, the Environment and Resources Committee, is currently inquiring into the opportunities and challenges for the Queensland government associated with increasing the proposition of electricity generated from renewable energy sources in this state. Our latest hearing was attended by representatives from Clean Energy Australasia who gave my committee a brief outline of their work in geothermal or ‘hot rocks’ energy. They described Queensland as having the largest potential for geothermal energy of any state in Australia. Hence the need for legislation. They also said it was closer to the surface which means easier and cheaper access and that the source would last a million years.

The Geothermal Energy Bill is another step to tackle climate change as we move towards less reliance on fossil fuels. The bill aims to support this burgeoning industry by delivering a flexible framework for regulating geothermal exploration and production and delivering a concise message to the geothermal industry--and that is you can invest in this state, as Minister Robertson says, with certainty and confidence.

The bill supports the Queensland government’s investment in geothermal initiatives. An example is our $15 million investment in the state’s Geothermal Energy Centre of Excellence and a further $5 million committed to the Coastal Geothermal Energy Initiative, which will identify high geothermal heat flow areas close to existing electricity transmission lines along our coastline. Obviously the further the energy source is away from the grid means it is more expensive to connect to it.

The bill provides for the underpinning of the concept that Queenslanders own the resource which is consistent with other state resource based legislation. It provides a balanced approach to private land access and recognises and clarifies the rights of authority or tenure holders and landholders in relation to access to private land for resource related activities.

I look forward to seeing the wise management of the industry, but the protection of the environment must come first and foremost. I also look forward to the promotion of competition so that the industry can grow and create jobs in the future and help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms MALE (Pine Rivers--ALP) (9.22 pm): I rise this evening to support the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010. This bill amends a number of existing acts such as the Petroleum and Gas (Production and Safety) Act 2004, the Electricity Act 1994, the Mineral Resources Act 1989 and the Timber Utilisation and Marketing Act 1987. I will confine my remarks to the geothermal energy aspect of this bill.

This bill has been designed to establish a framework to encourage and facilitate the safe production of geothermal energy to accelerate the expansion of the renewable energy sector in Queensland. Geothermal energy or ‘hot rocks’ energy is a virtually CO 2 emission-free energy source that has the potential to produce more baseload energy than any other single source of renewable energy. It is for this reason that we need to get the balance right. I will speak tonight about the land access provisions, as this is usually one of the most contentious parts of energy exploration and provision.

The bill contains landmark amendments to the way resource tenure and authority holders access private land and how compensation arrangements are arrived at. These amendments are essential due to the increase in interaction and conflict between rural landholders and tenure or authority holders for land use, particularly in the light of the continued strong growth in coal seam gas and coal exploration and development across the state. The new land access provisions will make it easier for private landholders and mining and petroleum companies to deal with the complexities and challenges caused by overlapping activities by providing a uniform framework for land access and compensation across all resources legislation.

The key elements of the Land Access Policy Framework reflected in the bill include: a single Land Access Code of Conduct, with all tenure and authority holders required to comply with the code; a notice of entry process for designated ‘preliminary activities’ that will have little or no impact on landholders; a requirement to make a conduct and compensation agreement prior to entry of land for advanced activities that are likely to significantly impact the landholder; graduated negotiation and dispute resolution processes to remedy disputes; and improved compliance and enforcement processes for administering the code of conduct.

The bill introduces activity thresholds that increase the level of regulation as the intensity or impact of the proposed activity increases. This is a sensible measure that balances the level of regulation with the level of impact. Early exploration activities can have nil or negligible impact on private landholders. The bill defines these as ‘preliminary activities’ which might include taking rock, water or soil samples and walking the land. For preliminary activities, resource authority or tenure holders must give each owner and occupier of land within the tenure or authority area an entry notice and a copy of the land access code at least 10 days prior to entry. Access for these activities does not require a conduct and compensation agreement.

Correspondingly, when the impacts are more significant on the private landholder or occupier, a higher level of accord is required. These activities are referred to as ‘advanced activities’. For advanced activities, tenure holders must be party to a conduct and compensation agreement with each eligible claimant for the land. Where agreement is not reached, the framework provides mediation mechanisms. To assist in the negotiation process, a standard conduct and compensation agreement template has been developed in consultation with resource and agriculture industry peak bodies, along with a negotiation tip sheet for landholders.

The land access amendments introduce an innovative new requirement for mediation to occur between parties if agreement negotiations break down. This has been included on the basis that all stakeholders have expressed a desire to keep these matters out of the Land Court and to use all means to negotiate a mutually acceptable outcome for both parties. Matters cannot be referred to the Land Court for determination until mediation has occurred. A detailed compliance and enforcement strategy will be developed to ensure that these new measures achieve their full effect on the ground, particularly with respect to the land access code. This bill is an important step in the ongoing viability of the renewable energy sector, and I therefore commend the bill to the House.

Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (9.26 pm): I am pleased to make this short contribution to the Geothermal Energy Bill 2010 and, in so doing, I commend the shadow minister for natural resources, mines and energy for his particularly good analysis of this very large bill. But, in saying that, it is also a very important bill.

Geothermal energy is one of the more latent energy sources that has now been realised, and progress is being realised to harness its power. Although geothermal energy is not a major contributor to world energy sources, its use is increasing. I have no doubt it is going to increase a lot further. I think we are at the base of what hopefully will become a very exciting industry.

The Birdsville geothermal power station utilises wet geothermal energy. This provides part of the electricity requirements for the town of Birdsville. I have no doubt that this is where geothermal energy will come into its own--in areas where other energy sources are far more difficult to access.

In addition to these known resources in the south-west of the state, the Coastal Geothermal Energy Initiative will be investigating additional sources of hot rocks for geothermal energy close to existing transmission lines. There are 38 reported potential geothermal targets identified in eastern Queensland. The Coastal Geothermal Energy Initiative underway will report on the geothermal potential of eastern Queensland and provide potential targets to industry for future potential exploration.

This technology may well go some way to ensuring that we are working towards emission-free power. However, it has to be undertaken in a planned, methodical manner. With respect, this bill is laying the foundations for that. Whilst investigation of these future potential energy sources is encouraging, the effects on the land and interaction with affected landholders and those adjoining must be considered, and a proven and workable co-existence must be worked through.

Over the past few months we have witnessed a breakdown in clear communication and questionable process with regard to, amongst other things, underground coal gasification, particularly in the Darling Downs region. There have been numerous documented concerns from farmers and graziers directly affected by the poor processes in place. At this stage, I note that, as third-generation landholders ourselves and our sons as fourth-generation landholders who have coal seam gas exploration activities going on across their property, I can certainly say that we are experiencing this firsthand and from a family perspective we are working through many of these issues.

It is noted in the objectives of the bill relating to both geothermal energy and land access that there are many common traits. These relate to improved relations and constructive consultation between affected parties such as resource companies and landholders. In many ways, this is an admission that the present government has acknowledged a need to improve on its processes and work more constructively with landowners. This aspect is to be endorsed and welcomed.

We have to remember that the agricultural sector is still a very important primary industry that Queensland relies on. Queensland relies very heavily on its agricultural resources together with the burgeoning resource sector. As we know, this is the powerhouse of Queensland, but we must protect it into the future.

There is an accepted need to ensure planned and controlled resource growth. All Queenslanders would acknowledge a need to keep pace with a sustainable demand for minerals and other such resources within the state. The need for people within these industries to have a balanced framework to co-exist has never been greater. This is an area that will have to be looked at very closely in the next few years.

The retention of agricultural land now and into the future is also critical. I think it is crunch time now in terms of looking at the preservation of agricultural land. Until this point in time this has not been an issue. Now it is definitely coming forward as an issue.

The LNP takes a strong stance with regard to the protection of prime agricultural land. Agriculture is the cornerstone of the Queensland economy, as are the minerals industry and the underground coal gasification industry. Protection of our agricultural land has to be balanced with the needs of the resource industry. Agriculture needs to be acknowledged and protected as the economy diversifies and builds.

Within the LNP’s policy on the protection of prime agricultural land there are five key planks. One of those is the charter of property rights which impacts on this issue. We will entrench in law a charter of property rights that will legally guarantee the rights of private property owners, whether they are householders in an urban area or primary producers in a rural area. The charter will ensure that all government policy relating to land and water rights is basically based on science and not on politics or hearsay. The charter will legally enshrine compensation for landholders whose pre-existing rights are diminished perhaps as a result of government policy.

With regard to protecting prime agricultural land, the LNP made a commitment in March 2009 that it would protect prime agricultural land from mining. The LNP recognises the long-term need to preserve prime farmland for continued agriculture throughout Queensland and to protect it from mining, urban development and other incompatible uses. We keep in mind the major importance of our resource industry.

This issue is fundamental to many areas but is especially relevant to the Burdekin electorate. The Burdekin electorate is blessed with fertile soils in the Bowen and Gumlu areas. They are a food bowl for horticulture produce. I add that these areas are bracing for the impact of the seedling poisoning that occurred in June of this year. Disappointingly, a couple of weeks ago we had a very heavy storm that virtually wiped out huge crops of corn in the Bowen area. From an agricultural perspective, Bowen is doing it very tough at the moment.

The area of the Burdekin delta is very fortunate because it does have an abundant water supply that ensures a consistently high tonnage of sugarcane together with many other varieties of horticultural produce. Added to this, there is prime grazing land for cattle production from the Collinsville region north. Collinsville is a mining region. We are seeing new coalmines spring up there. There is also a great deal of coal seam gas exploration underway in that area.

I have talked to a lot of landholders who are frustrated and concerned about the negotiations and working with these companies. With respect, I acknowledge that the majority of our resource companies are very sensitive and are aware of the impact they have on existing landholders. For most of us, having strangers come into our front garden and dig holes in our front garden would be very difficult to handle when looking at it from an urban perspective. I think it must be acknowledged how very difficult it is for landowners, for farmers, for graziers to appreciate what is occurring when it comes to land access issues.

Another facet of the legislation is the rural water advisory panel. The LNP believes that no individual group or community should have their water access or reliability negatively affected by coal seam gas or underground coal gasification development. This is a very serious issue. Certain recent events have started to show how important this is. If their water access or reliability is negatively affected there must be an absolute obligation to ensure that the original landowners do not suffer loss and that their interests are repaired.

The issue of land access can be quite daunting and confronting to landowners. The majority of these people have put their heart and soul into building up their properties, which may have been in the family for generations. As I said earlier, I can relate to that because I look at my sons who are fourth-generation farmers and graziers. It is one of those things that builds up and is accepted as part of the family.

Consultation by resource companies needs to be genuine. There needs to be understanding and empathy for the affected landholders. There needs to be an acknowledgement as part of the land access issue that tracts of land are also being withdrawn from production due to rail lines linking the existing and new mines to the eastern seaboard.

Within the Burdekin electorate we are seeing a lot of new mines under development that are negotiating for land right now. Rail lines are to be laid to deliver this revenue source to Abbot Point for export. It is worthy to note that the Hancock line is certainly underway. It goes right through the Burdekin electorate. Waratah Coal has also started negotiations and consultation processes. There seems to be the possibility that two railway lines will go through. That will take up a lot of land and will involve a lot of landowners.

It is very daunting for those landowners. One property owner said to me that their property has had a large piece taken out for a coalmine, it has coal seam gas exploration work going on right across it and now it has a railway line cutting through major paddocks. This man looked at me and said, ‘I just wanted to be a grazier. I just wanted to run a grazing property.’ When we think about what has happened to that property we can understand the difficulties they are facing. They may be getting compensation but it also affects the long-term value of that land. I appreciate that the government is also acknowledging that in this bill.

Consultation by resource companies needs to be genuine, with understanding and empathy. There needs to be an acknowledgement, as part of the land access, that this land is being withdrawn from production. As I said, rail lines are being built to deliver the revenue source to Abbot Point for export. The net result in most cases is a considerable impost for graziers as they see their properties divided. This also creates a host of management issues that will be ongoing. These rail corridors will cause concerns in terms of accessing adjoining parts of the property, increased potential for fires from trains, and noise and dust issues. The potential of fires caused by trains is a big issue and certainly something that my area has seen given the dry conditions. Resource companies need to be sympathetic to these realities and need to be willing to fully compensate for those imposts for the mutual benefit that will be realised from the arrangement and a symbiotic relationship has to be built and developed.

The areas for compensation within this bill need to be wide ranging and include such aspects specifically as the depravation of possession of surface of land--that is, the actual depravation to the owner in that loss of land which, even though it may only be a significantly small amount of land, can have a huge impact on the overall value and the overall productivity of that property. As a result, we are seeing a diminution in the value of that land. When that goes down, that is like a slap in the face. We are also seeing a loss of the use of the land and the improvements. We are seeing severance and any cost or loss incurred from the conduct of the resource operations.

The land access objective to facilitate improved relations between resource companies and landholders is to be welcomed and is well overdue given many of the recent issues. The next objective to provide a consistent, transparent and equitable process to facilitate access of private land for authorised activities will also be welcomed to provide a consistent approach to these dealings and will protect the best of intentions by the two parties. There needs to be a credible consistent process to ensure workable outcomes. The last objective is to provide clear dispute resolution, compliance and enforcement processes and powers, with legal proceedings considered only as a last resort. Hopefully they will be needed and used in isolated cases. I am aware that the minister has quite a broad range of amendments to this bill. I support the shadow minister’s stand on this bill.

Mrs PRATT (Nanango--Ind) (9.42 pm): I rise to speak to the Geothermal Energy Bill. I have to say at the outset that there is a lot in this bill that I find very easy to support, especially with regard to the property rights of landholders. Over the last 12 years I have been involved in many incidents where people’s properties have been taken over by mining companies, roads, possible rail corridors, transmission lines et cetera. I have been involved with those people who have felt the angst in these kinds of situations. Some members in this place have possibly smiled or even laughed at the fact that people are going through this and say that they understand what those people are going through. The majority of people in this House cannot understand what it is like to have someone come onto your property and virtually shut your activity down--something that you, your father, your grandfather and everybody else have worked for all their lives. It is a very difficult situation and everybody in this House should try to recognise that.

In this bill the minister is trying to at least make up for the shortfalls of the previous legislation by increasing compensation. Many aspects that the minister has included in this legislation with regard to paying legal costs et cetera have been done by Tarong Energy. If any mining company has endeavoured to do the right thing on many occasions, it has been Tarong Energy. However, it has still fallen short for many people and there is still a lot of unfairness in the whole situation that people have to go through. For instance, how can the value of a property in Kingaroy be compared to a property in Chinchilla and therefore a reasonable price paid for a property? It does not happen like that. It is just not the way it should be done. The value of a property to an individual cannot be overestimated when it has been generational or they have planted a vineyard and after 20 or 30 years they have achieved a really good wine. Nobody can put a price on that sort of thing, but Tarong Energy has at least endeavoured to come to the party.

Geothermal or hot rock energy could very well be the way to go, and it is admirable that any government is looking for better, cleaner and greener types of energy. We hear the phrase ‘cleaner and greener’ types of energy being bandied around as if to say that because we put a green and a clean on it it automatically is clean and green. I bring to the parliament’s attention once again that they said that UCG was clean and green and they sold it to our community of Kingaroy on the basis that it was clean and it was green. In the last few months it has been proven that it is far from clean and green. Regardless of whether someone believes one part per billion or 100 parts per billion is acceptable, we do not. It is contamination. There is contamination where there was no contamination before. Regardless of whether it is still within the Australian drinking standards, it is still contamination. It is not acceptable, and UCG is not one of those technologies that should be pursued.

I am going to oppose this bill not because it is full of bad things, because it is not, but because it does not curb UCG. That is why I will be opposing this bill. The Kingaroy and the South Burnett area have dodged a bullet--literally. It could have been a heck of a lot worse. I know that the minister has visited the area, and it was good that he came to the area when invited to talk to people. Like most government bodies, all of the right things were said. The minister said that he would look into it and there will be an investigation. The Minister for Sustainability did the same thing, and I also commend her for her interest. But the people in my community do not want this to be a whitewash. We do not want this technology in its current form to go ahead anywhere else in Queensland, because no community should be subjected to this kind of concern.

If one reads all of the documentation dealing with UCG it is well known--all the experts agree--that contamination will occur. It is recommended that UCG be conducted away from populations, away from watercourse and underground water, and away from good arable land, yet here it is smack bang in the South Burnett on some of the most prime agricultural land in the state on top of a hill which can lead to the main water supply of Kingaroy. Luckily it has not this time, and we will be fighting to ensure that there is no next time. I believe that the minister is aware of the concerns that the potential is there and I hope that when the expert panel comes to Kingaroy on 25 August it will know and understand that this UCG industry was in the wrong place.

Hot rock or geothermal might very well be the perfect energy in the right place, but UCG is not. I would like to know if anybody here in this room is a mining engineer, a geophysicist or a chemist? Do members know terms such as coal pyrolysis in UCG or what it is? Do members know and understand the very complicated heterogeneous chemical kinetic reaction processes that occur when you burn the coal? I will bet you 10 to a dozen that there is not one person in here who knows that, but by God I am learning these terminologies and I am understanding them. The more I learn the more concerns I have. This government needs to recognise these terms. Do the people on the expert panel know these things? Do the people who back all of these new technologies understand them? It is a difficult task for anyone in this House to grasp the concept of all the technologies that will be involved in the future, whether they be for energy or any other form. It is a big game of Russian roulette that we play with our communities and I hope my community will not get the bullet.

So let us go geothermal if it is the right way to go, if it is going to be the one that works and achieves the goal that we want of not harming the earth in any possible way. If that is the way to go, let us pursue it. I hear the LNP members stand up one after the other and say how they have a policy that will protect agricultural land and that they will be supporting this bill. They, too, have also talked about UCG and its possible effects in the future. But I have not yet heard one of them say that they will oppose it until all the kinks are ironed out. I have not heard one say, ‘We will put it way out where there is no population, where there is no underground water and there is no good-quality land.’ They have not said that yet. They can say one thing and they can talk to farmers out the front of parliament when they are protesting and say, ‘We will do this and we will do that’ but they do almost the total opposite when they are in this House. That is something the people are seeing more and more of. They cannot just talk the talk and not walk the walk. They will get found out in the long run.

I know that this bill will pass and I have to agree that it is probably the better way to go. But it is also a way for me to express the concerns of my community. I know all the members smile and shake their heads, but people live in my community. There are so many questions that have to be asked when it comes to mining. As I said, I am not opposed to mining. I am not opposed to new technologies. Not very long ago I fought very hard to keep 400-plus jobs in my area when it was reported that the Meandu mine was about to close. I know the value of mining and I know the value of it to communities and governments. I know we cannot turn back the clock. I would like to see all open-cut mines disappear in the future. But I do not want the technology that we are investigating to be detrimental to any community in Queensland. It is just not worth it.
Everyone has heard about Acland and the mine that has swallowed that particular town. That will forever be a disgrace.
Mr Shine: It was set up as a mining town. It was a mining town always.

Mrs PRATT: Mr Beutel is out there now all by himself. He has been fighting to protect the memorial park there and the things that his mother has done. Whether it was set up as a mining town in the first place, it is still sad to see a community just disappear off the face of the earth.

I have seen how mining companies work. I have seen how they pick off what they would deem the easy pickings and buy properties one by one. They will take one particular gentleman who has the worst possible country and pay him an excellent price. He had 13 acres. He now has roughly 150 acres. That is what mining companies do. They pick them off. They give this fellow a really good deal and hold out on the ones who have prime-quality country. They pay this man a very bad price and this man right next door a top price. There is no fairness in it and I do not know how you legislate for that type of fairness. I would imagine that it is one of the most difficult things to do.

I have had people crying in my office. I have heard people accuse the state government and mining interests of killing their father because the stress was too much. I have seen it all. I know that they are all emotive things and we should not base things on emotive issues but on facts. But the fact is that there are places in Queensland where mining should not be conducted. This new technology is not proven in Queensland. It is not actually proven anywhere in the world yet. If one person can tell me of one UCG project in the world that is successful, by all means tell me, because the group of people who are fighting UCG have not yet found it. I have asked and I have asked and I have asked for months for an example. Not one has come forward. When you look up the pilot plants that are starting in America and China, what do they refer to? They refer to a successful operation in Chinchilla. That is their example. How can we claim that this is a successful project in Queensland? Yes, we are dabbling with it and they are pilot programs, but they all appear to have problems. But what is even worse is that, when they do have problems, there is such a long delay in reporting it.

I have mentioned before that when Cougar Energy did their burn Len Walker, their CEO--I think that is his title--said at the meeting at Kingaroy, and the minister was there, that he expects that the crack and the blockage occurred between 20 March to the end of March, in that time period. It was nearly 3 months before we got anything into the public arena.
So is geothermal the way to go? Perhaps. However, UCG is not. But geothermal has everybody’s hopes. We have seen it around the world. We have seen it in New Zealand. It works--

Mr Shine:
It will make our electricity.

Mrs PRATT: I am not a mathematician but I know that I pay a flipping lot now for electricity and so does everybody else. It has gone up sky high. The truth is that we can explore other technologies but not in areas where there are people. We can explore where it is recommended by CSIRO, not where there are people, not where there is underground water and watercourses and not where there is good arable land. We all know that Australia has so much unusable land and so little arable land, or usable land, and that land is mainly on the coastal fringes. It is negligent of us to waste one acre of that land. It is negligent of us not to utilise it to its best use, which is to feed the people of this country and perhaps other countries of the world as their populations grow and their demand becomes greater and greater.

I know that this is probably not the way to go, but I would get down on my knees and beg that the minister not set up these plants anywhere near communities if I had to. If he would put on hold any future exploration with UCG--until its safety can be guaranteed, and that is not something that anyone is prepared to do--I would be grateful. We have spoken to Len Walker and many people around the world and every single person has said that contamination will occur. It is true that with any mining there will be contamination, but we cannot afford to have contamination in our watercourses.

When we asked the people who spoke to us how they would deal with contamination they said the likelihood of it is so minuscule that they had not actually thought about it. That is not a good answer. That is a fail in anyone’s book. How does one clean up a watertable? How does one clean up the cavity that is left behind? We say: show us. People are willing to look at the information, but we cannot find anything that says UCG is effective or that the mess can be cleaned up. They tell me that hot rock therapy is good. Maybe it will be the best way to go for our country, but I beg all members not to play Russian roulette with the people of any community because not one of them deserves to have their life, their livelihood or their children’s future gambled with.

I will be opposing this bill. I will not oppose it because it is a bad bill; I believe it has a lot of good. I would have embraced it, and probably the minister too, if he had just said that he was going to hold back UCG until it was better regulated, better monitored and that there would be severe punishment for anyone who failed to comply with government legislation.
Debate, on motion of Mrs Pratt, adjourned.

Mr SPEAKER: This morning I ruled the notice of motion given by the honourable member for Burnett out of order, but invited the honourable member to redraft the notice of motion and provide authentication of the facts to me to consider further. The honourable member for Burnett has now provided me with authentication of fact and has amended his notice of motion, to which I have agreed.
Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (10.02 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs MENKENS (Burdekin--LNP) (10.02 pm): Seniors Week is a good opportunity to recognise the efforts, achievements and needs of seniors in our community, a chance to say thankyou and to highlight what needs to be done to help ageing Queenslanders. Today I applaud our seniors and recognise the amazing contributions they make on a daily basis to their families, their communities and to our state.

Sadly, year after year the Bligh Labor government misses this opportunity and consistently fails not only to recognise the needs of seniors but also to implement any way of gauging and hearing those needs. It is time the minister moved beyond catchphrases and condescension in dealing with seniors and started implementing some active programs for advocacy and political facilitation. At a time when older women represent the new face of homelessness, elder abuse is rising by 20 per cent a year and the rising costs of living are hurting more and more pensioners and retirees, the need for a political voice for seniors has never been stronger. The red tape facing our community organisations, changing family structures and consequent responsibilities that fall to seniors, transport, health, isolation and employment are issues that are facing seniors. Every community concern is a seniors’ concern. The perspective is the difference. We as a community desperately need a place in government that notes and listens to that perspective.

After another year of rhetoric, what has been achieved for seniors? One document, which would be better entitled ‘Positively Aimless’, a compilation of catchphrases that was remarkably devoid of any new initiatives or ideas, no new programs and tiny funding increases. To find that out, seniors had to wade through pages of glossy condescension and phrases like ‘treasuring wise gems’ and ‘hippy hippy shake’. Seniors deserve better than what this government is prepared to give. They do not want to be told how to age, they do not want to be told what to believe. They want a fair voice and representation in the political process. That means consideration of their needs in policy making, advocacy for the rights of seniors and opportunities to have their input and their opinions heard.

Seniors have been acknowledged in the federal arena with the Liberal National Party promising to deliver a minister for ageing and seniors, specifically giving older Australians a voice in the political process. Another initiative that I applaud is the Seniors Employment Incentive Payments to help seniors who want to return to work. So many older Queenslanders who have faced redundancy find it hard to re-enter the workforce. They have so much to offer, their experience is irreplaceable, yet they still find it difficult to return to the workforce. A raft of other initiatives, including financial measures and helping improve the safety of seniors in their homes and communities, highlight the need for political priority and variety in helping to improve the quality of life for our senior Queenslanders. So who can we say is a senior Queenslander? A senior is a person who has built up the wisdom and experience of the years.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP) (10.05 pm): At 57 Billington Street, Labrador there is a little building that offers to families living in Labrador and surrounding suburbs a range of services. It is the Labrador Child and Family Centre. Formerly the United Church building, the $3 million Labrador Child and Family Centre will help improve the lives of local families with children. The centre has been made possible through the Queensland government’s Community Renewal Program and supports the Toward Q2: Tomorrow’s Queensland strategy of building fairer, healthier communities.

I had the great pleasure of representing the Minister for Communities, Karen Struthers, in officially opening the centre some months ago. Recently I revisited the centre to find the centre coordinator, Brooke Hughes, busily working with local mums delivering the centre’s busy schedule of activities and programs. I was pleased to see the centre’s weekly timetable is full of programs for mums and bubs, allocating times for counselling and family support worker availability. There is a playgroup, a read and grow program for children aged 0 to 5, an intergenerational craft group and mums and bubs yoga. On Wednesday mornings new mums and dads have access to the child health nurse clinics, when the wonderful nurses from the Labrador Child Health Centre located on Frank Street come to the centre to conduct weekly weighing of newborns, health checks and offer feeding and parenting advice, a service that I can personally recommend.

The facility has a large covered veranda and an outdoor play area for children and landscaping that has been enhanced by a great big sandpit that was kindly built by the gentlemen from the nearby Men’s Shed. The Men’s Shed was officially opened last week and I would like to congratulate this group on their fantastic efforts. With 90 members signed up there will be lots of sawing, hammering and sanding going on as they make children’s toys and work on a range of special projects.

The Labrador Child and Family Centre was developed in partnership with local residents, the Gold Coast City Council and other government and community agencies. It is this collaborative and integrated approach that enables the centre to be the hub of activity, support, services, connectivity, gathering and improved outcomes for young families and their children. I would like to acknowledge Lifeline Gold Coast, ACT for Kids, FSG Australia, Labrador Primary School, Kalwun Development Corporation and Playgroup Queensland for partnering with the Benevolent Society. The Labrador Child and Family Centre has been created as a model of best practice for the Gold Coast and has been set up as a collaborative multifunctional community hub. I encourage Labrador residents to pop by the centre and have a look inside and pick up a timetable of the activities on offer.

As the local member I am pleased to see the Labrador area benefit from the state government’s community renewal funding through a project that will continue to provide critical support to those who need it and positive outcomes for local families.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (10.08 pm): Nowhere are current hardships experienced by the unemployed and low-income workers being felt more than in my electorate of Gaven. If the walls of my office could tell stories, you would hear tales of people facing constant struggles to obtain food or housing and relying on local groups to provide them with assistance. To illustrate the difficulties, one has to look no further than the Nerang Neighbourhood Centre, which runs a food bank for the needy. Only last year the food bank was providing 12 boxes of food per week, but this has skyrocketed to 120 boxes a week. The centre is in the process of seeking funding to start a Get Set for Work program in Nerang to improve the job prospects of many of these people living off Centrelink payments. There are 2,653 people in the Gaven electorate currently receiving jobseeker Centrelink benefits, and this number increased in June by about four per cent.

People are doing it tough on the coast. Just recently I had a couple who live in rented accommodation with their three children come to my office desperate for social housing because of their worsening financial situation. One of the really sad points about their visit was that one of the partners was morbidly obese and had wanted to have lap band surgery but they could no longer afford to have health insurance to cover the operation. They told me that they had to stop paying their home, contents and car insurance as well. They had expenses of $2,427 a fortnight and were receiving income of $1,762, made up of Centrelink payments and a Defence Service pension. Despite living in the same rental accommodation for the past 18 months, their finances had become an intolerable burden and they could no longer afford their medications or the $500 they had budgeted for food. They were paying $520 a week for rented housing. These are normal costs on the coast. Because of the enormous shortage of housing on the Gold Coast they were having extreme problems finding something cheaper. Similarly, a father of two children came to my office desperate for assistance. He said that he could either feed his children on the streets or keep them under a roof without food.

Small businesses are also doing it really tough on the Coast. Unemployment in the construction industry is forcing tradespeople to leave in droves to find work in other areas, and this causes further downward pressure on spending. Our local Nerang chamber of commerce has reported that small business sales are down between 15 and 20 per cent. For example, a respectable tiling business in Nerang has been operating for 40 years and they have never seen it so tough before. They are not sure how much longer they will survive in this environment. Honourable members will hear this story over and over again. The flow-on effect of this struggle leaves small business owners in dire situations. They are forced to reduce staffing hours, creating even more underemployment for residents, and the owners find themselves working 80 hours a week just to support their families. They are in a pressure cooker just to make ends meet. This is coupled with the constant rise in the cost of living and can lead to severe mental health and stress related problems.

Small business is at the heart of the economy and holds the key to delivering jobs to people across my electorate of Gaven. We must be working towards smaller government, less red tape and lower taxes to give small businesses the fuel they need not only to survive but also to flourish in undoubtedly one of the best places in the world to live.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Burleigh Heads; Gold Coast Quota Club; Burleigh Community Consultative Committee
XML.Hansard-Body: Mrs SMITH (Burleigh--ALP) (10.12 pm): Burleigh Heads must be one of the most beautiful and family-friendly destinations in Queensland. Nearly every visitor I speak to has a memory of coming to Burleigh as a child with their family, on their honeymoon or just for a break and they are now back with their families. But not everyone in Burleigh is on holidays. We have a large resident population who call Burleigh home. There are those who have lived here all their lives and those who have come just recently, but every one of them intends for Burleigh to become their permanent home.

A community is more than a group of people; it is a living, breathing, caring neighbourhood--a place where we know the families living next door or across the road, where we care what happens to the single parent with small children or the widowed person down the road. I am proud to say that Burleigh has all of this and more.

The Gold Coast Quota Club has launched a reading program involving students at Varsity Junior College. The program, called QuoCKa--Quota, Cops and Kids--aims to bring police, children and members of the community in a unified, positive framework reading together to demonstrate to young children that the police and the wider community are there to help and support them. To see a police officer sitting down reading with a six-year-old is priceless, and the school community is very excited with the program. I congratulate Quota on this initiative.

Since uniformed police officers were returned to Burleigh on a trial basis, Inspector Des Lacy reported that there was a 40 per cent drop in reports of property crime and a 45 per cent drop in reports of crimes against individuals. Residents tell me that they feel safer just seeing the police in their area. I thank Assistant Commissioner Paul Wilson and the officer in charge of Palm Beach Police Station, Senior Sergeant Chris Ahearn, for their support and willingness to undertake this trial. I think they would agree it has paid off.

We have now formed our own Burleigh Community Consultative Committee. The first meeting saw 60 people attend. Six months later we are still averaging 40 people at each meeting. The police are committed to ongoing public engagement to identify new and effective measures to keep our communities safe. The chairperson, Margie Gardner, and secretary, Dan Byron, work tirelessly to make the meetings relevant and ensure that participants’ concerns are heard and addressed by the police officers present. Dan Byron, by the way, is the candidate for the McPherson federal division. Refurbishment of the Burleigh Heads police complex is about to start and I look forward, once completed, to a full complement of police being permanently stationed at Burleigh Heads.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (10.15 pm): The economic lifeblood of my community is small business. I never fail to be amazed by the enthusiasm, energy and commitment displayed by the small business operators. Unfortunately, I also hear a growing level of frustration and that frustration is fuelled by the increasing burden of having to comply with more and more regulations.

Queensland businesses have to deal with 70,000 pages of often turgid and sometimes meaningless compliance regulations. In contrast, the state of New South Wales, with a larger population, has about 40,000 pages. So while Queensland has fewer people, it has almost twice the number of pages of regulations as New South Wales. It also has many thousands more--and in some cases 10,000 more--pages of regulations than Victoria and Western Australia. These regulations tend to strangle enterprise and initiative by small business. It is estimated that they are costing Queensland businesses almost $18 billion a year because owners, managers and senior staff are forced to spend an average 10 hours a week and more than 20 days a year coping with red tape.

Having run my own business for five years before entering parliament, I understand the challenges of coping with this red tape. Unfortunately, there seems to be little understanding of business from the state government considering the skyrocketing cost of compliance. The difficulty with red tape is that, while each individual regulation can normally be justified by government as being in the public interest, when we add all these individual regulations together it creates a regime that works against business growth and employment. If small businesses were freed of unnecessary red tape, they would be able to put a greater focus on servicing customers and employing more staff.

Government needs to be committed to cutting red tape and unnecessary compliance costs to give Queensland small businesses the best chance of succeeding, and that will give Queensland the best chance of lifting its economic performance. Government needs to go beyond rhetoric and achieve real regulatory reform rather than grow the regulatory burden. It needs to systematically reduce the 70,000 pages of regulation and set achievable targets to do so. I believe it can start by committing that for every page of new or amended legislation which is passed in our state two pages of old laws are repealed. This is a straightforward approach that would force governments to put as much effort into ridding small business of useless, redundant and unnecessary old laws and regulations as it does into creating new ones.

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP) (10.17 pm): This is a very special week in which a spotlight is thrown on a very special sector of our society. Yes, it is Seniors Week. I have heard a few interpretations of the week’s theme ‘Positively ageless’, but I would like to think that it means you are only as old as your attitude to life, and the more our seniors get involved with their communities through volunteering or social interaction the more positively ageless they become.

Last week I had the privilege meeting hundreds of wonderful seniors from right across my electorate. More often than not they are just like me, juggling a number of commitments on any given day as they find time to contribute to organisations like CWA, ESA, Fauna Rescue, older women’s belly-dancing groups or community visitor groups. I am amazed at the energy and dedication of seniors in my electorate who give so much back to our community. That is why this year I held two Seniors Week events to acknowledge and celebrate the contribution of seniors.

The first was in Proserpine and targeted those seniors who volunteer their time to a service or charitable organisation, and what a great morning we had. Morning tea was followed by a very special fashion parade featuring clothes from our local Lifeline store. This was a great event, and I thank my special models for their bravery in strutting their stuff in the Lifeline fashions. They looked fantastic in a range of modern and often designer label clothes that were all available for sale at Lifeline. They did a roaring trade that day and I think we were all amazed at just what value for money these stores provide.

We were also very pleased to welcome the local fauna rescue group to our morning tea and, of course, we all fell in love with the baby possum. They were hoping to enlist some new volunteers to help host the birds and animals that come their way for care. I really commend the fauna rescue members who take on injured native animals and nurture them back to health and, hopefully, to release. The regime of feeding baby animals can be more demanding than feeding a human baby, so it is a job that takes some commitment but you can tell that it is all worthwhile.

My second seniors forum was held in Mackay and was generously hosted by Breezes lifestyle village. I was delighted to welcome the Minister for Community Services, Karen Struthers, as special guest for this event. She very graciously gave of her time to chat with my guests and provide them with some very useful information about the services available for seniors. I was also pleased to welcome representatives from the Department of Communities and fair trading, as well as the Office of the Public Trustee and representatives from various HACC and other health organisations. We had a lovely morning and, as I did then, I say ‘thank you’ to all of our wonderful, positively ageless seniors for their amazing contribution to society.

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP) (10.19 pm): Seniors Week is an important time in the Redlands for the various groups that represent our senior citizens and that run events. Seniors Week is important as it gives us the opportunity to acknowledge the significant contribution that seniors make to our local community. Yesterday, Monday 16 August, I joined Sallyanne Atkinson, a former lord mayor of Brisbane, at a U3A breakfast at the Donald Simpson Centre in Cleveland. In her speech she highlighted some of the issues confronting seniors in the transition to the senior years. She also referred to a question that I had asked her prior to giving her speech. The question was, ‘What are you doing with yourself these days’? Sallyanne said that she had been Australia’s senior trade commissioner to France, a representative to the International Chamber of Commerce and various other things. Sallyanne described the activities in her senior years as a ‘portfolio’ of activities. She further explained that sometimes this innocent question--what are you doing these days--may inadvertently be interpreted as a question about an individual’s worth in the community.

I acknowledge the work of various seniors groups in my electorate: the University of the Third Age, the Donald Simpson Centre, the National Seniors Association, the Redlands District Committee on the Ageing, the Redlands RSL, Rotary and Lions clubs, Probus, the Wellington Point and Cleveland bowls clubs and others. The work of those groups is particularly significant as the Redlands is home to a higher than average proportion of senior citizens. I acknowledge the good work of the Redlands U3A, Ted Grant, Julie Porteous, John Butters, other leaders and many volunteer tutors who freely give of their time to share their expertise and talents with others. U3A provides members with affordable education and the opportunity to study and learn in a relaxed environment.

I acknowledge the amazing work of Ernie Harrison and the Donald Simpson Centre. Ernie has built a fantastic centre that provides various activities for seniors such as Matildas Quilters, music appreciation, Out With A Difference, Spanish classes, the stroke support group, the theatrical group and Walkers for Health. It was a pleasure to be invited to the recent breakfast and to see the new bus stop that we worked hard to get being put to good use. I look forward to returning this Friday with Rosemary Menkens to meet many more wonderful Cleveland senior citizens. I also pay tribute to other key seniors in the Redlands: June Craven continues to raise much needed funds for the Cancer Council, 107-year-old Edith MacFarlane after whom a department of housing complex was named, 103-year-old Olive Webber who still performs at seniors concerts, Aunty Margaret and Uncle Pat Iselin of the Minjerribah North Stradbroke Island elders, to name but a few.

I close by raising one issue that has put a slight damper on Seniors Week in the Redlands. For some reason, unbeknown to me and Redlands seniors, in 2009 and 2010 funding to Redlands seniors groups to run events during Seniors Week seems to have evaporated. I ask the minister to look into this and to provide some assistance.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP) (10.23 pm): I rise to speak on something that has been very topical tonight, which is Seniors Week. Seniors often go unrecognised for the significant role that they play in shaping the generations that follow them. This week is Seniors Week, giving us a chance to acknowledge the special contribution that seniors make to our communities. In the electorate of Everton I have been delighted to be able to present the Everton Senior Heroes Awards for a second year to a group of very deserving community elders. I regularly meet with Everton seniors and in the past week I have celebrated Seniors Week with dozens more.

This year 15 awards were given out to the Everton senior heroes. The five winners from the Albany Creek Aveo retirement village were Shirley Whittaker, for organising many trips for the residents at Aveo; Marilyn White, for her hard work organising functions and as a coordinator of the activities committee; Marilyn’s husband Tom White, for being able to help out with committee finances and resolving various organisational problems; Les Ambor, for the many hours he puts into the finance committee; and Elizabeth Eardley, for running the village library, which I was privileged to tour when I was at Aveo last week. Ann Cavallaro, while not a resident at Aveo, was also honoured for her religious education work in local schools.

Another nine winners received their awards at the Mitchelton and District Senior Citizens Club yesterday. They were Pat Stephenson, for her 18 years of service on the club management committee; Ann Howie and Nola Attwood, for teaching migrants conversational English for over 10 years; Beverley Bell, for her religious education teaching at Albany Creek State School since 1993; Colleen Chalk, for her service to Neighbourhood Watch Stafford; Allen Tomes, for his volunteer work with Reach Out Community and Family Care in Everton Park; Jan Neville, for her work with Mitchelton Meals on Wheels since 1997; Ian Turner, for his religious education teaching at Albany Hills State School and his service to the Knights of the Southern Cross; and Des Miles, for his 50 years of service to the local soccer community as a referee and referee coach. I congratulate all 15 Everton senior heroes and thank them for their contribution to our community.

The Bligh government is helping seniors with many rebates and subsidies, including sizable increases to the rebates on electricity and water in this year’s state budget. In addition, this year we have released the Positively Ageless strategy, which outlines a range of new measures to help seniors. We are creating opportunities for grandparents who are raising grandchildren to have time out. We are highlighting the sad occurrence of elder abuse as a means of stamping it out. We are allocating funding to provide nutritional information for frail older people and service providers. We are assisting the University of the Third Age to provide online learning opportunities for seniors in regional Queensland. Through Positively Ageless, the Bligh government has a long-term strategy for Queensland seniors. From my experience with Everton seniors, this vision is very much a reality. I relish the opportunity to continue supporting the wonderful work of seniors in the electorate that I am honoured to represent.

Mr FOLEY (Maryborough--Ind) (10.26 pm): I rise to bring to the attention of the House a matter that is very concerning for people in my community. Firstly I would like to thank the police minister, Neil Roberts, for opening up a consultation period so that people can comment on the new draft weapons legislation. A number of people have written to me, including people who run laser skirmish venues. Such venues fill a great need in the community. For example, youth groups and various church groups run great team-building exercises and participate in physically demanding exercise at such places. Skirmish and paint ball games provide great exercise and teach people to think laterally. My friend Bob Davis, who runs Splat Attack at Susan River, is so committed to the community that he also runs a Hard Yakka program for kids who have become disconnected, which has been the subject of much debate in this House. Bob does a brilliant job.

Tonight I will particularly zero in on the laser skirmish industry. When similar laws were enacted in New South Wales, the result was that players under 18 years were banned from playing laser skirmish and other laser tag games. Some operators were forced to work under positively draconian legislation. It is a very popular game for things such as birthday parties and team-building exercises. It is a multimillion dollar industry in the states. It is of concern that the proposed draft act has broadened the definition of ‘firearm’ from replica to imitation and does not differentiate between real firearms and toys.

A number of sporting shooters have also written to me about this. I am a member of the Sporting Shooters Association, Wide Bay branch. I regularly participate in target shooting. It is a sport that is enjoyed by everyone from kids to mature-age participants. Target shooting is a fantastic sport for people with disabilities. People travel from all over Queensland to participate in sporting shooting events, which has a tremendously strong emphasis on safety and family participation.

I am a licensed pistol and rifle target shooter. There is a disconnect where people think that shooting must be bad. I remind members of this House that target shooting is an Olympic and Commonwealth Games sport. An added burden of compliance has been put on shooters, and legitimate shooters do not deserve to be sacrificed and put in the same basket as people who work outside the law and completely flout the law. I commend the minister for opening this up for discussion.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Narangba Valley State High School; Building the Education Revolution
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr RYAN (Morayfield--ALP) (10.29 pm): Recently I was pleased to attend the Narangba Valley State High School’s school musical Beauty and the Beast . All performers--whether they were singing or dancing on stage, playing instruments in the orchestra, or helping as a stagehand or sound and lighting technician--contributed to a brilliant production. I was certainly very impressed by the quality of the performances and the production generally, and I can say without any qualification that the standing ovation and multiple demands for an encore were not only genuine but also unanimous from members of the audience.

Specifically, I would like to pay tribute to the lead performers--Nate Edwards, who played the beast, and Vivien Emsworth-Copland, who played Belle. Their performances were flawless and reinforce that they have bright futures in the dramatic arts. The live orchestra also is most deserving of particular praise. The orchestra was made up entirely of students and they were just brilliant.

I also want to note the contributions of the people who designed and built an electronic red rose. I understand that teachers, students and parents came together to design an electronic red rose that automatically dropped its petals at key points during the performance. I commend those involved for this innovative work. It was the icing on the cake.

Finally, I want to highlight the magnificent contribution to this production by the teaching staff. Mr John Coulson and his teaching staff are to be highly commended for their dedication and their vision. They should not underestimate the impact that their contribution has had on the young people of Narangba Valley High.

Well done to everyone at Narangba Valley High. I will certainly remember the day that Beauty and the Beast was performed at your school. And I will certainly remember the day that you made me so proud of the public education system in Queensland. State schools are great schools, and Narangba Valley High certainly proved that on this day.

While I am on my feet, I want to inform the House about some of the outstanding building projects underway at the Narangba Valley State High School and more broadly throughout the Morayfield state electorate. The federal Labor government has been very kind to schools and communities around Australia. Never before have we seen so much investment in educational infrastructure. At Narangba Valley High, a language centre is being built under the federal Labor government’s Building the Education Revolution program. This building project is not only supporting jobs in the local area but also delivering a critically important facility for the Narangba Valley community. However, if Tony Abbott and the LNP had their way, Narangba Valley High would never get a language centre. Moreover, if Tony Abbott and the LNP had their way, Morayfield State High School would never get a trade training centre or new science labs. If Tony Abbott and the LNP had their way, Caboolture Special School would never get a refurbished school hall. If Tony Abbott and the LNP had their way, Burpengary State School would never get new classrooms.

I am proud of the schools in the Morayfield state electorate, and I will do everything I can to support them and their wonderfully talented staff and students. Sadly, Tony Abbott and the LNP want to hurt our schools and our students. How nasty, Mr Abbott. How nasty.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 10.32 pm.
